RATING: 2
I understand and appreciate that a lot of time and energy went into the design, there are just some aspects of the game that are crippling *to me*. I find that the critical nature of my decisions are decreasing as the game wears on to the point that after the first round is over, I'm already past the half-way point on that decline. What faction you pick, and where you start your settlements will have a bigger effect on your success rate than any other factor in our experience (related to how likely it is that someone can effectively steal a spot from you, how effectively you can expand and exploit your faction's specialty, etc). This goes hand in hand with the static setup of the board, so the variable powers have favored setup locations and strategy already defined for them during that critical decision making period. As such, there are only a few spots that are of particular value for each faction, and outside of that, it's not worth it. So the net effect here is that all of my super important choices occur before the first turn, and as the game progresses, each choice I make is less likely to create any serious swing or effect on the end game, to the point where the final 2 rounds are largely auto-pilot in terms of game play.

Second, I find that I have 8 or 10 choices each turn, but really only 1 or 2 of those will do anything other than cause a backslide (similar to the opening setup choices), so I don't spend my time debating choices so much as taking the obvious choice and planning multiple turns of obvious choices in advance. It's a very tight game in that regard where the potential to "catch up" or make breakthroughs to put pressure on opponents in the second half of the game just doesn't exist. I like wide choices where no one choice sinks you and they are largely opportunistic in their timing and accordance with your strategy. Terra Mystica seems to favor a "deep" approach where you don't have as many choices, but you plan for multiple turns in concert. 

Last, it takes about four times as long to play a 4p game as I'm realistically interested in investing in said design. A large reason for this is that the late game decisions are all sort of meh. I actually enjoy the game when I can bang out a session online on lodev in 30 minutes.

It's not a bad game, it's just not a game for me. My 7 plays in person (3-4p) and 10+ on lodev have helped me learn my preferences in games, so it's not time wasted, but I won't play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The theme is bizarre and thin, the board is garish and bland (is that even possible), the description of gameplay sounds derivative, and yet...this is a great game.

An area control/building/point grab game that scales very well from 2-5 players, and combines a variety of tried and true mechanics with some new subtle twists.  There are a set number of rounds during which you, as one of 14(!) unique races, try to conquer as much territory as possible and score as many points as possible.  You have 3 currencies in the game, money, workers, and power tokens, all of which are useful and scarce at different points in the game.  Money and workers are needed for buildings which give you income advantages and set you up for potential point scoring.  Power tokens give you access to extra actions.

Points are scored in game by meeting various round conditions (these vary from game to game), by meeting the criteria of some specific races, and by building cities.  End game points are scored for longest contiguous area and for most influence on the cult tracks.  There's alot of different, variable moving pieces in this game and it really is more than the sum of it's parts (and it has alot of parts).  When this gets a proper wide distribution it will probably be a top 20 or better game on BGG.  Looking forward to more designs by this team.

Own the [boardgame=161317]Fire & Ice[/boardgame] expansion, as well as the [boardgame=149890]4 town tiles[/boardgame], [boardgame=150740]spielbox bonus card[/boardgame] and [boardgame=184895]Erweiterungsbogen[/boardgame] promos.

RATING: 10
The heaviest game I own, in both weight and play experience. The first play through and set-up might be daunting, but persist and you will find a beautiful, challenging experience that rewards your initial fear. Once you've played it once, the set up is easy and the rules fluent and accessible. Highly recommended to watch a play through online first, then get a demo at a trade show/local store if possible. Even if you can't, if you want something meaty and intrinsically satisfying, get it.

RATING: 8
This is a very fun game, but be prepared for the first game to last a while.  There are a lot of choices and small rules to learn and absorb, and anyone prone to AP will have difficulty determining what optimal plays are with this one.

The races all have interesting interactions, but I feel that there are some that are strictly inferior or just un-fun if you get stuck with them.  This is, however an interesting and tight euro with many different avenues to explore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terra Mystica was one of the first games that really opened me up to the broader horizons of Eurogaming. I have it to thank for my love of Lancaster, Russian Railroads, and Tigris and Euphrates. And still, two years later, few games are as epic in scope nor as fulfilling in strategy as Terra Mystica.

I love civilization/engine-building games, and Terra Mystica is one of the best. Through two hours, you'll be building up your civilization, expanding through buildings that make you wealthier and more powerful, and manipulating the four religious tracks to gain points. Yes, this is more of an abstract puzzle than an immersive, thematic experience -- more Eclipse than Civilization -- but it's worth it, because the puzzle of the game is just so, so good. 

I haven't found a 'dudes on a map' game that really satisfies all my desires, and Terra Mystica does without even really being a dudes on the map sort of game. The map forces you together with your opponents -- and yet the power leaching mechanic rewards you for cozying up to them and building your empire right next to theirs.

Overall, Terra Mystica offers a near-unmatched experience. The only game I've found that comes close to it is Scythe, and that's an entirely different sort of puzzle that, while very good, is also very different. Terra Mystica remains one of the tensest games I've played and I look forward to getting a lot of play out of my own personal copy.

RATING: 7
Rules explanation took approaching an hour, which serves to show the amount of different elements which make up Terra Mystica. Despite that, the rules feel fairly intuitive once playing - everything hangs together well. It may be slightly overcooked, as seems to be the trend in 2012/13 with big-hitters Bora Bora, Tzolkin and the like, but it doesn't feel as bulky as those other titles. It's an intelligent game, which doesn't outstay its welcome. I don't know if I really fancy ever having to teach it to someone else, so it may not be one I ever purchase!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
5 plays / 3,4,5 players.

LIKE: Different races all have different powers and combos, which make mixed strategies. Deep decision tree, the strategies have interesting arcs.

DISLIKE: Very disparate mechanisms. The cult track seems tacked on. I almost want the cult and magic tokens to work together, but I understand why they did it this way. The bits can be fiddly. Many, many corner case rules. The game is difficult to comprehend first time through.

OVERALL: The more I play this, the more I appreciate it. The map and tracks add a nice competitive element, and both are tied to your strategy. The game feels similar to Tzolk'in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you have any interest in Euros, this is a must play (although be prepared for a long rules explanation).  This is likely bound for my Top 10 I like it that much.  I really want to try out all of the factions.

This game reminds me of Dominion (hear me out...).  Once you have your faction, you can literally plan out your entire game based on your faction's strengths and the scoring tiles.  With that said, you need to make some in game tactical adjustments based on how the other players play.  In Dominion, it is very similar.  You survey the available cards, decide on the most efficient way to build your deck, then execute your plan with minor tactical adjustments based on the cards your opponents are acquiring.

Five plays in, I've now tried : Witches, Dwarves, Alchemists, Halflings, Auren.

RATING: 8
Excellent game with many interesting dependencies and unique play mechanics. Building cities and gaining power under strained conditions leads to excruciatingly difficult decisions. The various races in the game play quite differently and are wildly (?) unbalanced. My main take back is the trouble for new players. They can be crushed when playing against experienced folks - and frustration will set in when they realize they made early mistakes. The game is unforgiving in this way. But this hardly matters because discovering optimal play is delightful (even if losing in play)! I love it.

RATING: 7
I'm not usually a fan of area-control games, but this one has enough resource management and economic engine building to make it interesting for me.  It feels a little like a cross between Small World and Settlers of Catan (but without Catan's randomness).  There's very little randomness and lots of paths to victory, which is good.  Why don't I rate it higher?  Mostly because of my aforementioned disinterest in area control games, and because TM doesn't do anything particularly innovative.  It's a solid game, but not one I'd want to play regularly.

RATING: 9
首次嘗試，玩4人局，配件多、設置複雜，講解大約40分鐘，規則直觀，遊戲機制相當貼合主題，只是要額外花時間講解種族並熟悉，需要找長期玩家共同投入會更有趣，否則每次光講解就飽了。

得分方式多元，且因為城市建設的關係而富有成就感，遊戲的變化性/耐玩性在於
1、種族變化 2、每回合獎勵目標變化 3、遊戲結束時獎勵目標變化 4、多元得分與城市升級，後期資源會越來越豐厚。

遊戲針對性不強，唯一針對性是在鏟地時，可能搶走別人將要開發的地皮，其它時候都是在選取獎勵/升級來壯大自己，增加資源，比較像是競賽，並且某些決策有它的機會成本。

我很樂意再次體驗它，但卻不想擁有它，因為還要熟記規則並經常教導新人，每場遊戲加上設置耗時相當長。

RATING: 10
I was sold before the first game had ended. Will play this any time. Always.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.95
One of my favorites on the heavier strategy side of my shelf, even though my initial enthusiasm has waned just a bit over repeated plays.  It's sort of like a combination of Puerto Rico, Settlers of Catan, and Small World, sprinkled liberally with pure genius.    

The art design of the game is beautiful AND brilliant, making it relatively easy for new players to pick up--lots of visual cues on the player mats so that everyone is constantly reminded of how all of the various rules work and how they interact.  I like that all of the factions are not created equal--some certainly seem much easier to win with than others.  This allows for some balancing among players of different skill levels, which makes this game more enjoyable for newbies than Agricola, for example.

Lots of choices in this game which could lead to analysis paralysis, but not necessarily a game where a bad choice at an inopportune moment seems to cripple you as much as other games (well, except when playing at the highest levels). 

The digital implementation is also well done, particularly given the vast volume of information that needs to be available for purposes of decision optimizing.  I'm actually a little surprised there aren't more bugs (though there are a few that remain even after a number of updates).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Such an interesting one!  The varied player powers and costs, along with the round chit thingies, vary the game nicely.  In addition, those competing desires to be next to others and yet not have them snap up your real estate.  I want to play this more.

6/05/13:  Upgraded to a 9.  LOVE THIS ONE!  Repeated plays bear out the awesomeness.  The 14 factions are cool, but it's the variability in the round bonuses and the turn tiles (whatever they're called) that make this worth playing again and again.  Plus (almost) everyone I introduce it to has enjoyed it.  One guy is lukewarm.  Very well done!

By the way, negatives (aka reasons this isn't a 10 for me):  (1) Game length.  This takes a long time to play though I think it's worth the effort/time.  (2) Lack of speed for player turns.  What other players do can influence what you do, thus making advance planning of your turn difficult at times.  This slows down play and is mildly unavoidable.  (3) The screwage is distinctly annoying.  Where does it occur?  Snapping up power actions and real estate, outflanking on the religion tracks, and in the number of cities.  I *really* dislike the limited number of cities in a 5-player game.  With 4 players, it's very unlikely to be an issue or ever come up.  With 5 players, it's unavoidable and devastating.  You can't wait on forming your cities and, if someone beats you by getting their 3rd (which I've seen happen), you may be out of the game.  Which stinks.

Notwithstanding these, a truly excellent game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like this game.  But for some reason I am really terrible at it... go figure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played this game just twice, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

Terra Mystica is a very challenging game. It feels very tight. You have always so many things to do, but you do not have nearly enough resources to do all what you would like to. You have to set your engine fast and try to use what you have at the best of your chances. The rules are not hard to learn, but the game is very hard to master. I like these things in a game a lot.

I also like the visual impact of the game and the components are a lot cooler than what I expected from the pictures. Also the their quality is very high, expecially the cardboard which is very thick. I don't like the art instead, but it's something I can live with.

The only doubt I have about this game is the balance between the races. I read that some of them are quite stronger than others... and I don't like that. If they were more balanced, this rating would have been higher.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
N/A
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
FAVOURITE GAME - In the land of Terra Mystica dwell 14 different peoples in seven landscapes and each group is bound to its own home environment so to develop and grow they must terraform neighboring landscapes into their home environments in competition with the other groups. Terra Mystica is a game with very little luck that rewards strategic planning. Each player governs one of the 14 groups. With subtlety and craft the player must attempt to rule as great an area as possible and to develop that group's skills. There are also four religious cults in which you can progress. To do all that each group has special skills and abilities. Taking turns the players execute their actions on the resources they have at their disposal. Different buildings allow players to develop different resources. Dwellings allow for more workers. Trading houses allow players to make money. Strongholds unlock a group's special ability and temples allow you to develop religion and your terraforming and seafaring skills. Buildings can be upgraded: Dwellings can be developed into trading houses; trading houses can be developed into strongholds or temples; one temple can be upgraded to become a sanctuary. Each group must also develop its terraforming skill and its skill with boats to use the rivers. It is the ultimate eurogame for me at least.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
And so it comes to past....i've tried TM once and I do have some pretty good feeling about it but similarly the amount of bad vibes do add to it as well.

The board is not modular, so its going to be same-same for repeated plays. Black is there, red is up there and blue hugs the river, etc.

As a Civ game, it lacks confrontation. the only 'war-ish' behaviour comes from opponents taking what you need first or just so happens there was nothing else they can do thus, they expand their territory in that pattern for that particular game session. Gamers expanded, as there was minimal choice, not because it was a strategy. It's not a game, so much as to screw your opponents up that creates confrontation, but its just a simple turn taking event that lead to a certain condition that is 'left by what is available to do.' The options are not 'always' available. Thus I do not see how this game could be that Civ-vy. Once you are there, you are there. period. Not for resources per se, but the changing/upgrading of structures brings new powers and completely removes the old. There is no 'stack em up' ladder.

removing all the beautiful art work, and what we have is a simple exercise of take A to get B and take B to Get C. That's good.....but you have to throw away A and B for that C.

Lots of game have been there and done that. There was no 'situational' gaming aspect that makes it a game to concentrate on. (Like a wargame about stalingrad, even though it may be the same situational battle, the outcome hovers on an expected antagonistic play. Further randomnised by uncertainty in dice rolling....)

Having said that, its a fun exercise with the right group of gamers. Especially those that hate confrontational wipeouts. The lack of random dice does create a math calculation kind of game play.

Beautiful components and artwork. Gameplay is smooth with some decision making in the beginning, but reduces dramatically near end game.

An above average game.

It's like a Rube Goldberg machine that ends with a wet fart.

RATING: 10
Excellent game. Have only ever played 2 player but love it in this format. Started out playing the traditional rules but after getting a hang of the game we saw instructions online for a double world alternative for 2 players. Essentially this involves each player controlling two factions each and at the end of the game they add and then divide their faction scores, to receive their final score. This is a very satisfying mode of play because there is very little down time and you get to develop two different strategies which hopefully complement each other and lead to your victory!

Would recommend this game highly to semi-serious to serious board gamers, and especially recommend 2 player as a great experience.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
It took me a long time to come up with what I wanted to say for this game because it seems like a lot of effort went into the game and I want to get this review right.

The problem is, there's a lot of work going into the exact wrong places in this game. For example:
• The theme is the biggest lie ever. "But who cares?" you say. The designers. They care. Look how much effort they put into writing fictional stories set in this clearly bogus world so you'd think there's theme in the game. That's clearly a case of trying really hard and failing.
• The currency. This game has like 4 currencies and the entire gameplay consists of trying to efficiently convert them. That's it.
• The terraforming. Which ultimately, while it does have impact in the game, is something you actively want to avoid if possible because it costs too much. But TERRA mystica is the name of the goddamn game! You're clearly intended to terraform as one of the major aspects of this game and yet it's so cost-prohibitive that you will only ever do it as a last resort.
• Which leads into the upgrades system. Again, this system just fucks you as you upgrade your buildings. Why? Because they wanted you to have an interesting system where things slow down a bit as you move up. Unfortunately, this just chokes your resources and actions so hard that it removes all fun from the game.
• The scoring. This game is straight up point salad in the worst ways possible. The priest track is the most egregious offender but I've found that new players (including myself) get the most screwed by aiming for those early bonus VP. If you do, they almost invariably stop you from having actions for 3 rounds. THAT'S HALF THE FUCKING GAME.
• Trying to hard to be chess. It's not. It never will be. Stop trying. Chess has symmetry. I personally think chess sucks but even I can tell that Terra Mystica needs to get off its arrogant high-horse with a lot of the stuffy mechanics they jammed into here.
• The awful mana pool system. It's actually BETTER to remove as many as possible, despite the game directly warning you against this. It's disgusting and if you're new and see someone win because they can spam their magic super fast, you're going to flip the fucking table.

Things they didn't work hard enough on:
• The art. This game is droll and boring. Nothing is interesting to look at and the insane number of abstract symbols breeds confusion like bacteria.
• The fucking DOWNTIME. This game is only downtime. I had an idiot fanboy try to sell me on the idea that the literal 20 minutes of downtime pre-game SETUP is just "front-loaded strategy". It's not. It's 20 minutes of downtime where you painstakingly calculate. Which leads to...
• The most important 80% of decision-making is done BEFORE the game starts. I'm not shitting you. The single most important decision by a landslide is where you place your opening towns. If you want proof, just google Terra Mystica strategies. And the second part of 80% of your entire decision making for the whole game is...
• What clan you choose determines if you'll win or not. There's an entire ranking list of the clans with one that's a clear top winner, basically guaranteeing you win since the game is DETERMINISTIC after setup. Which leads to an even bigger problem...
• The game is deterministic after setup. Look, I don't like randomness either but when I can sit there and look at everyone's board and just literally calculate like a fucking computer the best possible moves for the entire game, FUCK YOU for designing it. And by "I" I really mean the actual real Terra Mystica AI that you can google right now that will always win because it can out-compute you. I guess I was wrong, this really is like chess in that regard.

In summary:
Boring, with no life. Stagnant. Doesn't make you want to play ever again. Counter-intuitive gameplay that directly contradicts the rules suggestions. Criminally unbalanced factions. 80% of the game is downtime and setup decisions. Any human ingenuity will always be overcome by pure memory and calculator power. Literally inhuman experience to play. Choked decision-making. A single misplay renders the entire game fucked for you forever, with no ability to recover in any capacity. Fake theme. Fake game. Fuck you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
If there's such a thing as an 'epic' Euro game, then Terra Mystica probably fits. It has some of the flavor of a 4x game, but it's actually a pretty typical construction and resource management Euro ramped up with a cool theme, cool bits, and cool variable races. 

Love the commitment to a full on fantasy theme. And it's fun! It's on the medium-heavy side of the complexity spectrum, but I think it's pretty darn intuitive. The design is so clean it makes me happy.

RATING: 7
Good game, though I wouldn't call it great just yet. It has a heavy dose of determinism, and variability to play, but something about it just lacks spark. Perhaps that will change in future plays. 

(2 plays under belt - a 3 player and a 2 player, both times playing the Nomads). 

I feel this game rewards short term opportunism more than I'd like, where one's actions are in the service of generating points in lieu of doing something "cool" that, incidentally, scores points. For example, my most memorable move in my last game was taking a 3-points-for-a-trade-house tile before a round that scored 3 points for trade house placement. Scored 18 points that round ... and that's about as sexy as it gets.

RATING: 9
An extremely clever engine-builder that has an interesting theme and absolutely beautiful components.  Plays very well and deceptively quick - the playtime drops dramatically as players get more experienced, and the game is all about timing your actions and optimizing  your race's abilities.  Balance is fantastic, though the Darklings are a bit strong and the Fakirs a bit weak, and there's a ton of skill in reading the objectives and other people's picks and grabbing a race (of the giant pile in the box) that plays well with the current spread.

The rules themselves are clean and straightforward, though the rulebook's not great, and the races all play very differently.

Expansion at Essen this year!

RATING: 6
I felt pretty much the same while playing Terra Mystica as I did while playing Agricola.  Here is an admirable piece of design that achieves some quite complex things in intuitive, streamlined ways.  And those complex things all fit together to make a thoroughly coherent whole. That I am not champing at the bit to play either game again is down to personal taste. Terra Mystica is a luck-free, low interaction exercise in efficiency.  Each game's challenge is to grok how to get the optimum out of the race you are playing.  The terra-forming and board placement promises a level of Settlers-ish crowding and interaction that doesn't quite materialise.  Perhaps there is simply too much space and too little time (six rounds) to really get in each other's way.  

Production quality is very good.  The artwork is quite functional but rather dull.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Now that I've got two plays under my belt, it will be interesting to see if I continue to learn much strategy wise.  I'm not going to read the strategy articles, at least for a while, but based on my limited experience the keys to winning in order seem to be:

1. Fully understand the advantages and disadvantages of your character and how that impacts what you develop and where on the map you need to focus

2. Integrate the end of turn bonuses into your overall strategy.  You don't want to go completely out of your way, but it is a very important source of victory points that many players ignore.  I believe the ability to manage this properly is often the difference in games that involve experienced players.

3. Grab the bonus wish tiles for settlements and trading posts as early as possible. There may be characters for which this is problematic, but I have a hard time seeing somebody winning without one or both of these bonuses by the end of turn 3.

4. Don't worry too much about the end of game bonuses for connections and temples until the last turn or two.  Earlier in the game there is usually better things to do, and you don't want to get in a pissing match trying to get the lead.  

5.  Getting a third town is nice, but I think it is sufficiently tricky that you are almost always better off doing something else less risky.

RATING: 10

RATING: 5
A big, deep and extremely overrated game that initially bruises your brain for relatively little eventual payoff. The fantasy theme here is entirely pasted on and the magic bowl thing is malarkey. The main board is painfully dull to look at; very euroy and beige, but all those wooden bits are lovely. It's cool that there are lots of varied ways to go about getting points, but this game is overwhelming for new players and there are other things I'd prefer to teach and play. It's definitely not bad. A lot of it is good. It just shouldn't be top 10 on BGG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a good gamers' game, if not as spectacular as the current hype might suggest.  Two seemingly novel mechanics are particularly praiseworthy and interesting to think about and play with in Terra Mystica: the power bowls mechanism and the terra-forming mechanism.  Very nicely done.

The other mechanisms are also fun, and include a lot of familiar and pleasant things we have seen before, and I can see how the assymetrical powers and the evident, various pathways to earning VP's are likely to draw us gamers into wanting to play Terra Mystica a number of times to "figure it out."  

I think this game is "Feldian" in the sense that it's primary focus is on combining interesting mechanisms into a distinctive game with interesting decisions, rather than being thematically driven or determined, as perhaps, your average Wallace game would be.  As such, in the final analysis, Terra Mystica is not a very thematic game unless you "buy" the idea that playing a character type, and building wooden buildings to become towns, makes the game highly thematic.  It doesn't.  On the other hand, the game does create its own aesthetic and world, and that "world" feels like a nice place to play in, so the game has decent atmosphere.  

Actually, I think this game "out Felds" a lot of Feld games that are perched in the top ranks of BGG.  What that means to me is that if I am in the mood to play this type of game, I would much rather play Terra Mystica than Trajan, Notre Dame, Macao, or Year of the Dragon.  For me, this game has "fired" Trajan.  I would not want to play Trajan again if Terra Mystica were available to play instead.

I finally had a chance to play this game and enjoyed it as much as I expected.  It probably didn't hurt that I won ;)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I usually describe this game to people as similar to Go, if Go was about 4 fantasy races colonizing Louisiana. It's weird, tense, counterintuitive, and crazily deep. 

The good: TM is tremendously strategic and varied. Well-suited to the gamer who enjoys researching gameplay in their spare time. The game is all about depth of replay value. 

The bad: not for the casual. The game easily punishes you for using the wrong strategy with the wrong race, and the races are a bit unbalanced and must be played very differently. 

This is the most critical review I've made of a game that is one of my great favorites. TBH my greatest criticism is that the barrier to entry for new players is a bit high (it takes at least a full game before you know what is going on). If not for this, I'd play it every damn weekend. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love this game. Probably too dense for non gamers.

RATING: 7
First impressions summed up in one word ‘Convoluted’. 

It had very little luck which is a good thing for a game of this complexity and length. It seemed like you needed to pull a lot of levers and press a lot of buttons to progress your civilisation a minimal amount. It was a learning game and with only two players so I realise I’m seeing it in its worst light.

I tend to shy away from games of this complexity these days. I get at very least, the same amount of enjoyment from the pure abstracts or the more streamlined, cleaner rule set, brain burners.

It also left me wondering if it needed more conflict for my personal tastes. It did have quite a bit of meat in the growing and building so I'm not sure yet.  

Once learned thoroughly though and with the right amount of players to tighten up the board I’m sure there is a lot of fun to be had here.

RATING: 10
Most of my plays of Terra Mystica were online. Terra Mystica is the best Euro I've ever played and it certainly deserves its spot on BGG Rankings.

The subtle changes of each game and the combination of different races make this game a unique experience every single time. Highly recommended to anyone who has even a remote interest in Euro-style board games.

The reason I don't need this game in my collection is I have a friend who owns it and there won't be many opportunities to play this game on the table with three other people around the same skill level anyway.

terra.snellman.net is a perfect online implementation and everyone should give it a try.

RATING: 9
Variable player powers, economic engine building, four+ currencies, and competition for limited space.  As a bonus, victory points are granted at the whim of randomly chosen (before the game) tiles, and the things you do for points often do not align very well with the things you need to do to grow your economy.  At the moment I think this is wonderful, but I worry that it's actually just a parsing problem disguised as a game with meaningful decisions.  I'm having fun parsing though, even after a dozen plays.  Much of the game is front-loaded, with a pre-first turn plan needed as to which scoring bonuses you plan to hit and when.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

If you'd have shown me this 10 years ago I would have been all over it but this is just more themeless euro number crunching where you adapt to board situations and sit in near silence with your fellow gamers while you figure out, to be honest a very clever, little puzzle.

I see why people like this. Not sure it deserves the high praise it gets as it is nothing new. Not for me.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
I tried playing Terra Mystica against an AI several times, and the game is better than I thought it would be. Nonetheless, there are some problems. (1) The player interaction is small, you may want to try to stop your opponents from building towns on the map, or compete for some cards or bonuses, but this doesn't make a huge difference. You'll want to expand/build wherever it's cheaper to do so, so hurting or affecting your opponent in anyway is pretty rare. (2) This is an extremely complex game, and you have to find players that don't mind that. There are so many competing factors to think about, that analysis paralysis should be quite common. (3) Each faction will be played pretty much the same way every time, in other words, there is a dominant strategy for each faction. You want to take advantage of the stronghold and sanctuary powers for almost every faction, and that is basically what you're limited to. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I'm considering trading this, as it seems too long/heavy to get to the table much

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The learning curve on this game can appear steep, but it's important to note that learning the game is harder than actually playing the game... significantly so.  There are lots of elements and exceptions to try and manage in your head as you read the rules.  The rule book is not the most clear, but it has more to do with how to present the game than with poor writing or translations.  If you can learn the game from someone, the journey will be much simpler.

Once the rules are comprehended, actual game play is quite simple.  6 Rounds with 3 phases each: Collect Income, Actions (multiple mini-turns with 1 of 8 actions), clean-up and prep next round.  The individual actions are easy to understand.  What you get on the output of this though is a rich complex game with a nice balance of player interactions and individual planning.  The duration of the game is quite well refined, leaving players feeling neither like the game overstayed its time nor being too short to get anything done.  The game achieves a unique combination feel of being both very well balanced and asymmetric.  The former coming from the mechanisms and the latter from the different factions.  

Overall, this is a solid title and a good candidate for the Kennerspiel 2013 prize.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There's a lot going on in this game, which combined with only a single play leaves me a bit uncertain about the rating. 

Mechanics wise, the game is very good. It's a mix of resource management, building placement and upgrading game; nothing truly groundbreaking, but I thought the energy system was innovative and a nice way to introduce some direct interaction and extra strategizing into the game. I also enjoyed the way the game is structured to curtail a snowball effect through the building upgrades. There's a lot of things to balance, and for now it felt like it's possible for different approaches to be sucessful. 

These great mechanics are largely dissociated from theme, which for me is unfortunate as I prefer otherwise, although I appreciate that the game for the most part is honest about being abstract and doesn't try too hard to shoehorn a theme into it.

Finally, all the different factions and their subtle differences are a big plus. Though I think there's a definite risk that they're not fully balanced, it felt like they potentially favour different approaches providing a lot of replayability, and should make for an interesting analysis of the various possible strategies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
It's a more complex Eclipse-like economy with an interesting area control mechanic. Shut up and Sit down said it best when they said "everything in this game will remind you of a different game" - but it's all fun. 

As far as Euros go, this one is really good.

I really want to get it to the table more. I feel like at this point I've only scratched the surface of the game and it's going to get better with more plays (and I see how to block other players rather than just go for my own goals.)

I like the snowball affect it has. The game is only 6 turns, but that last turn is about as long as the first four combined.

RATING: N/A
Organizer - Meeple Realty
Terra Mystica: Fire & Ice
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
A whole lot of moving parts, but they fit together _really_ well. Very high replayability due to the massive amount of distinct races, great components, and reasonably swift gameplay despite the total length. Occasionally someone will have a bout of analysis paralysis, but generally most individual turns flow swiftly (as mostly the previous action won't cause you to have to rethink what you're doing), meaning that you generally don't have too long to wait until your next turn, even in a five player game. Deserves its swift rise through the ranks.

Bumped up my rating for this after six plays from 8.7 to 8.9, and further to 9.2 after seven plays; the more I play this, the more I start to appreciate all the ways this game has been balanced. So many subtle tweaks to the board and the different races. Games keep getting more intense. This won't ever rise to a 10, but it's overtaken Agricola way faster than I'd have expected.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like it, but I have plenty of better games, and because of it's (gameplay) weight it rearly lands on a table

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Yes. It really is *that* good. It deserves its very high ranking. The rules might be a bit daunting at the beginning, but once you get going, it's a wonderful game. 

It has multiple ways of scoring, but it's not really a point salad, as the two only real ways to score are expanding or increasing your religion.

It also provides you of myriads of ways to bypass someone else "blocking" you (as in, stopping you from doing what you had planned), even if they tend to cost a bit more effort. But you're never completely out of options, and that is really rare in a game so deep.

It might grow up to a perfect 10 for me. I've only played it once, but I'm really glad I bought this gem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic mechanics with a lovable fantasy theme. Nice depth in gameplay and strategy. The amount of resources to keep track of can seem overwhelming at first, but by the time your first game is over you see how things should work.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
Must have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting games.  With a couple of sessions under my belt it's hard to give a rating.  In my last game I felt like I did everything right and was leading in all the end game scoring categories and somehow came in last place.

Very keen to dig deeper into this one (no pun intended).  It feels very different from other Euros.  Is it an area control game?  Well sort of.  Is it economic?  Yes probably.  Point-Salad?  I suppose.

It's also a bear to teach.  There are so many moving parts and systems that it's difficult to know how best to lay it all out for new players.

The other big question people might have is whether or not this is "thematic".  I feel the answer is both yes and no.

Yes - The things you do seem to make sense mechanics wise.  Build small houses for basic workers.  upgrade to trading poses for more money, or temples for more priests.  etc etc.

No - While the individual parts make sense to me, Im not sure those parts really jive well with the fantasy setting.  In fact it's not super clear that this game is really about anything.  If you were to make a list of the things that you should be able to do in a "fantasy civ" game I dont think any of the actions in Terra Mystica would be on that list.

So it's an strange sort of a beast.  Very interesting game play in a setting that isn't nessesarly compelling but still thematically coherent. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The design is genius, a magnificent feat of the human brain. But do I want to play it again?  The only way I could answer yes is if I somehow became so wealthy that I did nothing but play board games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It is fantastic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ez egy nagyon jó játék!! A 2012 Esseni nagy favoritok közül volt több csalódás is (Escape, Keyflower, és egy kicsit talán a Robinson is), de a két legsikeresebb darab, a T'zolkin és ez nem okoztak csalódást.
A Terrát úgy harangozta be mindenki, mint egy bonyolultabb Hansa Teutonicát, ami az egyik kedvencem, ezért nagyon kíváncsi lettem. Nos a hasonlóság kb. abban kimerül, hogy a saját táblánkon tudunk fejlesztgetni... szerintem félrevezető volt ez a hasonlat. De ettől még szuper a játék:)
Pozitívumok: A manna rész nagyon ötletes, a terraformázás átszínezős megoldása is tetszik. Nagyon jó ötlet az is, hogy a legfontosabb épület olcsóbb, ha más mellé építjük, így szinte szükségszerűen egymás közelében leszünk, ugyanazokra a hexákra akarunk majd építeni, így dinamikusabb lesz a térképes rész. A sok faj (7x2) nagyon nagy újrajátszhatóságot sejtet, és 7 teljes szett fa van a játékban, tehát nem spóroltak az anyaggal, pedig valószínűleg 5 szettel is megoldhatták volna. A játék egyébként nagyon szép, igényes, tökéletesen nyelvfüggetlen.

Negatívumok: A hajós rész talán egy kicsit felesleges bonyolítás, de gondolom letesztelték, és a híd kevés lenne, túl könnyű lenne keresztbetenni egymásnak.
A másik, hogy elég sok mindenre kell figyelni, nekem határeset, még éppen belefér ennyi, de azért van pár öncélú dolog, amit csak azért tettek bele láthatólag, hogy bonyolutabb legyen tőle a játék. Mert itt aztán tényleg minden van: templomozás, mint a T'zolkinban, bónuszok választása kb. a Puerto Ricos mechanizmus szerint, vannak extra akció lehetőségek (fixen a táblán és egyéb helyeken is), van egy fajta lapka mindenféle bónuszokkal, amit a vallási épületek építésekor kapunk, egy másik féle lapka, amit a városok építésekor, stb. Elég nagy az AP veszély.
A sok faj, amit pozitívumnak írtam, talán kicsit kérdésessé teszi a kiegyenlítettséget is. Pl. Az Engineers elég gyengének tűnt, a Witches meg sokkal erősebbek, de biztos mindet lehet jól játszani, csak bele kell jönni. A játékszabály 1 óra, a dobozon szereplő játékosonkénti fél óra játékidő pedig nyugodtan szorozható legalább másféllel.
Összességében nagyon bejött, annak ellenére, hogy hosszan soroltam a negatívumokat is, ez még akár nagy kedvenc is lehet, ha lesz olyan társaság, akikkel gyakran elővesszük.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[121102 - 5 játékos]
Ki kell jelentenem, hogy ez egy REMEK játék!
Több korábbi játék mechanizmusa felismerhető benne, azonban a "hatalom tál/manna" használata unikum.
A tartozékok mennyiségére, és azok minőségére nem lehet panasz. Van benne anyag és "erő"...
A 14 faj más-más képessége pedig garancia a játék sokszínűségére és újra játszhatóságára. (bevallom vannak fenntartásaim az olyan játékokkal kapcsolatosan, ahol a játékosok nem azonos "feltételek / lehetőségek" mellett játszanak!)
A játék szabályrendszerét nem mondanám bonyolultnak, inkább talán sok "apróság"-ra kell figyelni. (pl. leléptem a megszerzett VP-t?)
Egy lépés során nyolc akció közül lehet választani, így azok megtervezése, illetve sorrendjük kialakítása elég embert próbáló.
Kizárólag gyakorlott játékosok számára ajánlott!

Szívem szerint 8.5 pontot adnék neki, azonban a borzasztóan hosszú játékmenet - sok holtidővel - ront ezen.(Úgy vélem 4 játékos az ideális játékosszám.)
Ennek ellenére bármikor szívesen játszom vele a jövőben...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I approached Terra Mystica with caution, more than a year after its initial release, due to distribution problems (it seemed victim of some kind of curse, and the italian version was repeatedly delayed, while the Z-man version was in reprint after reprint). The hype and #7 on BGG… what to expect from this game?

Just one word: awesomeness!

14 races with asymmetric powers, variable set up with different short term goals, great interaction, tough trade-offs between points and development, awesome components. And the gameplay is smoother than one can expect from a game with so many moving parts and intertwined mechanics.

Is there anything I can add?

Can't wait to play it again and again, and explore all the different races and strategies.

I definitely feel it will find its place in my top 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Excellent strategy game. Asymmetrical factions keep the game fresh. How well you employ those asymmetries often decides the game's outcome. If you want an involved asymmetric efficiency engine with scoring variability, this game is for you. 

Once you learn to play a particular faction, you may find the game to play out a bit prescriptively when you play that faction. That prescriptiveness is an indication that the faction assymmetries hide that this game is less a competition for board presence and more a puzzle played alongside others.

RATING: 10
This game is really not that hard to learn despite its heaviness. The player board is really intuitive (maybe cause of the similarities with Scythe that I played before this) and it has so many nice hefty wooden components. To do well in this game is an entirely different story, it rewards repeated play and it provides the most nail-biting experience if everyone is experienced in it. 

Replayability is insane in this game with the huge number of races and there's no luck at all completely in this game. Everything is open information right from start, you can map out your entire game right from the get go. This is like Catan meets Scythe, improved one hundred times over. Strongly deserves its place in BGG top 10.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
S+E
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Terra Mystica seems to think that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts -- and it has parts [i]in spades[/i]. The idea is interesting, and the graphic design of the game is quite well done. Unfortunately, I find that the overall experience falls quite flat. 

The variable income resulting from building new dwellings or upgrading existing structures is an interesting idea, and helps to create a very tight budget for each player. (I won't say 'economy', because I don't think there is enough interaction to call it an 'economy'.) This income mechanism combined with the limited rounds and increasing marginal cost of terraforming certainly creates a tense experience trying to accomplish your strategy. However, this tension comes at a significant cost: due to the large number of 'resources' (or 'currencies') and the possibility to converting between them, this game is incredibly mathematical. Calculating, re-calculating, and re-re-calculating costs, incomes, and conversions is necessary to execute any kind of plan. Being thwarted by an opponent is fun; being thwarted by miscalculating a three-step resource conversion [i]from the last turn[/i] is not. 

Connected with this is a strong feeling that the game is simply needlessly complex, perhaps to appeal to the idea that more nice wooden and cardboard bits make a better game. Besides balancing factions that rely on it and adding a function for the priests, what purpose does the cult track serve? The many sources of VP also diminish the opportunities for player interaction, and make strategy more opaque (rather than [i]deeper[/i]; the former is undesirable, the latter is desirable). This is despite the fact that all players are seemingly competing for spaces on the common map. Due to the limited resources and high costs of terraforming, it seems to rarely make sense to play aggressively (except perhaps in a two-player game), as otherwise the other players will gain a relative advantage.

For this reason, the player interaction is mainly found in the round action tiles, round bonus tiles, and (perhaps to a lesser extent) the town, bonus, and favor tiles. The fact that the main player interaction is jockeying for action tiles and round bonuses and competing for the 'best' bonus tiles, rather than 'on the board', is somewhat anticlimactic given the apparent opportunities for player interaction via terraforming. I don't really care for this sort of player interaction in general, and perhaps care for it even less in Terra Mystica as it is so critical to performing well but is also overly complex in and of itself and obfuscated by the complexity of the rest of the game. 

The different factions are a key feature of the game and seem to reflect a trend of providing 'variable experiences' (artificially increasing replay value) in lieu of depth of strategy and/or balance. And balance is a key issue with Terra Mystica: the factions are quite imbalanced, to the extent that bidding for factions with VP is essentially necessary to make the game competitive. This compounds the following point, which is that the game is dominated by early planning and execution rather than adaptability. Like Dominion and Princes of Florence before it, Terra Mystica requires players to develop a strategy at the outset based on the round bonuses and action tiles in play, and then execute that strategy as efficiently and flawlessly as possible. The problems with this type of 'front-loaded' strategy in Terra Mystica is (i) the execution of the strategy is dominated by the mathematical nature of the game (see comments on resource conversions), and (ii) it takes a [i]long[/i] time to see your plan through to completion. Compare this to Dominion, which requires similar front-loaded strategic planning, but plays quickly, or Princes of Florence, which shares features including limited rounds, but reduces 'brain-burning' complexity to allow players to focus on interactions for key auction items and best work.

A quote from BGG user Cole Wehrle sums up some of my remaining thoughts (emphasis added): [i]Update: A few more plays are confirming some of my fears. It is [b]much harder to block and interact with skilled players[/b]. The [b]most interesting relationships in this game are with non-players[/b] (the various conversions). There is [b]little sense of a "game"[/b] and [b]very few ways to manage incentives[/b]. In short, it's [b][u]a conversion puzzle performed in proximity[/u][/b][/i]. If the 'game' poses more challenges to me than the other players, I would rather find something else to play; even worse if the game is as brain burning as Terra Mystica. 

Terra Mystica is an interesting concept -- or perhaps a collection of interesting concepts -- and one which obviously appeals to many people, but I find it to be more [i]work[/i] than game, and ultimately not very much fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Eseen 2012: A rule book that takes some time to get through but well presented none the less. After reading the rules I could not envisage how the game would play. Having finished game one I don't think I could.

This is a very heavy Euro. The options for each turn are clear but you are swamped for choice. At game start your options are limited, by turn 6 you are scrabbling around trying to beat the others to the key features and points. There are so many paths to victory.

Game 1 needs to be considered a learning experience, after that this will become an extremely cut throat battle for experienced players. I'm looking forward to game 2.

Second and third games all in the same day. I like this one alot and the winner is never cut and dried until the very end.

RATING: 9

This one is just great, and I love the competitive synergies that evolve around being in proximity, and all the little races that come along with that. Speaking of races, the factions are all well done and interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
From the designer of Kaivai, one of my top games, comes this gem of a gamer's game. Everything about the game screams excellence. The strategical choices, the immense replayability with the different races, the tactical options being made within your strategies, the theme, the components and, of course, the well thought out design all lead to awesomeness in a few hours.

Central to the game is a terraforming mechanic which requires resources, tech upgrades and the ability to intelligently compete for spaces on the board to do well. Intertwined with this mechanic are the different races' special abilities which give the game longevity. Each round provides a different victory point condition (different every game) for that specific round which guide your choices of when to build certain buildings, when to terraform, when to hold back and when to explode with your actions.

Granted, if you are averse to heavy Euro games, this might not be your cup of tea, but for heavy Euro gamers this is a delicious dish that doesn't leave room for dessert.

After the fourth play: I have been officially converted. This game is amazing. It most definitely gets better and better, whereas I often cool off on euros after a few plays. The multiple races really make this game. Rating = 9.

Very over rated

RATING: 8

Negative: There is some downtime. You have to form your strategy before the game, actually before you decide for a race, since you choose the race best suited to the set-up, which is hard for beginners. You cannot adjust in the later stages of the game. There is not much interaction, but its not multiplayer solitaire.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A massive euro for hardcore eurogamers, Terra Mystica doesn’t feature even a scrap of theme apart from the fourteen different races it includes, which are just a pretext to give each player different ways to grind his path to victory by amassing points, thus granting the game an almost unlimited replayability.

Undoubtedly, Terra Mystica is a well conceived game and, unlike most euros, it even seems to somehow forgive mistakes as well: in fact, should you take a false step, you may lose some victory points (as it needs to be) but at least you don’t waste your whole turn (which happens too often in this kind of games) and still have the opportunities to make up over the next few actions.

Anyhow, although it’s a very good game, I still find it too long, cold and demanding for my taste.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's one of those games where you need to do a bit of everything to succeed.  For those brainy types looking to clash wits this will be a delight.  For guys looking for fun with plenty of shitbaggin' and trash talk?  Not so much.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not a terrible game, but not one I'd be willing to play twice.

PROS:  The mechanics were interesting and unique.  Some of them were similar to those of other games, but changed enough to be unique.

CONS:  I'm not convinced that the races are balanced, and the random phase bonuses can easily favor one race over the others.  There are four different kinds of currency used to advance your race (workers, money, priests, and power) and there always seems to be a lack.  On your turn, you feel very limited which is probably by design.  Still, as you grow your civilization, it doesn't feel like any real progress is being made toward becoming more prosperous.  It seemed everyone was still as frustrated and desperate for currency toward the end as they were at the beginning.  Also, nothing exciting ever happens.  The game just continues the same as it always has, each phase basically the same as the last, with all bonuses being additive with no way of gaining real momentum on any dimension of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
From the initial rules read it seems like a very complicated game, in my opinion these could have been written better.
After the first play turned out to be quite intuitive and very deep for strategy.

Will see how it pans out over time, but seems quite re-playable. Some races do look to be much better than others, but for diversity of play this might be necessary.

Overall was impressed, very good eurogame and might be light enough to get the less seasoned board gamers playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Another great Civ-like game that has elements from other games you recognize but put together in a most innovative way. The faction powers differ in often subtle ways that need to be experienced to understand. There are many moving parts and at first grasping the game may seem daunting, but like many really good designs you play your way into the flow quickly.

Our group was all brand-new to the game (being punched and sorted virtually minutes before the group gathered), but after a relatively brief tour of the environment we waded in and within a round or two felt we were onto it fairly competently. You soon get a good feel for the relative importance of the various methods of exchange (workers, power, priests and money) and we all felt those moments of having just enough of some, more than was entirely necessary of others, and a critical lack of at least one commodity.

It is entirely safe to say that none of us felt we had maximized our faction advantages, or had a confident handle on the economics of the game. Yet, by the game's end (with five players), one of us had lapped the track (halfling) with another not that far behind, and the rest of us spread variously. Everyone expressed the strong desire to play it again soon - always a good sign!

There are not a lot of random elements (just the turn track which can have a fairly large effect on some of the dynamics) and the player interaction is at best indirect (someone snapping an action you really wanted badly, occupying terrain tiles you wanted for expansion, leap-frogging up the cult ladders, having the largest spread etc.). I imagine some would have wished for some combat dice, but I believe the competition is nonetheless real and can be as cutthroat as any "Waro."

It is a very competent design incorporating some of the best features of recent strategy games (Kingdom Builder, Eclipse and Through the Ages come to mind). I have given it a very strong rating after just one play and I'm looking forward to exploring the various factions which will no doubt keep our interest in the short to medium term - the game's staying power through longer term may be the only question here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Juegazo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I liked this so much more than I was expecting.

Yes it's a euro, and the fantasy theme is a bit weak - there's no combat here and the components are your usual wood houses etc, so you have to work a bit more to get into the thematic side. It is helped by the different races though.

Stuff I like: No luck, no hidden information, different races all a bit different, variable setup (although a variable map would be better, there is a tendency to have prime spots for particular races). Strategic - you need to have a plan, rather than just react.

There is a bit of interaction, although it can be played as a heads down multiplayer solo experience - much like Race for the Galaxy - you'll do better if you keep an eye on what others are doing and adjust your play accordingly, and there IS a reason for being next to your opponents, which is a bit unusual in a euro area control game :)

Overall, pleasantly surprised with this - there's a reason it's so high in the ratings.

*** Update - playing this a lot, and it scales well with the number of players. I'm still enjoying it, and look forward to playing it. Upped my rating to a 10.

Maybe I'll burn out on it and the rating will come down a bit. We'll see.

RATING: 10

The replay ability of this game is quite staggering.

Must have game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Eurogame puro, con poca interacción. Gestión de recursos para conseguir puntos de victoria. Se trata de construir ciudades, venerar a los elementos, etc con el fin de ir sumando puntos y posicionarse bien para la evaluación final. 

Tiene un sistema de gestión de puntos de poder (magia), muy interesante. Estilo mancala. Mezcla muchas mecánicas de otros juegos, y resulta muy atractivo, aunque es un poco abstracto. Cada jugador lleva una raza y todas son diferentes, cada una con una cualidad. Fue un juego muy esperado y que en general gustó bastante.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A rather intricate system, but it plays quite smoothly once you get the hang of it. A very clever design in which everything seems to fit together pretty well. The "elemental" theme comes across pretty well and the game looks good. I like the trade-off between building near other players (for power and cheaper trading posts) and building away from them (for more land). It's kind of neat to have a land-grabbing game where you're not necessarily upset if someone expands right next to you.

It's a decent enough experience, but in the end I just found it a little bit boring. It feels too much like solving a puzzle for my tastes. While I praised the trading system above, ultimately I'd say this game might just be not interactive enough for me. It doesn't really excite me enough that I want to play it repeatedly. Still, a decent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Have played twice now, but my second play was so far removed from my first, I might as well have never played before. And this is a game where you need a few plays before you can have any real competency. It's a true point salad, and the point gaps awarded between first and second on many of the scoring paths heavily reward players who know the game and punish newcomers. Still though, I do want to play again before I completely forget how to play, and see if it isn't more enjoyable.

RATING: 10
This gets a 10, even though its heavy, game mechanics are beautifully crafted for an immersive gaming experience. I don't know about balance, except what I have read, but its not apparent that it should be an issue. Tough game to play and learn! My 16 year old son said during the game "this is harder than Agricola." Maybe slightly, but it is just as brilliant a design. I typically am not drawn to heavy games, but this one, like Agricola, offers a huge thematic and mechanical delight with the gameplay that the heaviness doesn't detract. Should be a classic as time will tell. Own Erweiterrungsbogen expansion tiles.

RATING: 10
A top tier game. Only my 5th game out of 568 that I have rated a 10.

It is purely a euro and it's on the heavier side. Steep learning curve. Having 14 different ways to play ensures replayability. I can't think of another euro, that after 20+ games, I feel there is still more to explore.

Much more than the usual put a worker here-and-there to collect cubes to convert to veeps.

The play time is excellent at 25 minutes per player.

Update. Raised from 8.5 to 9.0. After 12 plays it is holding up. I'm still interested in exploring new races and looking forward to re-exploring past played races. 

Update. Bumped to a 10. After 16 games, I am still wanting to play more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First impressions: a lot harder to teach than play.  Many mechanisms taken from many different games, multiple resources, two of which track differently, variable player powers, with more unlockable during the game -- it's a lot to explain.  But in play, it seems to flow pretty easily, and the players catch on quickly.  Definitely warrants more play.  Can be a bit AP-prone, though, and while it's an impressive achievement, I think I prefer the relatively straightforward play of, say, Tzolk'in.  

P.S.: The rules are horribly laid out, with things like where to get power and how the cult tracks work explained in bizarre places.  This is a big-ticket item; someone should have spent more time editing the rulebook.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favourite game right now!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Wonderful, eminently replayable game, fully deserving of its top ten status on BGG. The mechanics are complex yet intuitive, combining multiple levels of area majority with worker placement mechanics (i.e power actions) and special powers. 

The various races, of course, make the game. Each race doesn't merely give a special power: they totally change the way you have to play, focusing your strategy in dratically different ways depending on which race you are. Amazingly, with all of this, the game seems to be remarkably balanced (ok, with a couple of exceptions for people who have played hundreds of times). It's hard to imagine the amount of playtesting this game must have gone though before going to print. An exceptional design.

UPDATE: Ok, so the game is not balanced. But it's still amazing. To prevent imbalances, either auction off races at the beginning of the game (using VPs) or pair equally-weighted factions with each other before play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 10
Citando Alkyla nel finale del suo videotutorial:"MAMMA MIA CHE GIOCONE!".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There is fun to be had Terra Mystica, certainly. But to me, it's a classic overdesigned, mechanics-centric euro - not a good thing. For all the ridiculous and unwarranted flak he takes, Knizia's games are both mechanically elegant and are (usually) thematically coherent and have both intellectual and emotional hooks. Terra Mystica is a pretty dry, incoherent mess of interlocking mechanics that gives you little to get invested in. It also lacks anything in ongoing player interaction; there are usually just a couple points of entirely predictable high-stakes conflicts early but it in the main is much more of a multiplayer solitaire tableau-builder than the positioning/placement game it superficially resembles. I think solitaire-y tabeleau-builders can work (Terraforming Mars is decent) but it's a really hard problem; without the energy of at least a little  competition (whether it's the inter-player competition of Power Grid, cooperative competition with a game system like Lord of the Rings or Pandemic, or a mix of the two like Greenland),  games have to work really hard to maintain engagement. Terra Mystica doesn't manage it.

The lack of any kind of ingame randomization is also a huge problem. With everything about the game state known before turn 1, it really does inflict a brutal level of look-ahead type analysis - to the point of requiring you to plot out your first 3 turns, half the game, before you even claim a faction if you want to be competitive.

On the flip side, I did find all the different factions entertaining to explore, in a solitaire-y kind of way (which faction you pick is a big deal for you personally, but they don't seem to produce interesting interactions which is kind of surprising). This is definitely not nothing, and it was enough for me to enjoy the game for about half-a-dozen plays. But for me, once I got through the exploratory phase, there wasn't enough left to keep me going.

There are a number of games that for me are sort of in this design space and which I find much superior: 504, Taj Mahal, Ginkopolks, Through the Desert, El Capitain (all 10-rated games for me). They're all fairly different from Terra Mystica mechanically, but they capture some key element or elements in a far more elegant, higher-octane package. 504 has the truly almost infinite diversity and sense of designing a strategy before turn 0 based on a unique landscape; Taj Mahal has the combination of long-term planning based on a known series of events and a placement game; Ginkopolis and Through the Desert have the interesting space competition that involves tight maneuvering against your neighbors, with Ginkopolis throwing in tableau-building; and El Capitain really captures an interesting sense of coopitition as two players competing to exploit a market make it worth more for both in the short term, until the market gets played out. Terra Mystica doesn't really manage to do any of these things all that well, so I'd much rather play a game that does one or a couple things extremely well than a game that tries to do too much and doesn't really manage it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terra Mystica is one of the latest and greatest in the "point salad" variety of games, where players score points for all sorts of things, hoping to have the best total by the end of the game.

The coolest thing about Terra Mystica is that every player is playing a different races of beings, which changes the way that player approaches the game.  Some players will be far more interested in certain aspects of the game than others due to their special abilities which encourage players to take different paths.

However, your plans will definitely intersect plans of other players, allowing you to frustrate other players' plans and vice versa.

Overall, just a really neat game if you don't mind a mild amount of complexity and like these sorts of "points everywhere" games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the best games I've ever played. This game, while there are minor balance issues with some of the races, is the most fun game I have ever played by far. The theme is amazing, the game has diverse strategy and extremely high replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[floatleft][ImageID=1450866][/floatleft][size=11][b][thing=120677]Terra Mystica[/thing][/size][/b] surprised me with its accessibility and speed of play.  A middle-weight game bordering on elegant is the last thing I would have expected from a collaberation between designers of [thing=13884][/thing] and [thing=20101][/thing].  Yet [thing=120677][/thing] most evokes memories of austere predecessors, such as [thing=43015][/thing] and [thing=107529][/thing].  That is not to say that [thing=120677][/thing] is uncomplicated -- it layers numerous ideas (indeed, one might argue a few too many) that require some time to wade through.  But the game progresses in a wave of quick turns featuring discrete and clearly defined options in pursuit of a handful of simple and well-understood goals.  

[floatright][ImageID=1458783][/floatright]In all honesty, [thing=120677][/thing] is mechanically most reminiscent of 2011's [thing=72125][/thing], though I hesitate to introduce the comparison because I feel that it may mislead more than it illuminates.  The game begins by adopting defined races with unique special abilities, it progresses through players' management of multiple currencies tied to a [thing=25613][/thing] style tech tree for further specialization, all in the pursuit of developing and then competing on a shared central board. 

Unlike [thing=72125][/thing], however, that seemed to build toward the culmination of just one or two strategies, [thing=120677][/thing] provides myriad opportunities to score points through a diffuse network of interrelated actions.  [floatleft][imageid=1450487][/floatleft]This seems to result simultaneously the blank canvas of a Jack-friendly sandbox game and the general dread that everything is necessary and nothing is quite sufficient.  Players can and will develop different skills, pursue different scoring opportunities, and yet continue to compete for (and complain about) the same fundamental building blocks.  It works in a way that I would not have expected upon just reading the rules.

I will be very curious to see how the game holds up over repeated plays.  Most importantly to me, I am interested in seeing whether increased player skill results in a more efficient pursuit of strategic paths, and, if so, what tax those efficiencies might levy on player interaction (which was quite high in our first game). 

If sufficient quantities of the game are available, I am confident that [thing=120677][/thing] will end up being one of the defining titles of this year's Spiel fair.

RATING: 9
Many strategy games suffer from one of the three evils: its all math and too little theme and immersion; or too many convoluted rules and feature that don't add any gameplay value; or they just have so much stuff in them - they take 6+ hours to play (yeah I am looking at you Twilight Imperium). Finding a well balanced strategy/development/area control game with good theme and reasonable gameplay is a challenge for me, and Terra Mystica is one of such rare games. There is some issues that some of the races a bit too weak, while some a bit too good, but over its a good strategy game that can be played in a reasonable time frame.

RATING: 4
When strategies meet. I suspect that the first level of this game is to simply figure out the best strategy for playing any particular race, while the second level would be how to implement your strategy in the way that best interferes with the other players depending on their races.

The question is, is that first level interesting enough for me that I'll end up encountering the second level?

And the likely answer is, no. The game is really way more complicated than I want it to be for the potential fun it delivers. Said another way, there are games I enjoy way more that are easier to play (but offer the same level of challenge during play in the same amount of time at the same player counts).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This really is an excellent deep game. It's only a 7 because the amount of options veers into "overwhelming" territory for me (SO much to track, and small mistakes can have BIG consequences). I'm sure if I played it regularly so I didn't have that emotional response anymore, my rating would be higher. Really, if you're looking for a deep Euro, this absolutely worth your time.

The resource game is excellent - this is resource scarcity at its finest. The way you can control your output is fascinating, and is the main driver for the game's tension. It ties neatly into the classic Euro so many options, not enough time to do them all angst.

Getting new powers as you progress gives you lots of little mini-goals to look forward to and plan toward, and keeps things engaging even over a 2 hour game.

The racial abilities are fun but... don't seem balanced. In our first play, one player's ability seemed straight up OP while another was clearly weaker than anyone else's at the table, and it felt like it had a really big impact on the winner. A shame as the racial powers are one of the cooler aspects of the thing.

There's also a big potential for downtime here, just because there's SO MUCH to consider on each turn, and warning: optimizing your next turn can require a lot of math.

The magic system is just straight up cool. Especially being able to permanently burn some mana to get some NOW.

I really would love to see a stripped down version of this, with less information to track (maybe omitting the cult track, etc) as the base resource game is SO enjoyable on its own that I think it'd make a solid 1 hour game.

If you like heavy Euros and are willing to work around some possibly unbalanced player powers, definitely give this one a go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Kerry owns.

RATING: 7
An interesting design for people who like competitive puzzle solving.  The variation provided by different game setups and different tools available to each player (the factions) allows repeatable game play.

It is important to note that this game is an economic-optimizer-snowball game.  This means that the strategy you set for yourself before the game starts (how do you expect to solve the puzzle?) and the first two rounds are crucial.  Come from behind victories are rare.

RATING: 5

Plus, despite sharing a board, there aren't that many opportunities to screw with other people's plans (there are some) that it plays much more like an individual board puzzle optimization solitaire game than it seems at first blush.

RATING: 9
Terra Mystica is one of the best modern boardgame in these days. It is my personal favorite game alongside with Troyes, the only reason that Terra mystica doesn’t be in my top three becuase its doesn’t scale well with 2-3 players. Which is the numbers of my regular gaming group nowadays.
