=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
Terra Mystica is my second favorite game right after Agricola - and that's after having played a 1000 different games! There's just so much I really, really love about this game!

The 14 different factions (20 incl. expansion), the power bowls system, the complete lack of randomness, the various bonus and round tiles, the map design, the founding of cities, the whole economic aspect, the game flow and overall just the deep gameplay that can be found in this truly awesome game!

There is absolutely no randomness in the game once the initial setup has been done, so it all comes down to the players' strategies. From here on out, it's all up to the players and which actions they take, and even though as I said there is no randomness, the choices each player takes can have a huge impact on your own strategy and what you're able to do; it's in no way a game with a solitaire feel, at least not when you play with 4 or 5. With 3 it's a little less tight, and with 2 it's probably too lose and you can do more or less whatever you want.

As said, the setup is random and makes sure that every game play out slightly differently, mainly because you get points for doing different stuff in different rounds, so in some games it might be a good idea to build a Stronghold in turn 1, in others it might not be wise until later on. It all depends. And this also influences your choice of faction, as some of them play radically different! This also means that, while the game isn't won before the game starts, it might actually be lost if a player takes a sucky race compared to the round bonuses... Speaking of sucky races, there's no denying that the races aren't equally balanced, and the Fakirs are extremely poor; lower starting power, more expensive SH etc. makes them almost unplayable, but in certain situations they might shine (err, not be as bad as usual). But, having played TM over 50 times, that's not necessarily a bad thing, because I can then pick a somewhat bad race (Fakirs, Auren, Giants come to mind) if I play against new players so the game is more balanced.

One minor nitpick I have is that I don't like the starting player system of the starting player being determined by the player passing first and then going clockwise around; if one player is having a bad game and don't have much income etc., he will usually pass first, and this gives the second player a (too big) advantage I think, as especially power actions are of critical importance later on in the game (who said 7 gold)).
Also, another negative is probably that Earth1 (and Air1?) is a bit too strong if you can get it early on, but I've both lost with it and won over other players who had it, and it's certainly not "mandatory" (otherwise nobody would win as the 4(+5)th player in 4(5) player games). I actually prefer myself to get other favor tiles that boost my income, but each to his own - and again, it depends on which faction you have chosen and how you play it!

I will elaborate further later on, because TM is just an incredible game that every hardcore eurogamer should play! I'm almost addicted to it, and it keeps getting better and better each time I play and learn new things!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
So, I got a chance to play "the new hotness." And, my opinion of a first play is "eh--not bad." 

Terra Mystica was dryer than I expected. I had heard comparisons to Dominant Species (which in retrospect don't make much sense to me) so I was expecting at least a bit of theme with the game. It's not really there. The different race powers are instead paths to pursue optimization. 

There are things to like. All the mechanics are smooth, the different races provide replayability, you get to play in your own little playground before the end game pushes people into each other for final point mooching. Something is missing though that keeps this from being a game that I get excited about. 

I need to play it once more. One play makes this game hard to judge, as I had no idea what I was shooting to accomplish at the start of the game. Now that I know, I wonder if a more informed play changes my thoughts.

RATING: 8
[b]Thoughts? - [/b]An excellent euro implementation of area control which has a lot of paths to victory.  The management of your workers, priests and power does have an element of book keeping as the resources required are massively varied to achieve an efficient turn.  One of the longer games to regularly find the table.

[b]Still Play Regularly? - [/b]Regular main game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent area control game.  Take on the role of the leader of a race and terraform the world so that your people can spread and build.

There are a dizzying array of options for players to choose from.  Each race has its own abilities and costs.  The general ability in the 3-bowl magic systems allows players to convert their power to workers or jostle for once-per-turn abilities on the board.

The semi-random scoring for actions performed in a given round -- chosen when the game starts -- pushes players to pursue different lines of strategy each time they play.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough.  It is outstanding.  The only caveat is that it's a heavy Eurogame, with all that entails.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Easily one of the best and most original games of 2010 onwards. An 8 or 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I've played this a number of times. It starts out interesting. The more I play it the less I want to play it more.

Near the end of the game there are often a bunch of different ways to get the same number of points. Interactions with other players thus enable some strategy, and it's clearly very well balanced. I much prefer when that's the way the game is at the beginning but a series of moves end up adding up to a lot more differences in points for later moves. That doesn't seem to happen.

It would also be nice if the board layout wasn't the same every time. This becomes more balanced than say Settlers (though it's in a different class of games anyway), but much less interesting from one game to the next.

RATING: 7.5
I've been looking at this game for the past 5 years as it has become one of the most beloved heavier Euro games. I'm glad to have finally had a chance to play it. The rules explanation was long (30+ minutes), and I was not completely grasping how all of the many mechanics fit together. However, after the first turn, it (mostly) all clicked and was a blast. I loved the many choices you had each round in balancing which building you had out (and therefore what resources you got each round) and your power pools while racing the other players for space on the board, bonus tiles, and elemental tracks. I would love to play again with the training wheels off to allow everyone their own choice on one of the 14 species.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Very cool.  Eclipse + HT + special sauce.  Lots of delicious blocking and cool interaction.  The game itself is wonderful and, as a bonus, there are fourteen very different races.  The two players is fun, but a little limited.  I imagine the game really opens up with four or five skilled players.  

I'll need at least five or six more plays  at all the player counts to settle on a rating but here's a hopeful 8.  There may be a 9 here, but, if the strategic interaction doesn't amount to anything, it could slide down.  Eclipse has fared well over the year, I hope this one will too.

Update:
TM differentiates itself from most currency converters by allowing more mixed strategies in the early and mid-game and then, as the game winds up, constraining the possible end-game options (expanding cults or area). In short, not everything converts and the big "cash cows" for victory points require positional strength rather than finely-tuned engines. I should add that the game did not seem like this after the first few plays. Then, in the most recent game we played races that were close to each other on the terraforming track. This made the game much more mean, and more interesting. 

I haven't mentioned races much and actually, I think they are mostly a curious inconvenience. They seem well balanced which is remarkable given their variety but parsing each race is an impediment to good play. The game would be just as interesting (maybe more so) if everyone played the same race.

Update: 10+ plays in the game is still good, but is beginning to feel a little solitary.  

Update: A few more plays are confirming some of my fears.  It is much harder to block and interact with skilled players.  The most interesting relationships in this game are with non-players (the various conversions).  There is little sense of a "game" and very few ways to manage incentives.  In short, it's a conversion puzzle performed in proximity--but at least it's a mildly enjoyable puzzle.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The thinnest of themes, but a mighty meaty game.

Seems to be a marmite among people I play with, maybe I need the App?

RATING: 10
Great Euro style area control game with lots of re-playability. Excellent instruction booklet which has very helpful first play scenarios for 3, 4 or 5 players.

Plan on a solid 20 or so minutes to teach before you play but this game is picked up by people quickly.

Game does a nice job of balancing long term strategy with shorter term tactical moves. The balance between in-game scoring & end-game scoring is also good - not too swingy but not insignificant either.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
First, ignore the theme on this game.  If you are turned off by elves, giants, and magic, don't let that stop you from playing this masterpiece.  On the other hand, if you are looking for a epic tale of high fantasy, keep looking.
BGG might as well put a picture of this next to the definition of "Pasted on theme".

Once you get past that, you get a great game with many interesting decisions.  It borrows from Peurto Rico with selecting a role each turn.  It borrows from Eclipse by having remove cubes from your personal tableau to reveal higher production.  And then it has some twists unique to itself.  Every time I play, I marvel at how well everything fits together.

After a month of owning it, it is already the most played game in our collection!

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I think this might be the game that fully demonstrates that I'm not really a Euro gamer per se anymore at all, or at least that I'm well past my point of being excited by them. So take this with a grain of salt.

But basically this is a connection game somewhat ala Through the Desert or Kingdom Builder with a huge heaping pile of extra Euro mechanics (primarily a dual economy of cash and mystical power) added to it that allow players to score points on an additional series of tracks instead of just on the board.

On a given turn players generally gather some wood, transform a hex into a land type that their character finds attractive, or burn some mystical power to make connections easier, towns affordable, or the like. Players seem to score most of their points by having long contiguous groups, by dominating the special tracks, and by placing whatever the special round tile is incentivizing (i.e.: VPs for building this type of wood building, &c., a different one is up each round).

The upside of this design is definitely the variability that the different tribal groups provide, as each board has its set of special characteristics (and presumably, dominant strategies to pursue; this in itself is not appealing to me because it also likely means that players are having a path laid for them that they would be foolish to ignore).

For whatever reason, I initially found this game difficult to learn, though it was fairly easy to play in practice. The plus side is the aforementioned variability, the downside is that this is longer, perhaps too long for this type of game for my particular tastes. Pure Euro fans seems to love it though, and I can at least understand that (compare to games like Hansa Teutonica where said love utterly mystifies me) and would play this again with an experienced group but I'm not sure the extra stuff really makes it any better than Kingdom Builders (a much shorter game) for me.

RATING: 8
Keep

A mid to heavy weight game (economic and area control with  significant depth of strategy in planning your expansion to score maximum points along the way). 

The game played really well. The gameplay itself is nothing particularly unique and I can't help thinking they could have come up with a better theme (or at least integrated it better into the game), however what I think will make this game different from other heavier euros is its replayability. While the game board is static, there are 14 different factions which can be played (all with different special powers/abilities). Combined with the variable bonus tiles and round scoring tiles this will create a genuinely unique game each time you play. Looking forward to playing again.

RATING: 8
KÖZÖS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players create cities on the game board while advancing on the cult tracks.  Players choose a race.  Races have variable powers and prefer different territories.  Advantages can be gained by building certain buildings to gain favor tiles or per-round privileges.  Having buildings in play provides various sorts of income each round.  Advancing on the cult tracks can help cycle power, provide round-end bonuses, and end game points.  End game points are also awarded for city size.

It may sound dry, but it's quite interesting.  The variable powers of each race help the game feel fresh each time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update: 10!

Ok, this game is amazing. Reminds me of the amazement when I first played Settlers 15+ years ago. Having played so many games since then, it's hard to have a game hit me with that much excitement. This has the hex map with different terrain types, the different buildings with upgradability, multiple resource types, land grab to build on spots before other players, and then about 37 other different things. But they all work. I wouldn't remove any of them. And then you not only get points for what you build, but there is an end game scoring based on connectedness, worth tons of points. Having only played a few times so far, I still stink at the game, but it absolutely captivates me.

I generally am not a fan of zero-randomness games. The exception is when the game provides significant variety of setup options (e.g. Luna). This game delivers that in spades. I love that there are more factions to play than max players. Right there that's 35 different faction combinations for 4 players, not even counting rotating who is playing which factions. 
---
Preliminary rating after one play. Lots to explore here. Seems like it will take many games to really get a strong grasp of all the nuances, especially with all the different races with the unique attributes. So many possibilities, I can't really figure out how I feel, other than I look forward to playing more. Will definitely pick up, unless someone else in my group does first.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Oh man. I love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
+ Exp : Terra Mystica: Fire & Ice (2014)
+ promo:  Bonus Card Shipping Value (2013)
+ promo: 4 Town Tiles (2013)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was never too impressed with Terra Mystica, and frankly I doubt a little that the game would have fared so well as it did if Uwe Rosenberg hadn't been there to lend his author status to the two designers Jens and Helge. The game would still have done very well to excellent on its own, I think... but at the same time there are hordes of designers who'd give their reproductive organs for such an endorsement. 

The game is unusual in that it is combinatorial after the setup, which is an impressive achievement in its own right. Of course it presses all the right buttons with asymmetric faction powers (and thus also questions as to their inherent balance, which several years after the game was released are agreed upon to be [i]un[/i]balanced, even if there is always some speculation by how much) and a fantasy setting. Of course once you're playing the kitschy back story disappears into the background; and all you end up doing is working out how to transform the various opportunities into VPs, power, money, and other resources like buildings. Thinking of buildings as resources is unusual, but once placed they don't really do much, and given that they leave and enter your supply in a controlled fashion leaves little to treat them as anything other than a resource. In this Terra Mystica proves itself to be something of a button pusher, but fortunately a relatively easily accessible one as the actions are fairly logically grouped together. 

After my first few games I'm not so sure that there is much player creativity and interaction to be found in the whole. The faction powers determine in some way or form how you are going to play the game; deviate from them at your own peril. Then the round bonuses are too attractive to ignore either, so you'd be a fool not to try to match up your actions to them. If you're not doing it, other people most certainly are! At some point you even begin to harbour a bit of a point-salady feel because there's always some easily obtainable carrot dangling in front of you. So certainly the interaction will have bite, right? Well... I'm not so sure. Interaction is primarily handled through Power, a rather fleeting resource which, although useful, isn't particularly ubiquitous either. Adding insult to injury, it costs VP to obtain it. It really takes a while to get anywhere with the stuff, and because most people tend to build in each other's vicinity the net result isn't far from 0 either (although the eventual purpose may differ). Blocking area expansion through the erection of buildings, or construction of a bridge before someone else can, is as in-your-face as it's going to get. For all intents and purposes this game is very friendly indeed; and it probably also explains why at 5 it still functions admirably: there is simply little interaction to deal with. This is a far cry from, say, a Splotter game.

So what are we left with? A simple, but very contrived majorities game on the side board, and a very elaborate dance of conceptually simple resource conversion with some area control on the main board, all packaged up in an ensemble of euro-friendliness. It's not unlike many titles What's Your Game? has put out, but then without the clunky feel that publisher seems to have a nose for. Still, I daresay that game-wise you'd be better off picking games which either do the majorities right, or the resource conversion, or the area control. Sometimes these aspects are even found in one single package. Terra Mystica doesn't offer much in terms of compensation for its much longer playing time and more elaborate ruleset, and that is costing the game my appreciation of it.

I've pondered a while about my rate for the thing. My initial rate was a 5, but given that it plays 5 people just as easily as it does 3 (even if it cheats in how it achieves this complex design feat), I've gone and upped the rate to 6. But that's where the rate will stay. Apart from the faction balance, the game works as intended... it's just not that spectacular if you look through the pink haze.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this game players have two areas to fight over. One is the land and the other is the control of the four elements. Players build structures to gain more control over both. After six rounds players score points based upon largest built settlements and elemental control. Some in game scoring occurs and should not be discounted as it is some sixty percent of the score. I would rate higher, but it does not have a trading phase.

RATING: 10


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I particularly love how the game provides incentives for proximity to other players on the board, thus eliminating the feature most other multiplayer games with an area control mechanic have: If two players fight over control of an area, this is usually to the advantage of the other players. I don't like the problems associated with this at all and therefore regard Terra Mystica's take on it as a huge accomplishment.

I love the game's [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamemechanic/2015/variable-player-powers]Variable Player Powers mechanic[/url] as well.

A downside (which prevented me from rating it even higher) is that the game seems to be especially unforgiving of mistakes. Particularly early mistakes can more or less ruin your entire game, which can be a problem for a game which lasts as long as Terra Mystica. The "need" to plan ahead very carefully resulting from that can feel a little tiresome. I hope it'll decrease with more experience, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Shame

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Enjoyed it for a while (old rating 8). It first came across from rules as a "you can do your own thing" game, but thankfully it's more interactive than that - partly for the blocking (both in building locations and in taking the special mana actions) and in anticipating where other people are going to build for purposes of gaining mana. Yet there's enough internal-engine development to satisfy that portion of my brain. (Edit: after playing more I find it overall slightly too punishing in that regard; tiny slip-ups early can cascade down the turns, making for lots of AP in early-game as players try to not do that.)

The varied "gain VP for this arbitrary thing" bonuses do very nice things for variability of play (changing incentives game-to-game), but also feel really arbitrary. I would have appreciated a thematic wrapper of some sort, even a really thin one. (Actually, that's true for a lot of things in this game.)

RATING: 7
Got this as a birthday gift. Yay! A heavier weight classic from my wife who is looking forward to playing it. Let us see how this goes... She did a lot of research!

This is a rare game that makes me want to use a rating in between two numbers. For now it's going to stay a 6, but I think over time this rating may go up as the subtleties of gameplay come out with more plays.

But for me, I guess I am a themeaholic. This game's theme is rather tacked on to a deeper Euro style. That's great, and obviously people love this game a lot for it's gameplay. As I said, I'm a themeaholic...

Clearly well thought out mechanics and balance- and a good blend of direct/indirect competition.

Long setup and cleanup time, though. But once you go, you go and just play- little downtime (at least in my group) so that is good.

RATING: 8.4
Entire game breathes the fantasy theme. Many ways of scoring points while developing your "nation" by means of 14 different races each with their own properties. One flaw in the game: there is only 1 way to build a bridge, and this action can only be chosen by 1 player in each of the 6 game rounds. This limits the amount of bridges built throughout the game to a maximum of 6. This is strange, as all other actions can be performed in different ways (power actions, bonus tiles, bonus scrolls, building a city, bonus castle action).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The theme is anchored well into the structure of the game, with each faction operating very distinctly.  I believe this is what's earned it so much praise.  It's well made and has excellently tuned mechanics and balance, and yet for me it feels like yet another samey area control game with an especially dull fantasy theme.  And that's somehow just not my cup of tea right now.  I don't want to look at my game shelf and see a dozen nearly identical fantasy area control games.  I want something interesting and different that screams to be played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial placeholder ranking of an 8, but if I can get this one to the table more and get to the point where I can compete well enough, this might eventually end up a 10.

Update: I think TM needs to stay at an 8, for now. I envy those who think of it as a 10; I truly wish I was one of them. TM really needs lots of play to reveal just how great it is -- the seemingly infinite combinations of the various asymmetrical factions matching up against each other is something I can only imagine instead of having experienced first hand. And there in lies the problem: I've too many games that get in the way of the time and attention Terra Mystica deserves, so I suspect the best parts of TM will forever remain hidden to me. 

For me personally, TM is not an intuitive experience. Watching others puzzle through their faction's strengths and succeed only makes worse the frustration I feel not being able to lift the fog of indecision that envelops me each turn of the game. For some, TM simply clicks, but I'll never be one of those people. To better understand, I've started playing some games against the AI at http://lodev.org/tmai so as to learn from each turn's suggested hints, but I can already tell the methods shown will probably never occur to me naturally. Still, I love playing the game despite my lack of success.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Don´t get me wrong - Terra Mystica is a very good game, a medium/heavy euro with lots of planning, decisions and options to be made and multiple ways of gaining points. The power bowls is also a complete and ingenious new mechanic.
However, the almost endless options with multiple development tracks, plus the different skills of 14 factions, can be somehow overwhelming. The scatter can be so huge that there can be several tracks a player never has time to start, or there can even be a game where there is a track where nobody has put one single effort!...The feeling is that one could have played 50 games and still have little notion of what is the best to do. 
The theme (if there is one) is very fuzzy and the board artwork could be better, though the components are of good quality.
So, if someone asks me if i like the game, i would say "yes", but if they ask me if i wanna play it, i would say "meh...i would rather play something else!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Quite a heavy game. I'm intrigued.

RATING: 7
One of those "everything but the kitchen sink" games. This is a heavy, long Euro, and is sort of difficult to categorize, mechanics-wise, as it has so many. There's nothing particular exciting or novel here, but there doesn't have to be either. It does what it does well, and that is provide an enjoyable gaming experience. The theme is non-existent, but if you can get past that, then the game can be fun, although it can feel a little long for my taste if players suffer from AP (likely).

RATING: 8
All the hype seems justified up to a point. A heavy game of figuring out your best actions in order to make best use of your race's ability to terraform is the crux of the game and you have to wade through understanding all the different actions and ways to make points in order to do so effectively. The choice on where to expand and when and how it gives an effectively free resource to players is not as interesting as a choice as I first thought it would be.

Terraforming in the game can feel ponderous in the beginning. A game for highly competitive people without the direct combat that I really love in competitive games. Still a good challenge of a game and decently fun.

RATING: 6.5
[29 Jul 2017] - 6.5 (1 play)
I was not impressed with this game. We played with 5 and the rules were explained fairly well. The problem is so much the rules or how things work but the total lack of realism with the game. There is no way that a race of beings that are all vying for control of a small section of land are just going to co-exist peacefully. It doesn't happen in nature and makes for a bland game. In the game I got blocked in and what was my recourse? Nothing. I am much more interested in something like Scythe where combat happens but is rare or some mechanism for rewarding the dominate player in a tight area of the map.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Terra Mystica is, hands down, the best board game I've ever played.  Every time I finish playing,(which is quite often) I have a strong urge to start another game.  I can't say that this is true for many other games.  The first game will take a LONG time, due to all the little rules you need to memorize, but after your 2nd or 3rd play you will have a strong understanding of everything.  That's when the fun really starts.  14 factions, and they all play differently.  I really enjoy playing a new character at random every game to keep it feeling fresh.  Each has its own exploits to discover and use to your advantage.  The power bowls system adds a new dynamic to the standard resource management, allowing you to throw away power for good, just to cash some in immediately.  This is a game for those who know how to take advantage of opportunity, as everything is face up, and there is little to no luck involved.  Came across this game after playing a lot of Cities and Knights for Catan.  Haven't played that one since.  The big heavy box of components is worth every penny.  Buy it.

RATING: 8
A good game, but a completely over-rated one. Not particularly point-salad, but definitely mechanic-salad. A very dry, flavorless salad at that. I really like Euro games, and I don't mind dry as long as there are interesting mechanics and strategies to explore, but this one doesn't have any innovative mechanics of its own that I fell in love with, nor does it seamlessly put together the other mechanics that it's borrowed from other games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-5

Set-up 

1. Elke speler kiest een ras en neemt het bijhorende spelersbord en alle tokens in die kleur (priesters, gebouwen, markers en bruggen). Leg de priesters en bruggen opzij. 
2. Plaats de gebouwen op de overeenkomstige plaatsen op je eigen spelersbord. De meest linkse plaats op het huisjesspoor moet vrij blijven.  
3. Plaats een marker op de “0” van het schip-spoor, op de “3” van het spade-spoor en op de “20” op het overwinningspuntenspoor. 
4. Plaats de overige markers op de plaatsen “0” van elk cultuurspoor.  
5. Verdeel 12 krachttokens over bal 1 en bal 2 zoals aangeduid op het spelersbord. 
6. Neem het aantal werkers en munten zoals aangegeven op je spelersbord. 
7. Plaats de actietokens naast de 6 krachtactievelden op het algemeen speelbord. 
8. Neem 6 willekeurige scoretegels en plaats ze aan de linkerkant van het algemeen speelbord. Bedek de meest rechtse bonus van de hoogste tegel met het einde-van-het-spel-token. 
9. Leg alle gunsttegels (ovale tegels) in verschillende stapels volgens hun symbolen. 
10. Plaats willekeurig x-aantal bonustegels (lange verticale tegels). X = aantal spelers + 3. Doe de overige bonustegels in de doos. 
11. Te starten met de startspeler plaatst elke speler een huisje op het speelbord. De startspeler begint en dan gaat het verder in wijzerzin. Nadat iedereen een huisje heeft geplaatst, wordt er in tegenwijzerzin (te starten met de laatste speler) een tweede huisje geplaatst. 
12. Te starten met de laatste speler en tegenwijzerzin neemt elke speler een bonustegel. Leg een munt op de 3 niet-gekozen bonustegels. 

Overzicht van een beurt 

FASE 1: INKOMEN 
Elke speler neemt de grondstoffen waarbij een inkomen symbool staat  (een open hand). Als gebouwen worden verwijderd, komen er steeds meer symbolen zichtbaar. Neem zoveel grondstoffen als weergegeven op de track op je eigen spelersbord: werkers (witte blokjes) van huisjes, munten van handelshuizen, priesters van tempels of heiligdommen, kracht van hansdelshuizen en burchten. Daarnaast krijg je ook het inkomen van alle bonustegels (verticale tegels) en gunsttegels (ovale tegels) in je bezit. 

FASE 2: ACTIES 
Te beginnen met de startspeler en dan in wijzerzin doet elke speler een actie of past hij. Een speler die eenmaal heeft gepast, mag die ronde geen acties meer doen. Zo gaat het verder tot alle spelers hebben gepast. 
 
FASE 3: CULTUURBONUS EN OPRUIMFASE 
1. De spelers krijgen de cultuurbonussen die aan de rechterkant van de scoretegels liggen (zie linkerkant van het speelbord). Elke verworven spade mag over verschillende plaatsen verdeeld worden, maar kan niet gespaard worden voor volgende ronden. 
2. Verwijder de actie tokens van de gebruikte plaatsen op het algemeen speelbord, het eigen speelbord, de gunsttegels en de bonustegels. 
3. Plaats een munt op elke overgebleven bonustegel (verticale tegels). 
4. Draai de scoretegel van deze ronde om. 
Start daarna met fase 1 van een nieuwe ronde. 
Acties 

ACTIE 1: TRANSFORMEREN EN BOUWEN 
Transformeren: een terreintegel mag getransformeerd worden als de plaats vrij is en als de terreintegel direct of indirect aangrenzend is met één van je gebouwen. Elke stap om terrein te transformeren kost 1 spade. Je kan hiervoor gebruikmaken van je eigen spelersbord. Wanneer dit is gebeurd, plaats je een terreintegel van het nieuwe type op de huidige terreintegel. Als je terreintegel is getransformeerd naar je huisterreintegel, dan mag je onmiddellijk een huisje bouwen op die terreintegel, zonder dat dit een actie kost. Als krachtacties of bonussen je toelaten om twee plaatsen te transformeren, dan mag je enkel op de eerste tegel een gratis huisje plaatsen.  

Bouwen van een huisje: huisjes mogen enkel gebouwd worden op huisterreintegels en als de terreintegel direct of indirect aangrenzend is aan één van je gebouwen. De kost om te bouwen is weergegeven aan de linkerkant van het huisjesspoor. Neem het meest linkse huisje en plaats dit op de terreintegel. Huisjes mogen ook gebouwd worden zonder dat je eerst het terrein hebt getransformeerd. Per actie mag je slechts 1 huisje bouwen. Wanneer je direct aangrenzend bouwt aan een andere speler, heeft die andere speler de mogelijkheid om kracht te winnen.  

ACTIE 2: VOORUITGAAN OP HET SCHEEPSSPOOR 
Betaal de kost aan de linkerkant van het scheepsspoor om je marker één vakje te laten opschuiven. Je krijgt meteen het aantal overwinningspunten die aangegeven staan op het nieuwe vakje. Tegels die gescheiden zijn door een aantal riviertegels gelijk aan het nummer op het scheepsspoor, zijn indirect verbonden. 

ACTIE 3: VOORUITGAAN OP HET SPADESPOOR 
Betaal de kost onderaan het spadespoor om je marker één plaats op te schuiven. Je krijgt meteen het aantal overwinningspunten die aangegeven staan op het nieuwe vakje. Elke spade kost voor deze speler nu het aantal afgebeelde werkers. 

ACTIE 4: GEBOUWEN OPWAARDEREN 
Betaal de kost van het nieuwe gebouw (zie linkerkant van je eigen spelersbord). Plaats dit gebouw op het spelersbord en plaats het vroegere gebouw terug op je eigen spelersbord. Wanneer je direct aangrenzend aan een andere speler één van je gebouwen upgradet, heeft die andere speler de mogelijkheid om kracht te winnen.  
Handelshuis: upgrade van een huisje. Betaal de laagste kost als het huisje direct aangrenzend aan een andere speler wordt geplaatst. In het andere geval betaal je de hoogste kost. Burcht: upgrade van een handelshuis. De speler krijgt nu de speciale eigenschap die onder de burcht zit. Tempel: upgrade van een handelshuis. Neem meteen een gunsttegel (ovale tegel). Deze tegel moet verschillend zijn van de tegels die deze speler al bezit. Heiligdom: upgrade van een tempel. Neem meteen een gunsttegel (ovale tegel). Deze tegel moet verschillend zijn van de tegels die deze speler al bezit. 

ACTIE 5: PRIESTER NAAR EEN CULTUURSPOOR STUREN 
Plaats je priester op 1 van de open plaatsen onderaan het cultuurspoor. Beweeg daarna je marker het corresponderende aantal vakjes omhoog. De priester blijft daar staan gedurende de rest van het spel. OF: Gebruik de priester om slechts 1 vakje omhoog te gaan op het cultuurspoor. Daarna mag je de priester terug in je voorraad nemen. Opgelet: niet als een grondstof, je moet de priester opnieuw aanwerven! Als de marker langs kracht iconen gaat, dan krijg je het aangegeven aantal kracht. Slechts 1 marker kan de “10” bereiken op het cultuurspoor. De speler moet 1 stad hebben voor elke bezette “10”. 

ACTIE 6: KRACHTACTIES 
Geef kracht uit om krachtacties te gebruiken onderaan het algemeen speelbord. Plaats een actie token op de gekozen actie. Deze krachtactie kan deze ronde niet meer worden gekozen. 

ACTIE 7: SPECIALE ACTIES 
Gebruik de speciale acties aangeduid op je eigen spelersbord (onder een burcht), bonustegel (lange verticale tegel) of gunsttegel (ovale  tegel). Aangeduid met de oranje achthoekige achtergrond. Bedek deze actie met een actie token. Deze actie kan deze ronde niet meer worden gekozen. 

ACTIE 8: PASSEN 
Een speler die heeft gepast, komt deze ronde niet meer aan de beurt. Je krijgt eventuele inkomsten op je bonustegel omdat je hebt gepast. Dit herken  je aan de dichtgevouwen perkamentrol. Leg nu je bonustegel (verticale tegel) terug  in de voorraad en neem een nieuwe bonustegel (die je omgedraaid voor jou legt). De eerste speler die past is de nieuwe startspeler in de volgende ronde. 

Einde van het spel 

Het spel eindigt na 6 ronden. Na de 6e ronde scoor je geen bonussen meer (dit was afgedekt).  

PUNTENTELLING 
1. Voor elk cultuurspoor: 
a. de hoogste speler : 8 overwinningspunten 
b. de tweede hoogste speler: 4 overwinningspunten 
c. de derde hoogste speler: 2 overwinningspunten 
  
2. Score voor een gebied. Een gebied bestaat uit alle gebouwen van een speler die direct of indirect zijn verbonden. 
a. De speler met het grootste gebied: 18 overwinningspunten 
b. De speler met het tweede grootste gebied: 12 overwinningspunten 
c. De speler met het derde grootste gebied: 6 overwinningspunten 

3. Zet alle overgebleven grondstoffen om in munten. 1 overwinningspunt per 3 munten. 
Bij ex aequo deel je de punten door 2 (afgerond naar beneden). 

Belangrijke regels 

AANGRENZEND 
Direct aangrenzend: gebouwen grenzen fysiek aan een ander eigen gebouw 
Indirect aangrenzend: er zitten riviertegels tussen de gebouwen. Het aantal riviertegels is minstens even groot als de waarde van de speler op zijn scheepsspoor. 

KRACHT VERDIENEN EN UITGEVEN 
Elke keer als een speler kracht verdient, moet dit verdiend worden in deze volgorde: 
1. Verplaats de krachtfiches van bal 1 naar bal 2 (indien mogelijk). 
2. Als bal 1 leeg is, verplaats dan het overgebleven aantal krachtfiches van bal 2 naar bal 3. 
3. Als bal 2 ook leeg is, kan er geen extra kracht meer worden verdiend. 
Krachtfiches kunnen ook meteen van bal 2 naar bal 3 verplaatst worden (zelfs al is bal 1 leeg). In dat geval moet je één krachtfiche uit het spel verwijderen voor elke krachtfiche die je van bal 2 naar bal 3 verplaatst. Dit heeft prioriteit op de krachtactie.  
Kracht kan uitgegeven worden door krachtfiches van bal 3 naar bal 1 te verplaatsen. 

CONVERSIES 
Op elk moment tijdens het spel kan een speler kracht omzetten in grondstoffen. Daarnaast mag hij ook grondstoffen omzetten in andere grondstoffen.
 
BRUGGEN 
Bruggen moet gebouwd worden over rivieren. De brug moet minstens 1 terreintegel raken waarop een gebouw van deze speler  staat. Twee gebouwen die verbonden zijn door een brug, zijn nu direct aangrenzend. 
 
STEDEN 
Een speler heeft een stad als hij een gebied heeft van minstens 4 direct aangrenzende gebouwen en een gecombineerde krachtwaarde van minstens 7. Als een speler een stad heeft gebouwd, neemt hij de stadstegel. Dankzij de stadstegel krijgt hij EENMALIG de overwinningspunten (bovenaan de stadstegel) en EENMALIG het voordeel (onderaan de tegel).

RATING: 6
First impressions quite positive after my first play. Essentially a much more advanced [i]Settlers of Catan[/i] combined with action selection mechanics, advanced types of buildings, special racial abilities and variable victory points. The interaction of the different mechanics is interesting without that feeling of cleverness for the sake of cleverness that games like [i]Trajan[/i] leave me with.

This is definitely a brain burner, probably on par with [i]Dominant Species[/i] in terms of difficulty.

Update: Eh, after a few more plays, I got a distinct "been there, done that". Another euro that just didn't hold up to very many repeated plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[2013-05-06 Rating: n.a. -> 7.5]

When I played Terry Mystica (TM) for the first time, I expected a more civilization like game, which Terra Mystica really isn't. Instead, I would compare it to Kingdom Builder, albeit TM is clearly the heavier game. The whole point of the game is to make the most victory points possible by using your race's special abilities and timing your moves so that you get as much victory points from the round bonus tiles as possible. 

The theme doesn't really matter, it's all about finding the optimal chain of actions to maximize your victory point income. Since all bonus tiles are known from the start, you can enter the game with a clear strategy in mind and choose the race that you consider to be the most beneficial. It's not about choosing the race that you like the most, it's about identifying the race that will yield the most points under the given circumstances.

As a Eurogamer, I do like this kind of challenge and I want to explore Terra Mystica further. But I'm afraid that my Ameritrash loving gaming buddies might not want to join me on this journey after their first game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Expansion strategy game with fantasy theme. A very strategically comprehensive product.

RATING: 7
2 plays, both with 3 players. Lost some interest in this game after the 2nd play. Don't feel like playing this again for a while.

Some points listed below:
Components look nice. The game is visually fantastic, imo.
Theme feels nearly non-existent for me.
Setting this game up frustrates me.

I've been thinking about why I enjoy Power Grid more than this and I suspect it's because I 'feel' like there's sufficient 'interaction' (due to the auctioning of power plants) in Power Grid but not in Terra Mystica. There'd be more interaction with 4-5 players but I'm quite confident that the degree of 'interaction' would still be insufficient for me to enjoy Terra Mystica. For comparison, Puerto Rico has sufficient 'interaction' for me and I enjoy Puerto Rico but it feels like Dominion has even less 'interaction' than Terra Mystica yet I still enjoy Dominion. Maybe it's the combination of long game duration, low 'interaction', and the race mechanic (i.e. I'm usually not a fan of games in which one has to pick a race and/or class) that makes me not like this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really love this game because it is deep and thinky, interactive without being directly confrontational, and packs this all in a reasonable play time. This may be the Ultimate Euro Game.

That said, there are so many better euros. I don't really understand why this one strikes a chord with so many people, but it is a solid game despite the flaws.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have a collection of about 30 games, and Terra Mystica is easily my favorite game. It's the perfect game for people that love strategy board games that involve 0 luck and 100% strategy. This makes victories feel completely yours and losses feel that much worse. Often times one or two different moves in the early stages could have set you up differently in the later rounds and these mistakes often cost you the game. Some people may not like such a high risk factor with every move, but that's what makes every victory in Terra Mystica feel even better, knowing you outplayed everyone and earned your victory. Rules may seem dense at first, but Rahdo does a great job breaking them down. Completely worth the 2 hr investment to get the rules down. Expansion only adds more and balances things out with race auction.

RATING: 9

I really liked it, but would probably prefer it with four players instead of five to get the playtime down a bit. Rating likely to go up with more plays.

The only problem I have with the game is the downtime when it comes to the cult track the last turns. Will perhaps be less of a problem with more games.

Update: Played a couple of three player games and think that four players is probably the sweet spot despite being a great three and five player game as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Players attempt to expand the territory of their fantasy race, by constructing buildings and scoring victory points.  Meaty, busy game of resource accumulation and management.  Players earn income of workers, cash, priests and power, and use these resources while taking actions to expand their on board position.  The key concept is building and upgrading buildings, which can only exist on that race's key terrain.  Terrain can be terraformed into the race's key terrain just prior to construction, consuming precious resources.  Players can also spend power from their "battery" (a 3 cup system of moving power tokens around, allowing the battery to recharge), which are powerful, limited bonus actions.  The game is about accruing victory points, and there are many ways to achieve this, so it all needs to be carefully managed.  Quite a straightforward game to play, once you get the rules down, and with fourteen difference races to play (each with different abilities and quirks), means you have an endlessly re-playable game.  Quite stunning, luck free, tactical .... possibly the best game from Essen 2012.

A few months later and this game is in my top 10 - and that rarely changes.  Stunningly good - best game of the 2010's so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
First game: Nearly 3 hours.  Second game, same number of players: 1.5 hours!  Seems like some of the races are a bit imbalanced.  That being said this game is just lovely. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting economic engine game hidden under a bland fantasy theme. The idea of terraforming to be able to build on the map, the interplay between the different currencies (workers, priests, money and mana), the diversity of ways of obtaining victory points (building specific buildings during different phases, getting bonuses at the end of a turn depending on role chosen, largest area at the end of game and highest in four different tracks) make for a game with a good amount of depth and relatively fast playing time.
It's a shame that the box cover does nothing to convey this and that the theme is a bland fantasy theme.
Well worth trying out.

RATING: N/A
_
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Variable player powers work really well in ameritrash games that are more free-form, but it is very hard for euros, with their tighter mechanisms, to pull these off.  Terra Mystica is a euro that manages to accomplish use of special player powers and yet keeps the game well balanced.  

The underlying game is a solid, if only moderately inspired, euro design, kept fresh by the random setup of scoring and bonus tiles.  The 3 currency system is well done, particularly power, which runs in a very interesting feast/famine cycle. 

It is impressive that a euro of this weight can even accommodate special player powers without breaking.  I think the trade-off for this is that the underlying system is rather simplistic, as it likely has to be to accommodate the layering of special powers on top.  This type of setup works great for a game like Cosmic Encounter or Small World because the excitement comes from the interaction between all the special powers.  There is not nearly as much interaction in Terra Mystica, so there is much less to discover as far as interplay between the various powers.  That leaves you with using your power to optimize how well you turn the crank on the underlying point-generation systems.  Eurogames rely upon having interesting mechanisms, so I don't know how this game will fare in the long run given that its skeleton is fairly dull compared to the truly great, enduring euros.

In order to do well in TM, I think you need to leverage your race power to maximum potential, and it may be that over time this will lead to somewhat scripted play.  To be sure, each character will have its own script to learn, but it may be a script none the less.  I don't get the sense that the interaction between player powers is strong, so I don't think there is a lot to explore as far as certain power matchups.  Time will tell!

I think my favorite thing about the game is that there is so often a clever way to squeeze in one more action.  It is as though you are constantly finding a forgotten $20 in your back pocket.  

I hope to get better at this game, because it gives me brain freeze like little else I've played recently.  I hate to be that guy who takes 5 minutes to do his turn, but it is hard to resist the urge to think everything through carefully, as the profits of doing so can be very great.

UPDATE July 2013:
I am even more convinced that the essential element for successful play is to use your racial power to its maximum potential.  This isn't like Agricola where you can get along without your cards, using them to boost you where appropriate.  In the absence of your racial power, development is very slow, and you will be quickly left behind.  The issue with this is that you need to play each race in a very specific way.  There is some  fun to be had in discovering this best way, but I am finding the game is losing its shine as the included races are "played out."  

I think this game has a lot of "curb appeal", but as I dug into it I found that the underlying mechanisms aren't all that interesting despite all the brain burn they require to execute.  The racial powers are the secret sauce here, but rather than adding interesting interactions, they just dictate how you need to play.  I doubt that this game will remain in the Top 10 on the 'Geek for long as it gets wider distribution and people accumulate plays.  

Where I have ended up on TM is that it I think it has a lot of fancy feathers, but not much tasty meat underneath.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
To me, this game almost feels like a happy accident.  As if many different ideas and mechanics were stuck together and just happened to work out magnificently.  The game undoubtedly has a lot of time and love put into it, and it shows, but it also feels chaotic, as if you are being pulled in many directions at once.  Elements of Kingdom Builder + Catan + Tzolk'in style religion track + racial benefits to improve replay value and variety?  Overall, a very fun game.  A little better with 3+ players, but 2 is still great fun.

I like:
- Encourages player interaction through rewards for proximity building and blocking of moves / rewards / board space.
- Very strategic.  Lots of paths to victory.  Main randomness element is from other players: no dice rolling or card draws.
- Racial differences give direction to a wide field of actions, enhance replayability.

Not so much:
- Poor initial choices or recognition of a race's strengths could lead to misery later on.
- Feels like your race grows exponentially; actions feel overly expensive until the last few rounds, then a sudden surge in options.  Probably related to first dislike.

RATING: 9
I originally gave this game a 10, but after some long thought: [-]the player interaction is limited to the Cultist track and the map-blocking[/-]; and I firmly believe that *every* game should have one (very) tiny random element in it (so that a losing player has some hope), and this game does not. This game was *the* hit of Geekway to the West 2013.

UPDATE: Well, I was wrong. There is also player interaction in the race selection, and the player turn order (though I think the player order is more an effect than a conscious design - I'm sure I'll prefer the player-order by passing-order variant from the upcoming expansion).

My nine-year-old son said, "I like this game". That's GOLD: he's never liked a (non-cooperative) gamer's game before. Ever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Felt unnecessarily complex at first, but after a round or two, everything becomes clear.   You kind of have to relish in the game's many moving parts, or it won't be enjoyable.   I was reminded of Hansa Teutonica, in that each player has a number of pieces on their individual board that they are trying to get onto the main map (i.e. it is a "dashboard" game).  A variety of wood bits represent the different building types, which functions essentially as a tech tree.   The catch is that you can only build on your own color, so you must "terraform" a hex to match your color first.   The game aims to have theme by providing 14 different fantasy races to play, each with different costs or special abilities, but I'd say the theme is almost non-existent apart from a few nods in the racial abilities.   It has as much theme as Kingdom Builder, for example.   The only part of the game that felt a little flat to me mechanically was the 4 color tracks that players are racing to be first in.   This has been done in many other games and didn't add much here.   But, by and large, for a heavier, thinky-er Euro, this is an engaging and interesting game throughout its length.   Has gotten better with age.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vote after first play. Complex but fluid. Very pleasant eurogame!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
TM is one of the few games that gets better with more players; it shines with 4 or 5. With 14 possible player factions to choose from, it offers a lot of variety to explore. With the round bonuses randomly changing, each game requires strategic adjustments to maximize your score. There is a lot going on, so teaching this game to new players requires patience from both the teacher and the learners. But it is worth it; the game is great fun. TM is an excellent way to spend 2-3 hours when you are ready for games with more depth than Settlers of Catan, Ticket to Ride or Stone Age.

RATING: 6
I think this game is among the most overrated games in the BGG. There are apparently many options but having your race and the VP tiles set, your optimal path is almost decided, with little tough decisions.
 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can't imagine not having this game in my library.  The balance between wanting/needing to build close to other players (for cheaper upgrades and for leeching power) while also being able to expand your territory is at the heart of what makes this a great game.  The race to secure those coveted and contested hexes in the early game is stressful and exciting.  Maximizing VPs by building and upgrading during the optimal round takes patience and commitment to your long term strategy.  The final push to score those last few VPs, win a cult track or two, and hopefully connect your last couple dwellings to compete for the largest area bonus is where all your hard work over the previous couple hours can finally pay off.  Can you wait one more turn to grab that power action that gives you the 7 coins you need, or should you burn power to grab it because Bob is looking like he might grab it before it comes back to you?  Do you need to pass early to get the bonus card that gives you a free spade, or would it be better to upgrade another temple (with that sweet, sweet favor tile and priest income) and risk someone else passing before you and grabbing it?

The box seems to weigh as much as a small car for a reason--the individual player pieces are wood and the game board and player mats are thick cardboard.  If the game play wasn't as good as it is, you might still want to pull it out just for the feel of the pieces.

It is highly replayable.  The asymmetric races each have their own unique attributes and powers, and it's fun to see how differently you have to play with each of them in order to succeed.  Combining all the different races with the variability of round scoring tiles and bonus cards means that no two games will be the same.  With different scoring tiles and bonus cards in the game, you might need to employ different strategies from one game to the next even if playing with the same race.

The fact that everything is available for you to see from the very beginning of the game (players can't hide their available resources and there are no random events that happen) means you can plan your strategy out from beginning to end (or at least a couple rounds in advance).  This gives more experienced players a distinct advantage; however, there's no opportunity to mess with your opponents directly.  There is competition for real estate and power actions, but you don't have to worry about someone attacking you which is nice and will allow newer players the freedom to figure things out without being annihilated to the point where they just can't do anything.

The artwork is attractive and interesting, and the fact that there are no words on the game board or player mats is very much appreciated.  Everything is handled with iconography.  So once you understand what the icons mean, even new players will rarely need to consult the rule book.

This is a HEAVY game (literally and figuratively), but it is incredible.  The only problem I have is finding people to play it with me since it takes a long time to explain the instructions, and it takes someone one or two playthroughs before they are comfortable with it.  It's also much better with 3-5 players than it is a 2-player game.  Though there are some interesting 2-player variant suggestions out there on the forums.  Fortunately, there's a mobile version of it so I can get my fix.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Abstract strategy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
CLUB COPY. I'm addicted to this game. Endless replayability, easily my most played game. Strategies are different for each race, and even then, scoring tiles affect strategies too. I'll never get bored of this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
The first time I played this, I was completely confused.  Ok, I'm building all of these things on the board, trying to expand and get more resources.  But that stuff isn't worth points on its own?  I'm trying to grab up all this territory to build on, but at the same time I want to be butting up against the other players?  I can build my big building to unlock new powers, or I can build temples to get persistent bonuses, or I can advance my tech so it's easier to do stuff, or just put lots of small buildings down?  And then there's the cult board to worry about?!  And the magic system!  And the variable player powers!  

This game is similar to some others, and feels a little familiar, but it's also very different.  Playing it is easy.  Playing well, playing to win..  now that's tough.

My only big complaint about the game is the map: it never changes.  There's no cordoning off areas in a game with fewer players.  There's no modularity to it.  I think I'd get tired of the [i]board[/i] long before I got tired of any of the other aspects, which have good variety to them.

I'm still at that point where I haven't played with all the races yet, and certainly haven't tried them all multiple times, so it's still fresh for me.  It was getting tons of play for a while, and still gets played frequently, but not at quite the frenetic pace when it was new.  Not one I feel like doing all the time, but still quite good.

ed. So, after quite a few more games and some discussion, I've become more frustrated with some of the game's rough edges.  The races just aren't balanced completely.  Most of them are close, but there are a couple standouts and a couple that are clearly weaker.  What I'd really like is a single document with errata that patches them up a little, as a result of all the play the game's been getting.  Maybe give the giants an extra worker to start, or take away a couple points from some other faction, or shift a token or two from bowl 2 back to bowl 1.  Minor tweaks to bring them in line.  I don't have the time or inclination to generate such a guide, but there are one or two online.  It is a thorny issue, for certain.  Figuring out exactly which factions are strongest/weakest and by how much is no easy task.  I do feel that it's necessary, however, for players to go into a game with confidence that they have an equal shot, and that their victory won't be because their faction is OP.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very good game, but does not tickle the fun factor as much as I'd like.

This was a day 1 buy for me as it ticked all the boxes I love, Euro resource engine/management, long term strategy, short term tactics, many factions, simple mechanics, area control, top-notch components... Drooled over it.

Could not have fallen flatter with our first 4p game.  It just felt lifeless and abstract.  The kicker was we consistently missed actions and messed up rules constantly, skipped some scoring, and many just played very poorly.  Most of my family group were not too excited to play again but remained intrigued at least.  

Games #2-3 were still just ok but could tell understanding was starting to click and scores were improving and fewer mistakes and rule misses were being made as our brains wrapped around all the different factors to building your engine, board presence, and final score.

Game #4 everything just started to click.  Great experience.  Tons of tough choices, very little luck, simple to understand resource engine, and everyone understood what each was going for to a small extent.

There are quite a few moving pieces here that just overwhelmed us at first and prevent us from bringing out more often:  Favor, Towns, Bonus tiles, Cult Track, Power, Stronghold Powers, Faction abilities, Round Bonuses, and Resources.  Most of us being seasoned mid-heavy gamers, it felt like a juggling act until 4-5 plays in.  


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a complex game with lots of mechanisms and exceptions to learn.

Now that I've internalized the complexity, most of the fun is in solving the private puzzles of acquiring bonuses and converting resources. Both puzzles reward long-term strategy.

A smaller part of the fun is interacting with other players on the shared map, power action spaces, and temple tracks.

It took a few plays to understand how to choose a faction and place well at the beginning. If you choose and place poorly it can be hard to catch up.

I enjoy this game in spite of its weaknesses: too much complexity, too much importance on early-game decisions, too steep of a learning curve, too little interaction.

RATING: 9.5
Great Game! I will admit this game is deep and has a lot going on. But once you start to get the knack for how things interact it becomes really fun to try and outwit your opponents of the actions that you can do and how you can get your great race to be played to its fullest extent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.08
Game tuned to my taste. Perfect mechanics, perfect game length, perfect complexity, huge replay value.
Great middle to heavy weight euro brain burner placed in fantasy setting where 14 (20 with expansion) different factions build their empires on different types of terrain through terraformation.
Every player has his own type of terrain on which he can build and they are also competing for the favor of gods in 4 cults: Fire, Water, Earth and, who would know it, Air. It is fairly complex, but perfectly designed, fluent and elegant. The components are beautiful, artwork is quite appealing and different factions are so perfectly balanced with many paths to victory.

People mostly criticise the lack of player interaction. For me, there is pretty enough of it. Although there are no any direct conflicts, we were constantly competing to in a race for different objectives and goals. Also the mechanic where it is much cheaper to expand your city next to other players while it also gives them power points to use their magic is fantastic. The game is just awesome!

[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] The way income on the player board is covered by buildings and different buildings cover different income. If you build a dwelling you will get income of workers. But if you upgrade a dwelling to a trading post you will uncover income of power and gold but you will have to return the dwelling to the player board, once again covering the income of workers.

RATING: 9
Nem véletlen tarolt tavaly minden nagyobb díjon: jól el van találva, változatos. És bár sokfelé figyelős, meg minden, azért valahol nem is olyan bonyolult, és meg van benne a másikkal szembeni konfrontáció lehetősége is. Nagyon bejött. Az értékelés egy játék után, ha többet játszom vele, akár még nőhet is. 
A játék:
6 forduló, minden fordulót egy lapka jelez, aminek az egyik felén a forduló közben szerezhető plusz pontokat mutatja (azaz h miért jár), a másik felén meg a forduló végén kapható bónuszokat. (vagyis h miért járhat mi).
A játék, világjáték: vagyis egy világon vagyunk, ahol sok csoport-törzs-nép él, (nem egyértelmű, mert a törpe nyilván nép, de a fakírok nem annyira :-), a szabályban csoport van). Az adott játékra annyi nép lesz,ahányan játszunk, amúgy is csak 7 féle lehet, mert a játékoslapok 2 oldalúak, mindkét felén 1-1- csoport, így egyik választása kizárja a másikat. Már csak azért is, mert azok azonos színűek. A színek egyben megfelelnek a földrészen látható tereptípusnak is, így az egyes csoportok otthonföldje, a saját színe: ilyen helyre tudnak építkezni, a másik típusúakat előtte terraformálniuk kell a hazai földtípusra. Az egyes csoportok nem egyformák, a csoportnak megfelelően vmi pluszt tudnak, vmi mást tudnak, mint a többiek, egyediek. 8 féle akció van amikből egyesével lehet választani a fordulókban és egy forduló addig tart, amíg mindenki nem passzol. A 8 akció, a terraformálás és építkezés, az épület fejlesztése (egymásra épülnek, ha az alap épületet tovább fejlesztjük, az visszakerül. Illetve a felépített épületek miatt kapunk a köv forduló elején bevételt (amit a  játékostáblán a feltett épület helyén van ábrázolva)). Hajózás fejlesztése  (messzebb is tudunk építkezni), ásó cserearány javítása -olcsóbban tudunk terraformálni-, pa küldése vmelyik kultuszba (4 féle van, a játék végén az egyes kultuszukban értékelés, h ki milyen magasra jutott, igen sok pont járhat érte, plusz menetközben így-itt is lehet hatalomponthoz jutni), aztán vannak a spec akciók is, ezek egy fordulóban 1x hajhatók végre, van amiért "harc" folyik, azaz aki kapja, marja: ezek a játéktáblán vannak, és hatalompontért szerezhetőek meg, hajthatók végre. Van amit adott játékos tud megcsinálni a csoportja miatt, van ami a bónuszkártyákhoz kapcsolódik, van ami a kegytárgyakhoz.
A játékban a fix körösség miatt egyértelműen látható vég. A terraformálás-építkezés nagyon jól van kitalálva, a hatalompontok rendszere szintén (3 hatalomtartály, egyikből a másikba lehet csorgatni a hatalmat, és a 3. tárolóból tudja a játékos felhasználni, ami újra az elsőbe kerül vissza). Ez egyrészt ugye a spec akciókhoz, másrészt papra, emberre vagy pénzre is konvertálható. Az építkezéseknél 2 jó ötlet: egyrészt ha van a szomszédban más csoportnak épülete, akkor ő kaphat hatalompontot azért, hogy mellette épít vki - igaz nem ingyen, és függ az épületének nagyságától. A másik: h az egybefüggő épületsorok várossá válthatók bizonyos feltételek esetén, amiért persze bónusz és pont jár. A menetközben szerzett pontokhoz (egyes fordulók spec pontjai, aztán az akciókkal szerezhetők, aztán bónuslapokkal szerezhetők stb) mellé a játék végén 2 dologért pont: az említett 4 kultusz kiértékelése -ki van benne előrébb- és a legnagyobb összefüggő saját területért is jár pont. 
Nagyon jó, ötletes, jól felépített, interaktív, de magadban is tervezős, jó a mechanikára öntött téma, szóval kiváló.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After seven plays in a week's time, this game has shot to the top of m favorites list. I have never obsessed over playing and re-playing a game like I have this one. 

For those who are wondering what it's all about: it's a heavy euro, with engine building, resource management, and a tiny bit of worker placement. There's a heck of a lot to keep track of throughout the game (five separate resources to manage, plus plenty of cost/benefit analysis on the multiple different ways you can pick up VPs here and there), but the rules themselves are actually not that complex, and most people should have a firm grasp of the game halfway through their first playthrough.

Running time is pretty fast: with four players, we knocked out two games in 2.5 hours, including setup and teardown.

There is a bit of discussion on the Geek about balancing between the 14 different factions you can play, but so far, it all seems pretty balanced. Some are definitely harder to catch onto the strategy than others, but once you've gotten a race's strategy, no one seems noticeably over- or under-powered.

For anyone who loves Euros, this game should be at the absolute top of their buy list.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Incredibly deep game requiring players to balance an economic engine while attempting use the same resources to develop and grow their civilization. While deep, surprisingly easy to learn within a round or two.  Mechanics feel borrowed from other titles that experienced gamers will recognize.  The sheer variety of races out of the box (14) will keep you busy for a while.  The races feel a little unbalanced, but each have strengths and weaknesses AND each play very differently. Discover your own play style!

Strongly recommend to acquire the 4 Town Tiles promo via Feuerland's website or BGG.

The expansion Fire & Ice was released at Essen '14 and re-balances the original map to make some of the more challenging races more competitive.  Also, incorporates 6 new factions and two new terrain types.  Looking forward to many more hours of play!
  

This copy includes the Shipping bonus promo tile, Temple bonus promo tile, Landscape promo tiles, 4 Towns promo tiles, and 3 GameTrayz for storage.

This is one of my most played games and I have yet to even scratch the surface of all the strategic possibilities.

RATING: 7.75
Sprawling, brain-burning, AP fest, in a fantasy civ-building package. You want it? It's in here, which gives it a kitchen sink of Eurogames feel. Seems like every game mechanism is included. Feels like a mashup of Small World, Kingdom Builder, Castles of Burgundy, and Eclipse. Yet despite all the game does well, I'm not sure it's fun. A challenge, yes, but it's too much like work, and it lacks the narrative that a game this long needs to sustain itself. That said, I'd play it again, because it needs repeat plays to get the reward it promises.

RATING: 9

I really like action selection games with passing incentives (e.g. turn order, bonus tiles) and the interaction on the main board is great. The cult track seems a bit bolted on, but overall, this could end up being my favorite Euro game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Terra Mystica is a euro with a strong spatial element. You have to manage the following resources: Workers, Money, Power and Priests. Money and workers are needed for building and upgrading buildings. Workers are also needed for terraforming neighboring land types to the type of land that your race is able to inhabit. You usually start the game with 2 of the most basic building (the Dwelling) on a hex board. The Dwelling gives you workers in an Eclipse sort of method such that when you remove something from your board to place on the main board you're uncovering additional income. These Dwellings can be upgraded into Trade Houses. The Trade Houses will give you money and power in the income phase. It's cheaper to build a Trade House if it's next to an opponents building. Though, if you build or upgrade any buildings next to an opponent, your opponent can buy power for a VP amount. The Trade House can be upgraded into one of two things. The first is the Stronghold which is one of your mega buildings. It usually gives you power for income and always unlocks a special ability based on the race you've chosen. The special ability could be a one-time effect, a constant ability, or a special action you can use once/turn. 

Trade Houses also have the option to upgrade into a Temple. Temples will give Priests for your income and also a Favor Tile. The favor tile will move you up a Cult Track of your choice and usually has a special ability. This could be income, scoring options, special abilities and special actions. Temples can be upgraded into a Sanctuary. The other mega building. Upgrading gives you a Favor Tile, typically a Priest for income and it makes it easier to create a town in your conglomerate. When conglomerates get so large, they will become towns which will give you points, a one-time benefit, and the ability to climb to the highest point in one cult track.

At the beginning of the game you can choose a special tile which usually will give you income of various types, and/or scoring opportunities, and/or special actions. Tiles that aren't chosen get money ala Puerto Rico. When a player passes at the end of the round they choose one of these special tiles to use in the next round gaining any money that may have accrued on them and then pass in their old one which other players can then choose from. So, what are Priests for? You can advance in the Cult Track with them. This can be done in a small increment or if you remove them from the game then it will be a larger increment. They can also help upgrade your workers to make terraforming land more efficient. Beyond that, you can use Priests to upgrade your naval capabilities. Naval capabilities will let you transform lands across water and make your network larger for the end game scoring. The alternative to naval capabilities is creating bridges which costs Power.

What's power good for? Power can get you immediate resources at a somewhat hefty cost that don't take an action. In addition to that, there are 6 power costing actions that all players have access to. That said, each actions can only be used once per round in a first come, first served basis. What's the point of the Cult Track? At the end of the game, each of the four cults have an area majority-eque scoring for whoever has climbed the highest on the cult track. Rising on the cult track is a minor method for gaining power. Finally at the end of a round players can possibly get a bonus based on how high they have climbed a particular cult based on the round tile. The higher they are the more they can benefit from this round tile. The round tiles also dictate what you will get bonus points for during that round. This is typically for putting a specific type of building on the board. Beyond the Cult scoring, the end game has a scoring for the largest network in an area majority sort of way. 

The game is alright. I like the various factions despite the fact that they don't seem completely balanced. I think my biggest problem with the game is the round tiles which give you points for doing something specific. I feel they dictate what you should be doing more than what I would like. I think it would have been better if building were worth decent VP and the bonus on these tiles were minor VP. Instead buildings are just a means to get resources and special abilities. Beyond that the round tiles also create incentives on which cult tracks you should be focusing on at various points of the game. I prefer more freedom in my games but this is a good game, with low luck and lots of replay value.

RATING: 8
I was very positively surprised about this game, although I hadn't expected it to be bad even if I was quite suspicious about variable player powers involved. They seemed to be balanced pretty well (based on 1 play). 

There is a nice pace in game, as it's possible to act only a little per turn but all players can take their turns until everyone has passed. Gaining benefits but also having some harm about the neighbours is interesting too. 
Now I must mention also that I had some Catan vibes (and the board's hexas didn't reduce them).

Mostly I like how the game looks but I think that those strongholds, temples and sanctuaries look dull, there would have been many ways to make them look more nice... but maybe they were too costly ways!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Resource and timing game, with a lot of area control, and opportunity cost decisions. 14 different factions, all with special ability's, make the game very re-playable. Most of the races feel at least a little different from any other. There is a bit of overlap in some races and some races will be wanting to compete for specific goals more then others. 

The order of the turn player markers, what turn bonuses are available and what other factions are chosen all change the game play for each faction (adding to re-playability). So, while some races feel better then others, and there may be a couple that are generally worse, most of the factions have the chance to be the best faction choice in a given game.

This game is a little complex for the casual gamer. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great balance between theme and mechanics. At no point did I perceive that awkward disconnect between mechanics and theme I get with other games. Lots to do and think about in this game. It is a heavy thinkier. Highly recommended.

RATING: 8

There is much to do and much to consider in this game, and several actions have a delicious give-and-take. My big complaint is that the game has a tendency to drag players through it, via round bonuses, rather than giving them the freedom to explore. Everything else though is top-notch, and I appreciate the asymmetry between the races and terrain types.

RATING: 9
This is a Euro that players are optimizing resources in order to position themselves to gain the most points.  The multiple 'races' give an interesting interaction.  Game is definitely best played with a group not akin to analysis-paralysis.  

Played a 2 player, 5 player, and 4 player game.  Definitely better with 4-5 players.  Will probably play 2 factions in next 2 player game.  Uncertain if 3 players would be a 'good' game.  Meta-gaming could have more of an influence on player interaction than actual game play.  Ex: Playing as cultist could have people NOT acquire power resource, which will influence what action are (or not) taken during a cultist game.
