=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really overwhelming in the beginning. First few games I played I really balked at how many different compartments the game had (area control, resource management, racing up the worship tracks, drastically different racial abilities, and who knows *what* the hell is going on with those bowls!). It felt like a hotchpotch, full of seams. I couldn't see how it all fit together. 

After about the fourth game, though, I started to get a feeling for how tightly interrelated everything is, and by the sixth game -- wow, it all opened up. I now find every game exhilarating and highly satisfying, extremely challenging and complex. The variable goals and races ensure that each game will require a radically different approach. You are forced constantly to evolve, to re-evaluate the merits for this game of a strategy that paid off well in another game. My gaming group is also hooked: they can't believe how much depth the game has. Am definitely looking forward to many, many more months of play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The rulebook/explanation makes Terra Mystica appear more complicated than it actually is -- at its core, TM is about scoring victory points in a few categories (primarily round-end scoring and racial bonuses, followed by favor tiles, end-game cult track, end-game contiguous size, and city building), all accomplished by spending resources to build/terraform or upgrade various elements. Of course, players need to balance immediate benefits with the resource production engine and correctly tweak said engine on a turn-by-turn basis to cash out. 

Player interaction comes primarily from map interactions, which are more passive-aggressive than aggressive proper, and more direct competition for the once-per-round spells, which usually offer better-than-usual resource conversion rates. There's a variable initial set-up (seating order, faction selection, randomized round bonuses and passing tiles), but there is no randomness after the game starts, both elements that I appreciate. I also appreciate that the bonuses for buildings/upgrades are printed under each building/upgrade (a la Eclipse) in an elegant manner, making it easy to determine income and benefits. The arrows that indicate the building upgrades, however, are not as prominent as one might hope, however. 

All in all, I find Terra Mystica to be a very good game, but not a brilliant one. It does everything well, incorporating ideas from many games that have come before, but it doesn't have the fresh, innovative feel that would make it a 10/10. Or perhaps I'm just an old, cynical gamer at this point. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has everything that I appreciate on a game. Plenty of meaningful decisions, many different factions that really change your way to play the game, random setup that makes every game feel different.

Also there is a decent amount of interaction and competition between players without direct conflict. You can plan your game with many different strategies and how you'll try to achieve the victory.

This is a heavy game, keep away if you don't like games that burn your neurons :D

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is not a game in my wheelhouse for fun though I can recognize that for people who like this sort of experience, this game must be nirvana with all the different race powers.  This is the strategy game [i]par excellence[/i] for hobbyists who like dry, action specialization. Those people who detest Agricola’s forced generalization will find refuge here as this one is all about taking one’s race power and maximizing the hell out of it within a narrow opportunity space.

I’ve noticed that I’m a lot less interested in games that ask me to show How to do something vs What I want to do. Giving me end-of-turn VP targets to hit and then asking me to complete them more efficiently than my neighbors leaves me cold since it requires a hyper focus on repetitive efficiency. You’re given an equation and told to show you can solve it then repeat for a different equation next turn. I prefer the creativity of deciding what to do in order to find VPs.

I only have a couple plays of this one, and I could be convinced to give it another try, but for a better implementation of this sort of thing, I think Hansa Teutonica beats it hands down. There you have a lot more creativity as to how to get VPs while still having to achieve a level of action efficiency. And you can get two games in in the same time as one of these.

RATING: 8.25
I love, love, love:
- the power/bowls mechanism
- the asymmetric players
- that it's a Euro-y, somewhat complex engine builder
- the many wooden components
- looking at my city/cities and buildings at the end of the game and seeing how I've expanded my faction

I dislike:
- that the theme is rather pasted-on
- that should you do one or two bad turns, you really fall behind
- that some of the favor cards are clearly the best to gain regardless of faction

Final verdict: This game is so Euro-y and complex and deep and interesting to play but feels dry and point-salad-y. On the other hand, I do like figuring out the game and playing something different like this occasionally.

RATING: 9
Fantastic civilization builder. Balance long term growth with victory point opportunities. It has enough races to keep the game fresh, and each player count also changes the game dramatically.

Some people have complained that the influence/magic bowls feel tacked on, but their manipulation is what drives the interest in the game for me.  You want to burn off some of it, but you can't lose too much or certain actions will be lost, or you can top out lower than you should.

RATING: 8.5
CoG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have a very specific game-type that I like, even though I still appreciate a great game. I say this because I tend to rate games much more on how the game play is to me rather than overall. 

So, I give Terra Mystica a perfect score for several distinct reasons. First is the round/action set up. The turn capabilities is outstanding, and is similar to Agricola in that respect. You are always building towards being able to do as much as possible per round, and generally the more resources, the more actions you can do per round (obviously). This makes the gameplay very intense, but also every action you make has to be strategically planned out.  

Second is the scoring. Scoring is consistent, and also goes throughout the game. You need consistent scoring per round as well as at the end to win. This is a bit different from most board games of this prestige, which makes TM incredibly unique but also makes you sweat. Love the intensity and anxiety a game can give you.

Third is the territory building. TM is like a combination of Settlers of Catan (territory building/civilization) and Agricola (economic), with a undescribable intensity that only will come from the likes of a Ticket to Ride game with extremely seasoned players. 

I LOVE THIS GAME.

RATING: 10
Just gold in my opinion.  I love every aspect about this game.  I do wish there was a bit more theme to it, but that does not take away from the overall experience.  The expansion is not needed but always welcome as it does not change rules just adds a few characters and they come with a few inserts. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One 4p game. There is certainly decent replay value to be had with the different factions, but the different factions are not completely balanced and a few are clear turkeys. This can make it difficult for players with less experience to survive against more experienced players. Some handicapping system for the factions is needed (as evidenced by faction auctioning in the expansion). Yet maybe experienced players can have fun trying to get the turkeys to work in their very specific ways(?).

A comment from one of my Geekbuddys is that after the choice of faction and initial placement, the game largely comes down to how well you execute since there is no luck in the game. I think my one play confirms that: there's not a great deal of interaction and it does feel rather solitaire-y when you play. Sure, you interact with others in available choices and there is some board interaction, but largely you are optimizing in your own little world. I contrast this with a more interactive game like Lords of Xidit where players are constantly bumping into each other resulting in laughs and some disappointments.

For me it all seemed way too long with little reward for the time invested. I'm growing weary of the typical Euro any more so a game had better have something special or unique and this one just doesn't do it for me. I feel like Small World does the multiple faction/ability thing better, it has faction auctioning built-in, and games are fairly quick. Terra Mystica is like Small World without direct interaction, that goes on for hours, and you're stuck with the same race/ability combo the whole time.

RATING: 9.9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I want to like this game, sort of like how it wants to have a theme. Unfortunately, neither situation really works out. The power cycle is clever, but slow. But...

There's no combat! It's a civ game FULL of potential plays that would be acts of war in other civ games. Yet inexplicably, these fantasy races all get along like bread and butter. 

This game would be a lot better if it wasn't such a slave to the unofficial Eurogame combat prohibition. As it is, it's an OK game.

RATING: 6.5
Rating after two full and one partial play.  Multiple resource management game where the fun element will be destroyed by players with too much analysis paralysis (long game, waiting for your turn, and relatively few turns in a game). Felt very abstract and didn't grab me as "my sort of game" but I can see it appealing to lots of people.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This initially seems very complex but the game play flows very well and the board becomes very self explanatory. It can be a bit brain burning at times but there is short term strategy as well as long term development of far reaching plans. It get the balance of this very well.

Huge amount of replayability in this one, not only in that you have 14  factions that all play differently but you also have more actions that you pick each turn than are required for a game thus each game several are unused, and there are more turn victory conditions than required therefore again some remain unplayed each game. 
The victory conditions for a turn are also shuffled randomly and therefore greatly affect the way in which you shape your strategy. 
For example I played as the halflings who gain a victory points per space they use. The final turn of the game gave bonus 2 victory points per spade spent that round and so I player the whole game towards stockpiling my workers to turn into spades to rack up silly points in the last round (this almost won me the game... almost) If this tile had been lower down the track i.e. earlier in the game, then this wouldn't have been a valid strategy.

In the first game we played the action that gained you a cultist was one of the ones removed from play therefore it was very difficult to gain priests therefore there was very little interaction with the cultist board. A second game where this power is included may mean the cultist board is more prominent in the game and therefore tactics will be very different again.

The magic power mechanic is really nice as you can always use it to make one of the three resources (priests,workers,cons) if you have miscalculated and end up a few short therefore you don't end up missing a turn because of a lack of components. It also encourages you to build your civilisation close to other players, but not so close they could block you off and thus hurt your expansion.

Really nice components and the board is very pretty however we found several times that the components were called names based upon flavour instead of what they did in the game and therefore there was confusion about what components were which, but as this was a first game this will change over time, although I suspect I shall forever refer to the dwellings as houses and the trading posts as towns due to the shape of the piece and thus confuse everyone.

Really looking forward to many more games of this as I suspect it may become a favourite with our group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Two more copies in my game group(s) present. Sold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very impressive game!  Love the vast selection of competing race factions.  Also love the circular flow of the player board... which is a huge improvement over Hansa Tuetonica.  Lots of replayability from the different races and the random initial setup (both on round incentives and available bonus tiles when a player ends his turn.  Very good interaction!  It also has an interesting collaborative mechanic with the "power bowl" system (and how players can "leech" off others).  It's a unique system in its own right and one I expect will be copied by future designs.

Definitely need more games to see how the tense interaction really plays out.  I can see this possibly growing on me even more and scoring higher with more experience.  But the first couple tries were very fun.  I do think the game is overpriced, but at least you do get a lot of wood inside!  Also interesting is how both Terra Mystica and Tzolkin: The Mayan Calendar utilize similar "temple tracks" (along with a system of benefits players can receive based on the level they reach - along with a rule that only 1 person can exist at the topmost spot).

RATING: 7
Terra Mystica is clearly an excellent design. It's deep and hugely replayable, the production is clear and didactic. However, after two plays I feel it's too heavy to play casually, but the number of games you'd have to play to properly comprehend the different factions and how to best play them in any given situation and player count is too high, at least given the game's length. Bottom line, it seems like a great game, I'm just not sure I actually enjoyed playing it, or not enough to devote that kind of time to it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I appreciate this as a tight tense euro strategy game, but the fairly bare bones mechanical connections are the very definition of "Just Another Soulless Euro" - but when the euro is this well-designed, it is still enjoyable to play. The factions are really what make the game for me. I'm glad a friend owns a copy.

Played 10+ times with 2-4p.
Ratings history: 10|10|8..|6....|4|6 
Ratings prediction: Solid 6

[b]Somewhat-abstract, dense p-euro that provides a nice mix of resource management, expansion, and improvements. The variation from play to play is fairly minor. I'll occasionally play a friend's copy.[/b]
PROS
- 14 factions allows for some variation
- nice visual presentation
- the gameplay on the map (i.e. terraforming and settling) is great fun
- slightly better than the average point-salad
- some fun confrontational aspects (blocking off) is mitigated by the help that comes from having opponents on your borders.
CONS
- very dense ruleset
- p-euro (if euros are not your thing)
- the theme is well chosen, but the game is still fairly dry
- not as much variation as you'd think, given the factions, actions, and round markers


My [b]first play[/b]: Definitely not nearly as strong as a 2p game, as a decent amount of the tension of the game comes from the power awarded for proximity to opposing players. Still, it's easy to see that this game offers at least 10 plays of interesting exploration (perhaps much more than that with the right gaming group). Very smart decision by the publisher to include 14 factions.

My third play wasn't great, but I can't figure out how much is the game, and how much is me. We played starting set-up - again - which I think is less interesting, but still, the pursuit of victory points is roughly similar every game, and the differentiation of factions just isn't that...different.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
This is a complicated game taking several hours to play.  Fascinating because the avenues for unique play each time are astronomical.  I guess this game has a cult following, especially with online play.  Knowing the game, playing often, planning ahead with intense attention to detail & character abilities and faults is essential to a high score.  Before I play this again, need to spend a few hours studying the components & characters. 

I give this a rating much lower than it deserves because to become good at this game I would want to play it 2-3 times a week, which would take a huge chunk of time which I don't have for just one game--although I can see myself getting caught into its web.  If I continue to play I am sure my rating will advance.  Also pricey since the expansion adds so much to the game.  Rules were explained very nicely to me, but introducing a newby takes a long time.

I also weighted this game at the full 5 for this reason:  the 14 factions each have their own advantages & therefore game plan.  There can be up to 5 players.  In order to play this game effectively, I feel I have to know & remember the special abilities of each of the opposing groups, and continually re-evaluate their game plan and not overlook any of their possible goals during any of the many actions they take.  This part of the game takes playing experience, and still is a brain burner.

RATING: 6
I'm glad I finally played this.

There is a lot to like with the various mechanics of changing terrain, building, upgrading, getting resources.  The power stuff seemed tacked on, same with the religion tracks.

There is no more than a thin veneer of a theme here.  I didn't feel like I was a nomad changing terrain to desert to build up my empire.  I felt like I was dropping a new terrain disk and plopping a building in a few places.

I would play this again, but I don't have a need to suggest it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Only one play in, Terra Mystica feels like a middle-weight Euro pushed to the extreme.  This sounds like it might be a great thing, and I think it some ways it is.  However, I wonder if it's enough to compete with the heavy-weight economic games that have more compelling player interaction.  Many games that have fairly one-dimensional player interaction feel like you spend some time creating a grocery list of stuff to do/buy in the beginning of the game and then the rest of the game is just about doing the work of proceeding down that list with minor adjustments when the store is out of what you wanted.  If Terra mystica can't be played fairly consistently in under two hours with 4, the more boring part of the game ( the execution of your list) will begin to eclipse the more interesting part (the creation of your list).  To be really enjoyable, though, I think it'll need to clock closer to 1.5 hours.  This could go up a little, but could also drop a point to where I won't actively recommend playing it.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The variable scoring opportunities each round combined with the various races make this game amazingly interesting. Each time I play it I have to improve my rating. Great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terra Mystica is a perfect information game with limited player interaction that works surprisingly well.  I'm a little surprised that it's so high in the BGG ratings compared to some of my favorites, but then again, I am rating it a 9 myself.  There is a lot of opportunity for clever planning with so many options for each turn.  My favorite part of the game is the way the special "power" actions have been designed: power is its own currency that can be gained in a few different ways and used for actions that often can't be done any other way.  The many races with their own special abilities will keep this game fresh and interesting with each play.  I don't care for the fantasy "theme", but thankfully the theming doesn't play a big role in what actually happens during the game. I wouldn't want to play this with people who have severe AP, but this a feast for the puzzle-lover's senses!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Take an economic engine, spread it over wide terrain and introduce an abstract concept of power or influence, and you have Terra Mystica.

The game is at its core an economic engine, but one which it takes slight experience to master; different race combinations make it fresher every time, but at the end of the day everybody is trying to approach a victorious endgame through multiple paths. Annoyingly, there is no conflict as such; unless you count blocking territory and terraforming land away from a player's desired terrain.

This lacks the points-salad approach of a Feldian design, which is a good thing; unfortunately it also lacks variety despite the different races. That said, I cannot say I have ever had a boring or unchallenging game; whilst I decry the lack of a variant board overleaf (they could have used that space to make one more suitable for fewer players), I adore the fact that every decision is meaningful.

The few shortcomings (which were mostly unavoidable, apart from the board thing) prevent me from rating this game above 8 - and it's the fun and challenge I have had which got it there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Thanks to the random placement of the score tiles and bonus tiles, along with the variety of races with unique special abilities, there is an endless potential for variety, providing a different experience each play. I really enjoy a game like this in which you are making progress toward a goal and accomplishing something without luck or other players destroying all of your hard work. In that respect it reminds me a little of Village. Every decision could be game-changing. Win or lose I walk away thinking, "That was a great game!"
 ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿http://greyelephantgaming.blogspot.com/2013/06/terra-mystica.html

RATING: 6
I really wanted to like this game.  I went into it with a clean slate, not having read anything about the game other than it was trending a lot on BGG.

After the rules explanation, I knew I was not going to like the game.  For me, it feels too much like a re-skinning of Settlers of Catan without any semblance of a theme.  The game feels too disconnected and auto-pilot and the lack of a theme really aggravates me.

That's not to say that the game play is terrible, it actually plays quite well.  But for my standards and expectations in games I enjoy, this was a miss.

RATING: 9
Elegant interconnected planning-and-budgetting-or-die. A favorite!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terra Mystica is not a resource conversion game. It is not a connection game, either. Nor is it an area majority game. While all of these elements are present in one form or another you can pretty much ignore any one of them and go after something else entirely. Of course, the various special powers may make taking one of those avenues much more attractive than another. In a way it is quite surprising that with so many different routes to follow and so varied incentives players still get in each other's way all the time.

The game includes a lot of material, special powers here and bonus chits there. That makes the game seem much more complicated than it really is. Individual turns are fairly short and simply enough. The real benefit of all the options, however, should be long-term replayability. Promising.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ohne TERRA MYSTICA kein Feuerland, ohne Feuerland kein TERRA MYSTICA: Die gegenseitige Geburtsstunde markiert einen ähnlichen Evolutionspunkt in der Entwicklung des Eurogame wie es zuvor z.B. PUERTO RICO, CAYLUS oder AGRICOLA getan haben, die mit ihren Ideen nachfolgende Spielejahrgänge nachhaltig geprägt haben und es bis heute tun. Dabei brauchte TERRA MYSTICA einen langen Atem um bahnbrechend und weltweit die Brettspielwelt zu erobern. Die ersten Ideen zu TERRA MYSTICA entstanden Mitte der 90er als CATAN noch die Lande beherrschte, die TERRA MYSTICA nun seit 2012 umgräbt. Dabei beschränkte sich TERRY MYSTICA nicht nur darauf einfach einen neuen Mechanismus zu kreieren, sondern gleich ein neuartiges Spielkonzept zu erfinden, das seinesgleichen vergeblich suchte: allein die konzeptionelle Leistung individualisierte Völker mit speziellen, asymmetrischen Fähigkeiten in immer neuen Konstellationen dennoch ausgeglichen aufeinanderprallen zu lassen, ist genauso großartig wie Frank Heerens Mut, in diese neue Spielidee in einen extra dafür neu gegründeten Verlag zu investieren. The Birth of TERRA MYSTICA und Feuerland ist ein verdientes Symbol dafür, dass sich wahre unternehmerische Risikobereitschaft an Kreativität orientiert, die sie verkaufen will und nicht am Profit, denn sie damit erzielen will. Helge Ostertags Spiel war von Anfang an eine Herzensangelegenheit, denn nur so lässt sich der lange Entwicklungsweg mit durchhalten, um zum Schluß immer noch VOR der Zeit mit einem Spiel für die Zukunft zu landen. TERRA MYSTICA war ein neuer Bewusstseinsschritt. Völker, hört die Signale: ein weltmeisterlicher Wurf mit der Schippe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Two Plays: A true 'classic' imo, after only two plays. I have a copy on the way from Germany (and much cheaper than FunAgain, including shipping). 

I really love it. I seldom rate a game after so few games, but I know this one will be at least a 9. I suspect it will join my '10' group, a very exclusive group of games, with a few more plays. Not easy to explain, but very intuitive to play. Lots of depth and replay-ability. 

Three Plays: It's a 10! Only downside - our group plays slow - but, we enjoy a less hectic approach to gaming.

Six Plays: Still playing with the beginners set-up. Have 5 people trained to play it. Ready to move to the Random set-up. Love it. 

Ten plays: using random set-ups. Still loving it and feel there is so much yet to discover. I have only played a few of the 14 races, so far (Nomads, Witches, Fakirs, Alchemists, Chaos Magicians, and Swarmlings.) 

14 Plays: my favorite game of all time. The more you play it, the more you see to do. 

20 Plays: Not even beginning to tire of it! Still as great as ever. THE BEST ALL-TIME GAME FOR ME!

RATING: 9

I didn't come away from it feeling that it had introduced anything new into the genre, as a lot of these mechanics have been used before (other than the Power system, which I found very intriguing). But what masterful integration of all the mechanics! Although it shares little mechanically with Settlers of Catan, it feels like Catan on crack! Expanding and upgrading your civilization through payment of resources: check. Getting in the way of your opponent's building progress: check. There's even a sort of 'longest road' final score. (Okay: largest town here). Anyway, a real celebration of a game for those who feel Euros are the great savior of the gaming industry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
TM seems, in a significant degree, to have the two characteristics that I like best in a game.  

1. It is [b]truly strategic[/b] - my definition: you can plan you mid and end game right after seeing the setup.  

2. Also, it is [b]explosive[/b] - you can set up big turns where your position advances exponentially.

After 6 plays in 3 days, it starts at a "9" rating and joins the list of my most favorite games.  I'm almost ready to say that it has dethroned Age of Steam as my favorite Euro.

So far, I have three wins in six plays: one with the Alchemists, one with the Dwarves and one with the Halflings.   Notable scores: 114 (w/ Dwarves) and 135 with the Halflings.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
Excellent euro resourse collection/VP conversion with lite civ building - adds some limited player interaction by linking some points to the proximity on the board of your own and your opponent's buildings. 14 different starting races and VP objectives are variable by game and by turn within games, both these factors adding to replayability.  

The rule book is very well laid out and easy to get into the game, icongraphy is good. Excellent bits. Excellent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Update: After a few more plays, I just don't find this game very fun. All of the systems work together, and the different races are somewhat interesting, but it just doesn't produce an fun game to play. There's some amount of interaction between the players, but you don't feel the differences between the races you're playing against. So it feels very different to play with the Darklings than it does to play with the Mermaids, for instance, but it doesn't feel any different to play against the Darklings or against the Mermaids. Nor is there an overarching goal in the game that gives you an idea of why you're doing what you're doing. Points here and there for building, cults, points when you pass... So it all works together but falls flat.

------

My impression is that this is a good game, but I am a little surprised that it is getting so much acclaim.

Everything is clean and works well together. But there is very little competition or interaction at all. This means that if the variable faction powers happen to match up well with the bonus tiles, there is nothing anyone else can do to stop that person. So your most important decision might be the one you make before the game starts, of which faction to play.

Everything is very abstract, as well. The faction powers don't seem tied to the actual factions, magic is just pushing disks around. Still, definitely a good point-efficiency game with a small smattering of different player powers. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game was extremely hyped. Upon reading the rulebook, I was reminded of the decision making of Dominant Species, which I love....

*Cue: excitement!*

Playing it however...I'm not sure how to feel. The theme made no sense. It's a mish-mash of mechanisms, I feel player interaction is low, much much lower than Dominant Species, and your goals (particularly for end game) don't seem so readily apparent. (Besides a mad dash up the cult tracks. :-/) The races have odd powers that don't match their fantasy stereotype, IMO.

It's a clever euro design I suppose. It just lacks, well, FUN.
It did NOT give me the 'feeling' I get when playing DomSpec.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game.... I am dumbfounded on how good it was.  It took some time to learn, and the game itself is in no way short, but I love it.  My friends and I finished a game that started at 10pm at 2am, and we were blown away on what we had just played.

This game is about choices, you have so many choices to make.  If you make the wrong choice you can set yourself back quickly.  

The races are fun, and so well balanced.  There is a great in game balancing mechanism so one player is going to run away with the game.

I really can't describe on how amazing this game is... in lack of a better term, it is PERFECT.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Raised my rating to 6 after my second game.

I have a weird relation to this game. It is certainly not a bad design, nor something that I would stay away from.

Nonetheless, not only I never feel the need to play it, but I'd rather play a bunch of other Euros.

This is one of the rare cases in which the sum of good parts makes for a bad ensemble. 

The mechanisms, some original some not, are nice taken by themselves (the temple track, the cool power accumulation, the digging) but they don't intertwine in a meaningful way, thus making for quite a dry experience.

The in-game scoring system is boring and arbitrary.

Too bad, the idea is nice.

Also, waaaaay to long for what is, after all, not so-clever a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Terra Mystica[/b] [i]Jens Drögemuller - Helge Ostertag 2012[/i]
A fantastic eurogame. Sure it does not add anthing new, and it has no high dosis of interaction, but as an eurogame it is a wonderful design. There are fourteen races in the game and all of them have their little nouances, but are wonderfully balanced. Every time you play you must adapt yourself not only to your race skills but also to its drawbacks. Rules and quite easy to grasp and the game scales very well for three, four and five players. I strongly recomend it and actually in my book Terra Mystica is the best game of the year 2012 hands down. If you dont need high interaction and dont worry about theme in games, this could be one of the best options currently available in the market. It is a bit pricey though (around 65 euros in Europe) but it worths every single penny.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Asymmetric play is a good idea. Also the mechanic of taking piece off the player board and using it on game board, while freed space on player board is giving you abilities, is also a very good, but not a new idea - it is well implemented in Hansa Teutonica, which was invented several years before this. However Hansa Teutonica you can play at least three times, while playing only one time Terra Mystica. But those things are the best part of Terra Mystica. The rest is quite annoying - theme is quite boring and more abstract than in most euros. Irritating delayed rondel (purple bowls) is also one of the most non-elegant solutions for taking more player actions I have seen. I recommend learning from Stefan Feld, how he does things in his games. Also, although this is a heavy strategy game, it is a little bit boring and therefore it is a way too long for what it offers. Overall - OK game, but not among the best strategy games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The game is awesome, probably would be rated higher if  wouldn't have played Tzolk'in in the same session. Many things to take into account, but with not so many rules

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I enjoyed this game from the first time I played, but it wasn't until quite a few plays in that I realised how strong the repeat play value is. I'd just tried playing as Engineers for the first time, and lost badly. Rather than being put off by that faction, I wanted to go back and play as them again to see how I could make the game work for them.

I also love the theme and world of this game. At first glance it looks like a bunch of high fantasy cliches, but I find it fascinating thinking about how all these different fantasy beings adapting to an industrial revolution of sorts, how they transform the world around them in a world in which magic exists. On top of that, the mixing of theme and mechanics is perfect - every special rule for each faction makes absolute sense.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
You won´t play TM for its beauty, you won´t play it for its theme and you won´t play it for its innovative mechanics either. But you will play it for it´s a solidly designed Eurogame that is medium weighted.
Normally you choose between 8 options which are easily graspable. It´s the optimal chain of your actions that is a bit of a brainburner. Furthermore your plans may be baffled by your fellow players as some common spots on the map are already blocked. I liked the "when I pass first, then I will be starting player next round and I can choose a bonus for next round as well".
All in all it did not feel that fresh but not old fashioned either. In case you doubt; I did like it but will not buy it myself.
edit: already after a second play I doubt that there is despite different races enough variety to make this a long term favorite.

RATING: 7.5
Beautiful components, awfully interesting mechanics.

I'm fascinated, since you obviously need to be obstructive of other players, when you also need their willing collaboration and good relations. A fine balance is required. 

Please, please, do not try to explain this game. Explanation will require at least 40 minutes. While you'll really understand it better by simply trying to play through a turn or two. 

Definitely a gamer's game, I totally recommend it. 


UPDATE
After my third serious game I'll turn this game down a 0.1 or two. The races are not completely balanced. I'm also not bought on the art. For as interactive that it seems to be, I'm starting to think that this game tends to become a multiplayer solitaire.

UPDATE
Fourth game, turned up 0.1 :)
I played with the expansion, on the new map, the game looks more balanced than before.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
How do I rate a good game that I don't actually want to play? I see its draw—it allows the consummate fan of the Euro to enjoy a game without any direct player interaction, multiple interlocking pathways to victory, economic optimization with the friction of currency exchange inefficiencies, variable player powers, etc.

I like many of these things, but when I play Terra Mystica, it strikes me as tactically overwrought because it practically invites players to make short-term decisions that wipe out opponents' strategic choices without a way to mitigate or repair them. It is also prone to analysis paralysis, because it requires some long-term strategic planning to maximize points—but such strategies are easily foiled by the high-intensity tactics (e.g., cities need juxtaposed adjacencies, but can be stopped easily). Strategic failures are very costly and hard to recover from. The possible AP (especially in a five player game) makes it so that a player who has been constructively eliminated must drudge through the remainder of the game trying in good faith to lose with dignity—or he may be left to kingmaking—ironic for a Euro game without any direct player interaction.

It's a game for bean counters who like very well made beautiful components.

Eclipse is a better game.

Dominant Species is a far superior game in the same vein—better because you can discard your strategy in DS more easily if you need to without being stuck in old decisions that you can't mitigate.

RATING: 9
Wonderful production. Awesome replayability from the asymmetrical races alone, even before considering how deep the game is. Cult track and power are interesting in their own right but integrate nicely with the rest of the game such that they don't feel overly out of place. Tons of strategic depth here. Lots of routes to victory with most races lying somewhere along the spectrum of town-focused to cult-focused (Of course with exceptions).

Some time issues with my playgroup but forcing people to play faster the second time through made it feel so perfect. Now we make a good pace of it and are finishing just a bit long of the games advertised playtime.

Don't care much for the extra scoring tiles in F/I, new races are fun but really unnecessary for how much replayability the game already has. New double sided board is nice though, and cloth bags are sexy. Overall a seemingly non-essential expansion, but nice nonetheless.

RATING: 6.5
The game needs some serious balancing. The different races are totally unbalanced. If two players are playing top races and the others get to choose among what's left, they have little chance to win right off the bat.

The idea is great, but it lacks work, especially on the racial abilities. Like the Fakirs are the worst of all.

I was told that in the expansion there are actually two races that are even worse than the Fakirs!

The game is also extremely expensive for a very ordinary content. I mean, it's the price of a game with miniatures but you have none. Just a bunch of ugly woodden blocks!

So instead of getting an 8.5 from me, this gets a 7 due to poor balancing of races and thus poor playtesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[After first game - rating 4]
This game is a prototype for all dull, heavy and overly complicated Eurogames.  Victory points everywhere, half a dozend different mechanisms, no recognizable theme whatsoever.  

Worker cubes, priest meeples, magic tokens, 4 different tracks for collecting majority points, 5 different buildings with different costs and income, 4 different city markers, 12 different special tiles, 7 different extra action spots, 14 different races with different special abilities, 6 different end-of-turn markers  etc. etc.  Get this, get that, turn this into that, get extra point here, get end-of-game points there. 

Bottom line: there's surely a lot of work to do.  But where's the game in this mess?  

--------------------------------------------------------

[Edit after the second game - rating 6]
Ok, maybe a rating of 4 is too harsh.  Played it a second time this weekend and the game was slightly better.  The aspect of building next to different players (to collect magic power) in contrast to build on your own (to have more room) is interesting.  
Raised rating to 6.

--------------------------------------------------------

[Edit after 4th game - rating 7.5]
I must admit that my initial impression was wrong.  This is in fact a quite faszinating Eurogame. Its all about timing to grab the various scoring opportunities as they come along.  Not sure however, how good the races are balanced.  Raised rating to 7.5.

--------------------------------------------------------

[Edit after 7th game - rating 8.5]
Ok, ok I've learned my lesson.  Never rate a (complex) game until you've tried it several times.  Regarding TM: I'm hooked.  What a fine game with so many interesting decisions.  A warning to new players though: beware this beast!  It's deep, it's complex and it may take a while until you recognize its full potential :)
Raised rating to 8.5

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
iOS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is not what one expects from a game with Fantasy races on a map. First and foremost, there is no direct confrontation. Instead, there is a strange concept of changing terrain that seems directly taken from the computer game series "Disciples". The players do that to build, because each race can only build in one type of terrain, and building is the core of the game. In most cases, however, the players change the terrain and build in the same action. As terrain has no other effect in the game, the whole thing feels unnecessary.

In fact, there are many unnecessary elements. This is the Euro brother of your typical, overly complex Fantasy Flight game, where the designers add as much stuff as they can. There are eight different standard actions, most costing two different resources (money and workers or priests), and half a dozen more printed on the board, costing mana. Then there are the tiles that each player chooses for the next round, most giving two different benefits. And each round has a two-part event that affects everyone. And certain buildings also allow you to choose from a dozen tokens with two benefits. And if you manage to form a city, you choose a token from a different set. And so on, and so forth.

However, unlike a Fantasy Flight game, it comes with ugly and generic wooden pieces instead of nice plastic miniatures that would have enhanced the theme presentation. There is simply no immersion. The players may, for example, advance in elemental tracks, but the game does nothing interesting with that and there aren't any differences between the four elements. The only sign of theme is in the particulars of each race. They are actually so unique that it is very hard to tell how well they are balanced, but my first impression is that some are much better than others. Besides, it appears the order of events may also favor some races much more.

I didn't have a bad experience, but it was far from exciting or fun. There is just too much to keep track and consider for too little payoff.

RATING: 10
Komplex és jó.
Hosszú, de végig élvezetes.
Rengeteg lehetőség, de gördülékeny játékmenet.
Nyolc akciólehetőség, de adják magukat.
Sok ismert elem és mechanizmus, de finom összhatás.
Sok ismert elem és mechanizmus, amik finom módosításokkal még jobbak lettek.
Kereshetők a párhuzamok, de nincs rájuk szükség.
Öt játékos ekkora táblán, de nincs jelentős konfrontáció.
Játékosonként más képességek, amik lehetőséget adnak.
Fordulónként más célok, amikre érdemes figyelni.
Fordulónként választott bónuszkártyák, amikre jó hajtani.
Változatos kegylapkák, amik nélkül sanyarú az élet.
Hatalomakciók, amikért versengünk.
Mint látható, rengeteg elem, de szép és áttekinthető komponensek.

És nem mondom, hogy sok a jóból.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Impressive that there is no randomness except for the initial setup: the initial player turn order, the choice of bonus tiles, and the choice and order of the 6 round-scoring tiles.

The main reason I dislike this game: with temple favours and city bonuses and power conversions, there are so many possible actions on one turn, and it takes a lot of thinking to come up with the ideal move (especially because you also have to analyze other players' capabilities and motives as well).  The fact that there often is a best move on a turn drives me into analysis paralysis -- I want to analyze all possible moves so I'm sure I didn't miss anything, or I'll feel bad afterwards for having missed it! 

After playing this a handful of times, I don't find it worth the effort any more.  It seems that since there is so little randomness, the most important decision you can make is the initial choice of faction (which depends on what other factions have been taken, and which scoring and bonus tiles are available).  I don't know the factions well enough to figure out the best one given the initial conditions.  And then it's important to choose your initial dwelling placements well.  In short, you could lose the game during the initial setup, before you take a turn!  I think I'll pass on this game from now on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Perfect game !

RATING: 8
Based on one play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I see this game as a throw-back to older games (i.e., '95-2005) that could not have happened without some of the more recent trends in game design. Here we see the inter-meshing of a 'traditional' Euro economic engine (i.e., spend money to make more money; rinse, repeat, optimize), a strong spatial play element (i.e., board-play that is multi-linear and encourages positional play), and asymmetrical powers (i.e., differing abilities per player). In a time in which many games coming out have boards which serve little more than an organizing function (or at best the spatiality of them is linear; e.g., Le Havre could have been a card game), I very much appreciate the map. While not as elegant as, say as Kramer game of similar weight, I say that this is a 'new' throwback to the old because it carries with it the complexity of many of the 'cult of the new' games (the game(r) market has created a space for publishers to put out more, longer, more complex games) while keeping a very streamlined package within a few hours of play and also incorporating elements that would not have often been seen in earlier Euros (e.g.,the variable player powers which make for great variability between, and within games). Rating will likely go up with more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is very fun with unique mechanics but, depending on the number of players you definately need to set aside several hours to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is a beast. It might take a while till you understand the rules quite enough to be able to form strategy as well. This is a heavy euro game with really complex rules. One of the most clever design i have ever played but it really needs a few plays to let your strategic view bloom. I love the mana mechanic by burning your mana to get an initial stroke like a bomb at the start of the game. After that you are going to progress rapidly and trying to use your mana points whatever you can or need. I love interactive area control games like Power Grid or Kemet but there is a bit strange kind of interaction going on there. Usually in area control games if you are going to a specific space first you are holding that position till the game ends. But in this one you must collaborate with your neighbours to get more mana point income and of course to build your buildings cheaper. The interaction is all about to get into advantageous places first before your opponents do. There are a ton of choices to choose actions from means that the mathematical aspect is really strong in this one. As the whole game can be calculated quite well means that in contrast paralysis analysis is a big problem here. In a game where the normal playtime is around 2-2,5 hour i believe just one person doing AP means you will be playing it 4 hours long easily and this is way too long for my taste. Each game needs another strategy to pursue as there are 14 very different faction in the basegame. I have to mention that the game artwork is more functional and not really stellar. The wooden game components are well designed and seems to be working well. Altough this game is quite expensive but despite the price tag this can be one of the best price / value game of all time. The 14 very different factions needs to be played differently and this makes up for a good replayability. After a few more plays i absolutely fall in love with this game. This is just fantastic in every aspect truly one of the best designes of all time. It is elegant and entertaining every single time. After about 30 plays i can tell that this is the best boardgame i have ever played!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(05/17/13) Comment on first play.

Despite all the enthusiasm for this game at the recent Geekway to the West, I was underwhelmed. While it looks like a creative blend of Settlers (variable terrain, building hierarchy), Kingdom Builder (contiguous area development), Castles of Burgundy (creative combos; the intricacy screams Stephan Feld), Small World (expansion and variable racial powers), Eclipse (variable number of actions until you're out of stuff, resource tracking), Atilla (cult tracks), Hawaii (variable turn order passing benefits) with some interesting new game mechanisms (mystic power pools, reminiscent of the "mana" in Magic:TG), it is a typical Euro of: Collect Resources-->Build Buildings-->Get Victory Points. There is an area-control spatial element with the board. However, with repeated plays, it seems the fixed board is prone to standard openings, given some specific race. I do wish the map were geomorphic, but I suppose this would introduce balance issues.

The asymmetric racial powers are truly unique, the board and components look fantastic, and the overall theme is well integrated. Still, I was bored for the first half of the game, averaging about two actions per turn, while it seemed everyone else was doing something extra, with maybe an extra turn or two more each turn. It has something to do with proximity to the the players, as building next to neighbors gives them a benefit in bumping up "power". It seems that players that correctly and quickly exploit their racial abilities, as well as exploit tactical position, will do very well. Duh. However, there is really no player conflict, except for the race to strategic/tactical choke points.

There was a feeling of dissatisfaction, given that there was substantial downtime between turns (it was for two of us our first play, and one player has a bad case of AP). When it was my turn, there was a very limited sense of possible actions, and the choice seemed trivial. Then it was another 10 minutes waiting for it to come around. The game seemed to pick up pace later, when the power pool afforded some extra actions and the economic engine kicked in, but this is typical of Euro games. Am I burning out of resource-collection Euros? It is a well-polished, well-developed game, and yet... it really doesn't grab me.

Initial rating is a "7", with limited room to go up with repeated plays. This is not one of those titles I am excited about running out and getting anytime soon. I'll be happy to play my friends' copies, if they are available.

(05/18/13) Update, 3 Plays.

After two three-player games, I'm beginning to like this game. With equally matched players, the game's last rounds tends to be a nail-biting affair of cat-and-mouse. Players need to keep their options open as long as possible, in order to respond to others, which means maintaining a stream of incoming resources. Some races are easier and fun to play, while others are more difficult, and may result in an unsatisfactory experience. I won with the Swarmlings in the second game, but barely lost with the Mermaids in the third game. Each game feels different, based on whether you manage to place your initial dwellings next to neighbors or not. If developing a city by yourself, the market upgrade cost alone will be prohibitive--you need to be next to neighbors! The second game was exciting, with lots to do, due to the race's starting conditions and proximity to neighbors. The third game was boring, like the first, where I was trying to build by myself. So, initial placement is very important, just like in Settlers.

I'll raise this to an "8". While it is enjoyable, still not excited enough to get my own copy.

(05/19/13) Update, 5 plays.

Okay, I admit it. I like this game. We had two five-player games that went rather smoothly, with little downtime. By this point, all but one had played the game several times in the past few days. However, there seem to be serious play-balance issues with the various races, or it could be that we haven't fully figured out how to play each race optimally. If you choose a poor race, it could be a lopsided and boring 2.5 hours. If you choose a good race, and the initial placement of dwellings are favorable, you're going to have a good time. Swarmlings, Halflings, Witches, and Nomads seem to do very well. Giants, Fierkers, Engineers, and Mermaids seem to do poorly. There is plenty of interaction, in terms of first-come/first-served for the action spaces, and a frantic race up the cult tracks, along with occasional surprises on the map board. Still, not going to get this, yet.

RATING: 10

Quite a lot of rules coming together here but as smoothly as I have not seen it done in other big games in past years. An excellent game that I am currently always willing to play, regardless of the other really excellent titles that were also released in Essen 2012.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Dry at 2 players. It should even be an option on the box. Haven't played with more. 

Original Score: 7.5
Updated Score: 7.75

I feel like first-game experiences fall into three categories: First, there are games that you understand well by the end of the game and could get a handle on the viable strategies available. Then, there are games where you still only kind of know what's going on at the end of the game, but you're willing to play a bit more to start understanding strategy. Finally, there are games that are so hard to understand you don't even know what you don't know. 

I think Terra Mystica falls into the last category. That doesn't make it a bad game, it just makes it one that I need to try more. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
4 Spieler
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Here is a game with so many complex mechanics (spell-casting especially) that it should be crushed under it's own weight. Instead the mechanics and rules add so much depth due to the trade-off with each move. There are so many good moves but too little time to explore them all. Plenty of good options but which is best? The bonus tiles further add layers of scoring variety that changes how each game is played. Helluva brain burner but incredibly satisfying.

The player boards are so elegant. They contain so much information and give each race many different powers without relying on a wall of text / cards / tokens. A well designed product with plenty of game in the box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
15-9-2016; verjaardag Irene,  van Martien

Irene met reuzen 131 gehaald, tegen Justin. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
起始設定:
獎勵板塊抽N+3，首家先選種族，尾家先選獎勵，擺放兩個房子順時針在逆時針百回來。(混法最後放)
1.回合任務最後兩回合不能有鏟子換分。回合獎勵得到鏟子從首家開始使用，沒用完可以鏟下一塊地或放棄。(苦行憎與矮人不能使用特殊能力)
2.以動作得到的鏟子可以使用工人加上去。
3.Pass選下回合獎勵板塊，獎勵板塊沒被選走會+1元上去。
!!4. 建築 付錢建築在你的相連(直接或間接)顏色地上，轉地形要花鏟子，可藉由工人轉換，獲得多的鏟子時除了轉換你要蓋的土地，可再多轉相鄰的但是不能蓋，只能轉換建築物相鄰的土地，魔力或獎勵板塊獲得的鏟子可配合工人增加來鏟到想要地形，回合獎勵的不行配工人鏟地要做完，才能蓋房，不能交替做
種族能力:(易忘)
1.異教徒:當其他玩家因你建族物吸魔，異教徒可以升一格信仰。或沒吸你轉一點魔。
2.混沌法師的要塞能力為使用後可以直接選擇兩個行動執行。
3.苦行憎:起始多兩祭司，可以跳一個進行建造，付祭司。
4.人魚:可以隔一格河流(僅一格)形成城鎮。
5.冰雪與河流種族再一開始就要先選起始地形，選了該種族本廠不會出現。然後起始地形不視為原生地形。跟火山種族判定有關。

擴充有最終額外計分。分別是
1.要塞與聖殿最遠距離
2.城鎮數量最多(一間也算)
3.地圖邊緣數量最多(至少要直接相鄰2間，不能空降)
4.兩個城鎮距離最遠。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a good example of why my interest in Euros is steadily in decline. Essentially it's just the usual fare of converting resources between types and then converting to VP as efficiently as possible. What's different with more recent Euros is the complexity, here there are 3 types of currency: cash, cubes and 'power' and multiple races that all have their own specialisations. All of which makes this a very hard game to 'get' and I won't be doing so as, for me, the effort involved in getting to grips with the system far outweighs the rewards on offer. A competent game, but not appealing for my taste.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Falls in the category of "Semi-crunchy" game that takes a few times to figure out. Helpful if you have two people who have previously played and willing to explain, since there are a lot of inter-player interactions that can be nuanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After three plays, I feel like I am starting to get a handle on this one.  The secret is that the tech track is shorter than it looks, and it's possible to get ambitious earlier than one might assume. There are a ton of things going on in this game, many having to do with the tradeoff between playing for the turn bonuses, which are pretty significant, and playing to keep up with your own plans, which you'll need. If you can afford to do both these things, you've set up your economy better than I've ever been able to do! It's got variable player powers which can be quite significant but which seem fairly balanced (though not 100% sure about this yet), some jockeying for board position, a little tech track, and an interesting economy based on what you have out on the board at that moment.  It still feels fairly tactical--a lot depends on accomplishing what you want in that specific turn--and yet, each turn is wholly dependent on the one before. Would love to have more opportunities to play this. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
A bit complicated, and takes a good bit to teach, but once you're past that it's lots of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
Refrito 2.0 de mecánicas que hemos visto en otros sitios que me ha gustado. Llevar una raza (en plan Smallworld) cuya misión es terraformar el tablero para hacerlo más habitable para si misma (los hobbits viven mejor en colinas que en cualquier otro lugar, los nómadas en el desierto...) y en ese terreno construir sus edificios  unidos en plan Power Grid. Las construcciones (en plan Puerto Rico) permitirán obtener recursos (a saber: poder, palas, sacerdotes, monedas...) como en cualquier juego de gestión de recursos y mejorar las habilidades especiales indicadas en el tablero personal de cada raza (en plan Goa o Hansa Teutónica). Además hay habilidades que se pueden escoger por turno y si no las escoges, para incentivar su elección en el siguiente, se las premia poniendo una moneda sobre ellas... (en plan Puerto Rico) Lo dicho: un refrito. 

Pero el caso es que no me ha parecido malo: hay mucha rejugabilidad porque hay 14 razas distintas que comienzan en el tablero de una manera distinta cada vez. PROS: absolutamente todo (acciones, precios, conversiones, árbol de tecnologías de tu civilización, poderes especiales, recursos iniciales...) está en el tablero, lo que facilita su digestión, y además es útil porque el juego es complejo, para jugones del nucleo duro que no olviden detalles importantes. Cierta interacción, para bloquear al contrario o todo lo contrario: para querer estar junto a él, porque los edificios que él construye pueden darte un recurso ("poder"). CONS Los 60€ que vale, la curva de aprendizaje que es elevada, y que es un refrito abstracto -¿Convertir pantanos en desiertos? - y muy, muy, muy euro. 

Le doy un 7 tras una primera partida con los gigantes en Runa a la espera que baje su precio. 

Sube en OCT 2013 a 9 tras la segunda partida

[ENG]

Nothing new here. It combines different mechanisms from another games I like. You manage a race like in Smallworld (hobbits, sirens...) whose mission is terraform the board in order to make it more habitable (the hobbits live in hills, the nomads in the desert...) and they constuct the buildings on this kind of terrain. The buildings can connect with each other, like in Power Grid and you can obtain resources (spades, magic power, priests, coins...) from them like in Puerto Rico and to increase your skills tracked on your personal board (like Goa o Hansa Teutonica). Further, there are more abilities that you can choose in a turn and if you don´t choose it, they will have a coin over them in order to be more attractive in the next turn.

But the fact is that I like it. There is a lot of replayability becouse there are 14 different races and they begin on a different place in every game. PROS: absolutely all the game concepts (actions, prices, conversions, technologies tree of your civilization, special powers, initial goods...) are on the board, so it´s easy to play a game, and very usefull too! Despite this, the game is quite complicated ("hardcore gamer´s game"). There is a kind of interaction becouse you can block to another player or you can do the opposite: to build near of him/her buildings in order to obtain "power" ( a resource). CONS: Expensive. Learning curve. Nothing new here. Are you transforming swamps into deserts? That´s a bit weird. Isn´t it?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

Gestionale tedesco che riesce ad amalgamare, in modo assolutamente efficace, una serie di meccaniche note, come la classica espansione territoriale, con altre decisamente originali. Molte le modalità per fare punti, ma si può riuscire - dedicandogli un po' di tempo ed un certo impegno - a tener tutte le variabili, perlomeno le proprie, abbastanza sotto controllo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So, the new #2 in all its glory.  "Gamer's game," "hardcore Euro," etc. etc.  Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed playing Terra Mystica, and I would gladly play it again.  There's some interesting wrinkles to the gameplay (I was a little skeptical about the whole "cycling power" thing, which seemed a little contrived, but it does provide a nice safety valve to accomplish things you really need to get done while not being too much of a gimme) and those wooden pieces do feel oh-so-nice.  But my main issue with Terra Mystica is the same issue I had with Tzolk'in (the other new hotness from 2012)...what exactly is it that I'm doing here?  The random point generators for each round, from which derives the majority of the "replayability," are just that - point generators.  You get points for doing such-and-such because...that's what the tile says.  It's surprising to me that in a game about expanding your civilization, buildings themselves have no inherent value (apart from getting a lot of them connected, but the 1st-2nd-3rd point values make the delta for that awfully small).  It becomes another puzzle game (granted, a very good one), which is fine if that's your thing but just isn't very high up on my preferences.  

One final note: this game gets major demerits for the "cult track" (another aspect it shares with Tzolk'in), which is just incredibly lazy game design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It may provide very satisfying decisions, but which is building on a very cumbersome and abstract rule-set.

TM becomes a too mathematical puzzle with huge downtime that squeezes out the potential fun. It's not bad, but just not a game I will enjoy. The flaws prevent me from exploring the fun provided.

It's not bad to have one as a collection, but it is not going to hit table frequently enough to justify the price.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interaction: 5 out of 10 (perceived)
Theoretically, there is a good deal of (indirect) play interaction. Players compete for the actions to be purchased with magic. Players try to control the area and limit expansion opportunities of each other, to be highest on cult tracks, and to have the biggest connected area at the end of the game.

So Terra Mystica is more interactive than many heavy eurogames. Most of the interaction is indirect. Thus, king-making is mostly avoided. The downside is that players silently ponder over their moves. At least in our rounds there was hardly any communication going on. After all the game doesn’t feel very interactive.

Fun: 6 out of 10
The challenge to find the optimal moves is fun. The missing direct interaction and the weak thematic implementation prevent the game from being more fun, though. Bonus tiles are put randomly so each game is a bit different. On the other hand it makes the game feel like maximization of points. For instance is the last one or two rounds, it can be better not to build any building if there is no bonus tile that awards points for doing so becauses also give a few points at the end of the game. Most of the time players do their math to check which combination of building they can afford to buy with their current resources. Personally I prefer to play the non-official AI implementation online. It takes much less time and I can try out some weaker factions so I really need to give my best to beat the AI.

Replayability: 10 out of 10
The game mostly uses common mechanics. The most innovative mechanic are the magic balls. It has little impact on the game experience, though.

The replayability is extremely high, with about 14 differenct factions and random bonus tile setups no two games are the same. The factions are not really balanced. Some factions are considerably stronger than others. Of course this can also be quite handy as weaker or less experienced players can get a handicap by getting a strong faction. Here you can find detailed stats about how often which faction wins: terra.snellmann.net/stats/

In the long-term I hope that the factions will be balanced by adjusting the amount of resources or power that they get in the beginning of a game. Alternatively, there could be an auction with power for the factions.

RATING: 6
Comments:

Still not sure about this one. I enjoy playing it, but it is both punitive and pretty opaque. I also can't shake the feeling that it top loads far too much of the relevant decisions into the opening of the game. If you do badly on picking a race, picking a starting location, or just have someone who counter-picks either of those against you, you will have a rough time.

I'm considering an attempt at playing the game with some sort of auction for races, or possibly a swap rule after opening race choice and city placement. I'd like to think it through a bit and then try out different options. Right now, I'm still okay with playing it, but I'm not the biggest fan.

No sleeves required.

RATING: N/A

Sonny(Chinese)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A city building game through the mechanic of variable character abilities. The game provides various tactics and lots of fun by planning city building. The aspect of game is dynamically diversified by the power of mutiple tribal characters. Every tribe has unique skills or privileges. Enjoyment of the game is originated from maximizing tribal strength. Like a double edged sword, however, it provokes the breakdown of game balance. Each races has its best tactics. Racial advantages are usually achieved by the best tactics and the ideal moves or choices. Because of the ideal moves for each races, players always pursuit the optimum strategy. Once played every tribal characters, the game is changed very tedious. Players repeat the suitable tactic methods again and again by which tribe the players choose. A so-called tactical standardization happens very often. This is one of the most serious problems on Terra Mystica. Except the tribal tactical standardization problem, Terra Mystica is still a very nice strategy game. It provides a lot of fun for those players who didn't find the optimum moves yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You need more than 2 players for this game to come alive. Would not recommend to teach others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
[b]2 Player Review:[/b] 

While the size of the map may indicate it would hold a lot more strategic depth with more players, it does play splendidly with 2. I have found myself enjoying the game more and more as I realize the massive difference a chosen race has on the game-play. The tactical nature of how you time your racial traits versus the strategical need for geographically supremacy blends to make a very tight and deep experience. 

[b]Pros:[/b]

- A deep brain-burn in around an hour for 2 players.
- While the variables for each race may seem small, they have a huge impact on the game-play.
- A massive amount of replay that you want to come back and experience, as every game is a new puzzle to solve.

[b]Cons:[/b]

- 5 to 10 minute setup time, even with Plano boxes. 
- You often find yourself one resource away from a great move which may infuriate some.

[b]2015 Rating:[/b] 9.60 [b]Rank:[/b] 8 [b]Plays:[/b] 6
[b]2014 Rating:[/b] 9.25 [b]Rank:[/b] - [b]Plays:[/b] 13
[b]2013 Rating:[/b] 9.5 [b]Rank:[/b] - [b]Plays:[/b] 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I tried to avoid the hype, but ultimately gave in and gave Terra Mystica a shot. And I'm hugely glad I did.

Outstanding Euro game that manages quite a bit of interactivity between players, without introducing a lot of screwage. Since moves typically take a turn or two to set up, it's pretty easy to string short term plans together and avoid their disruption. Long term strategy, however, takes work (the good kind).

Initial race selection perhaps figures a bit too strongly in the end result, but otherwise, this is good stuff.

RATING: 9.2
Bokkensprong Novelty Night 20/09/13, met Joris, Jelle Raes (Chiro), Sander (rechten), Gunther (Zwijndrecht) en ik (gewonnen met Heksen, 86? punten). Spelregels waren zware dobber; spel is zwaar maar echt tof.
Spel in zes ronden; elke ronde leveren specifieke acties extra punten op. Elke speler speelt met een volk (Heksen, halflingen, reuzen, meerminnen,...), bouwt zeshoekige landtegels om naar zijn eigen habitat (vb. bos voor heksen), en bouwt er vervolgens gebouwen op (huizen, handelshuizen,... tempel, fort). Buren kunnen meeprofiteren via paarse acties (die mogelijk wel punten kosten; zijn dat meestal zeker wel waard). Geld, arbeiders en priesters zijn nodig om landtegels "om te spitten" of gebouwen te bouwen. Grote steden (minstens 4 gebouwen, 7 punten waarde) leveren sleutels op (=punten, toegang tot hoogste tempelplaatsen, en extra voordeel).
Spel wordt beter na meerdere keren spelen.

Spel 2015, 44 EUR, Sinterklaas 2015 voor Ward

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Really solid game, the races all feel distinct and for the most part really powerful, and there's really a high degree of planning that comes in since the round scoring tiles and the round bonus tiles are all chosen at the beginning of the game and will have a huge impact on how the game develops. And the power system is really clever, knowing how much it makes sense to burn to get to a quick cycle time but without wasting any power generation is important. And of course the interaction is very important, you're really incentivised to build near each other to leach power and to make trading houses cheaper, but you also want to have room to grow and expand since the more buildings you have on the board the more income you get and the better you'll do on the end game largest territory scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Excellent eurogame with the add-on of being able of pick a different way to play (races) in each game.

Things I like:

- No luck, no hidden information. You can (and you should if you want to win) think your strategy from the very set-up, including your race choice.
- 14 different races allow for different ways to play the game. 
- Variable set-up (replayability)
- Power mechanism is great 
- No screwing interaction, but you should be aware of what other players want to do (and which race they are)

Things I don't like:

- My main gaming-friends don't like it as much as I do

RATING: 9
A new favorite!  Each  player has a different fantasy race with different abilities.  Each one is trying to gain maximal points by obtaining resources (workers, money, priests) and using them to build and upgrade buildings, terraform terrain to their home type to allow for buildings, and progression on the elemental cult tracks.  Every turn is full of agonizing wonderful choices and alternate strategies.  You really have to watch what everyone is doing.  Not much downtime as each player take an action at a time.  At the same time, a relatively short game with only six turns.  During income phase, I find it helpful to place a marker on each income source as I use it, to make sure I don't get confused about what income I've already taken in.  I think some of the races are better than others so the race bonuses were not as well balanced but perhaps I just think so because I haven't played enough.  The components are really nice.  The only downside is that it is relatively expensive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Terra Mystica features many familiar Euro game mechanics with a few small twists. It manages great replayability thanks to a variety of races with unique powers. Unfortunately, this is a long game that starts full of possibility but quickly becomes less interesting as strategic options often decrease as the game continues. This not only makes it easy to fall out of contention before game's end, but it also makes the experience feel less epic than other games of its duration and depth. It's a solid game, but not one that warrants the time to play and master.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
== Long Version

Heavy euro VP race with an opaque mesh of currencies and variable player powers. Gold, workers, priests, and power all act as currencies that are frequently exchanged and spent as players attempt to grow their towns across the map. A key mechanism here is that each player will only be able to place new buildings on their unique type of land, but there is the ability to transform land which morphs the board to your favor. 

The gameplay is heavily slanted toward optimization and efficiency. There is a bit of leeching off of others, and chances to cut people off on the board, but direct confrontation is absent. There is no way to destroy anything that another player has already built. Many points are scored during the game, with their relative efficiency changing each turn. However, once the board is set up there is zero randomness involved, so players may study the current setup before beginning to play.

It's a huge puzzle in the best sense of that term for euro games. Given an initial board setup, there are 14 factions to choose from. Each will perform differently for a given order of in-game scoring efficiencies and available bonuses. Choose wisely and react to your opponents' choices.

Endgame scoring revolves around two major sources:

1. "Longest road" -- It's not called that, but that's really what you're doing. It's big tub of points here.

2. Four tracks representing elemental cults which act as horse races for players to jockey on over the course of the game. You score nothing on these tracks during the game, but you can see where everyone is, what points they will be scoring at the end, and then choose to spend your resources accordingly.


Gameplay could drag with super-AP-prone players, but the turns *should* be short. The individual actions are small and self-contained, so the action should move around the table quickly. The problem for someone suffering from AP is that there's a level of fog over the game where it's probably impossible to calculate exactly what you should be doing, but it seems like you can, so people are going to try. The fog comes from not knowing what bonuses other players will snag from your or what lands they are planning to transform. Again, there's no direct conflict, but these decisions can change your calculations dramatically. Once the game is underway, it's mostly tactical. Your overriding strategy stems from your faction choice and initial placements and isn't going to change much without grinding your economy to a halt.

There's definitely a snowball engine here, but it's not of the crazy run-away variety. Upgrades to buildings are tempered by the removal of the ability that the old building was provided. Your economy (should) improve over time, but it's gradual.



== Short Version

I definitely like this game. Economic snowballs, variable player techs, efficiency optimization, and a light fantasy theme are right up my alley. The combination of these is well done. The rules are fairly well written, and despite the moderate volume of rules it's not hard at all to memorize everything. With very few exceptions everything works as you'd expect and is internally consistent. 

I buy very few new titles each year, preferring older games mainly. I've also not been excited about many newer heavy euros in years. I have no buyers remorse at all with TM. This is a solid addition to the collection.

RATING: 7
Very nice. Well designed, very playable, good quality components.

It's a bit dry and impersonal, in my opinion. It seems that there's a tradeoff in game design: You can forego all that flavor text that needs to be translated and use symbols only (Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy), but you end up with a game that lacks some flavor. Or use lots of text to add flavor (Arkham Horror, Magic the Gathering), but then you need to have all that text translated.
