RATING: 3
"Busy work" euro with many ways to score points: Get A to get B to get C and get D. Maybe next turn, you do B, C, D to get...F. Maybe you get E on the next turn. Monotonous with no life to it. Theme seemed pointless. Only conflict with other players is on the scoring side board, terraforming (fight for hexes to build on) and racing for the on board power bonuses. None of which are meaningful if you are looking for competitive play. Yet, I don't see this game as being a solitaire min-maxer type of thing, either.

The game is way too long and the last 10 minutes devolved into priest jockeying on the side board. Every player seemed to have or get 2-4 priests in the final round. Putting a priest on a track was countered by someone else making the same move to keep pace with you or the others. At the end of it all, there was no significant change on the leader board. It was an exercise in futility in trying to guess and outguess the other players on where you were going to place your priests. 

The only thing "Mystical" about this game is the fact that so many people are enthralled with this and it is a top 10 game on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
2013-06-04

Initial Rating: 7.0 (June 2013)

As I have heard a lot of good things about Terra Mystica, I was expecting a great GREAT game but I was a bit disappointed :S. Terra Mystica is a good game, but as I had huge expectations I didn’t enjoy my first game very much. Still the jury is still out on this one.

On the good side, Terra Mystica is a medium-heavy gamer´s game with a very low luck factor, the game components are great and the races seem to be very balanced. The game is pretty meaty and offers a lot to think about, you have many options and CAN plan long term as the bonus tiles and all VP generators are known to all since the beginning of the game. It has many rules but they are simple enough and straightforward, however the gameplay is very deep and complex with lots of meaningful/hard decisions. The game components are very nice too and the art is adequate. Pure Euro, with a steep learning curve.

On the bad side, the down time can be excessive with 5 players, I would like to play with 4 players or less. Also I don’t feel any theme when I play Terra Mystica. 

This definitively has the potential to go up in my personal ratings, for now I want to play again soon (but never again with 5 players). I still have a lot to explore in the world of Terra Mystica.

Current Rating: 7.0

2014-03-31

Terra Mystica has won me over. It is a GREAT game indeed and I always want to play it. Fortunately I found a regular game group for it as many friends dislike it (too dry they say). I will buy it soon.

I love the Chaos Magicians, I feel they are very powerful. The player who play the Engineers always loses the game :devil: they are hard to play well. I have many more races to explore. 

Current Rating: 8.0

2016-02-21

After many more plays, my desire to play Terra Mystica has taken a plunge. I’m not sure why because the game still delivers. Due to this I’m downgrading its rating.

I still haven’t bought it, but it is on my list of “must have”. The reason I haven’t bought it, is that many friends have it, so I always can play it if the mood strikes.

In my last game, we played only with two players and it was very fun and fast. When you play this way, the game´s strategy changes radically, a very positive thing in my book.
 
Current Rating: 7.5

RATING: 4
The quote from our game that sums up the whole thing..."as long as you aren't mean to anyone".  Typical passive-aggressive, non-interactive drek.  Scoring is a point-salad race but supposed "innovative" aspects are dull and insipid.  Played once. Never again.

My score reflects the design of the game not my willingness to play again.  I would much rather talk and drink a beer while others play than play it again myself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of best out there.  Creative resource, city building, and tableau management game. Lots to think about and the variable powers of each race is really where the game shines. Who doesn't want to play with them all and try out different special powers. This is a game I always come back to want to take down from the shelf. As for cons - the power token system is a bit fiddly and not thematic, and for a 2 player game to be fun some material modifications must be made to the end game scoring and god tracks. However, these are minor criticism for a top-notch game.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
MM Ding and Dent $40
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So far Terra Mystica is my favorite game of the 2012 Essen releases.

Terra Mystica is highly replayable due to its 14 different factions, not to mention the different combinations of favor cards and round bonuses that can occur.  What differentiates Terra Mystica from other such combinatorically replayable games (like Agricola for example) is that the most significant difference, the faction identity, imposes asymmetry on the players.  Sometimes these faction-specific abilities are radically asymmetric and require widely divergent strategies of the players.  Each faction has its own unique flavor which minimally makes me want to play the game 14 times.

My lone concern about Terra Mystica, and the single item holding it back from a 10 rating for the moment, is whether I'll eventually get tired of all the VP-grubbing.  To its credit Terra Mystica presents a highly engaging framework for its pointmongering, and very interesting point-for-benefit tradeoffs.  Under the hood though, it's still a game of incremental VP gains with large majority bonuses at the end - not very dissimilar in structure to many Eurogames in existence already.

Still, Terra Mystica is highly interactive (if often indirectly so) and yet provides significant individual control over civilization direction.  This is what others might call a "multiplayer solitaire" component but I want to avoid the pejorative as I don't mind non-interactive segments of a game.

I've been thinking about this game constantly since my last play, can't wait for a US release, and wish I'd had the foresight to import from Europe.

12/27/2012:  PBF is helping me really get this game.  I may need to raise it to 10 now that I'm understanding it a little better.

2/3/2013:  This is a 10.  While not necessarily "perfect" it has so many aspects I love about games - variable and asymmetric player powers, a tight snowball-ish engine, and brutal turf fights.  Once I hit 20 plays or so, I can see myself getting bored with the main victory tracks (+VP for trading posts, +VP for dwellings, etc) but the game as a whole probably has at least 30 plays before I'll want to move on.  That puts it in with games like Le Havre and Scepter of Zavandor among my 10s.

2/21/2013: I've been involved in a few really vicious first-turn turf fights.  Even though they're not necessarily crippling I have an emotional reaction to them.  I don't know where my rating will end up.  I'm going to play a few more times to find out.

4/4/2013: Back up to 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Purchased January 2016. I was finally able to play for the first time, after having reading and studying the rulebook, as well as watching a few YouTube playthrough videos; on January 3, 2017.
This is the single most game which I would love to play a lot more than I do. It took me long enough to be able to get it on the table to play it for the first time, although I had "test played" it myself.
In addition to my gaming group being composed of more lighter, Ameritrashey type of gamers as opposed to Eurogamers, I believe the complexity of all the little rules in this game contributes to it being seen as very intimidating.
However, if you can learn and get past (or reminded about, if need be) how to play the game, I find the actual gameplay to actually be simple and elegant. In addition, the game is so deep, there is so much to think about.
By the way, for those that were wondering the history of how I came aware of this game: I had purchased this game was because I had looked at the box and I had noticed that it had a board of colored hexes, as well as wooded pieces which looked identical to Catan. So I had actually originally bought the game on a whim that it was "Catan on steroids". As I have mentioned earlier, I have since looked into how to play the game.
I have not even scratched the surface with this game. It has such high replay value due to the 14 (+6 with the Fire & Ice expansion, which I have yet to acquire) different factions which all have different special abilities and therefore require different strategies, especially since which of the other factions are in the game could influence your strategy. For example, in a 3-player game, if one is playing the Witches (Forest/Green terrain), but the other players are playing the Swarmlings (Lake/Blue terrain) and the Engineers (Mountains/Grey terrain); then the player who is playing the Witches will want to terraform either of these terrains, not only because it would cost the Witches player less, as both of these terrains are only 1 spade away, but in addition, these are the terrains of both of the Witches player's competitors. Therefore, if the Witches player terraforms and builds on these spaces, he/she would be taking away expansion spaces from the competitors, which may possibly block them in.
That is just one aspect of this awesome game. You are essentially building your engine in order to use your resources in the most efficient manner possible to generate victory points (so unlike in Catan where economy = Victory points, that is not necessarily the case in this game). In the beginning of the game, resources are tight, so you will need the help of other aids, notably the bonus tiles, in order to supplement your income; and you may have to pass earlier during the first few rounds than you would like (that is, until you become more experienced with the game). However, hopefully you can eventually start accumulating sufficient resources.
Another thing which I like about this game is that it is a pure strategy game. You control every decision you make in this game (aside from the choices which your opponents may make which end up affecting you: for example, if one of your opponents terraforms and builds on a space you were going to build on; or if an opponent takes the power action you were planning on taking before you). You actually have to develop a strategy. However, the game does guide you on how to receive bonus victory points: the bonus tiles, some of the favor tiles, etc.)
I cannot wait until the next time I am able to play this again. Hopefully, I can convince some at my gaming club to at least give the game a try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Really like the shared map and building contention between players.  There's a neat Small World element where each race can have a significant impact on your strategy.

Building different buildings that provide resources and tweaking your play with Favor tiles or power actions is a nice wrinkle.

RATING: 8
It definitely takes experience in this game to do well. I definitely would be interested in playing it again soon; it is deserving of multiple plays to give the game a chance to shine!

After another play, I can definitely see the appeal of the game. The weird thing about this one to me is the ways that the points are awarded (perhaps the thematic disconnect is my main beef with the game). Why should I get points for digging in round 4 but not in other rounds? Other games have this mechanism as well (the Crown's Requests in Madeira for example), but I find the thematic reason for those to be a bit more logical.

More plays = more love. Such a great game!

RATING: 7.75
Complicated set up and instructions for what turns out to be a fairly simple and fluid play once it gets going. Victory points are awarded based on builds and final placement, but the manner in which you get to those final ones has to be determined early because there's only six rounds -- and if you don't get a quick launch, you're going to have a struggle to catch up later.

PLUS: variety of roles to approach the game, strategy-based
MINUS: rulebook isn't great, awards planning ahead over responsive strategy

RATING: 5.5
Very solid Euro.  Not exciting but interesting enough to happily come back to again.  If you like your euro games then you should like this.  No great complaints except that the whole 'priest' tracks are really lame - its as if the developer decided that the game did not have enough 'agonising decisions' or 'multiple paths to victory' and so added these tracks which serve no real purpose.  Not too heavy but it is a little long.  Its a good design, well developed.  In fact, perhaps too well developed?  That's a weird thing to say, but sometimes little quirky things in games really make the difference.  This one really has had all the wrinkles ironed out.  Some would say its had its soul ironed out, but that is too strong.  It reminds me a lot of a combination of Eclipse and Kingdom Builder, but that may just be the graphic design.  Update: downtime is horrific. Just boredom for three hours. The priest tracks are really lame design.

RATING: 10
This is the game that scratches every itch for me in a board game at this moment. It gives you all the best components of a great game: variable races and powers, civ expansion, tech upgrades, multiple paths to victory, and vast replayability. It's like a melting pot of settlers, eclipse and probably other games that i just can't think of right now. Heavy, elegant mechanics, brain-burning at times but just the right amount to provide a satisfying experience.

RATING: 7.5

I think the advanced setup adds variety, but can see the potential problem that you might be alone without a neighbor. So far each race seems fairly balanced which is an impressive feat. This is one of my favorite games of all time.

RATING: 8.5
This gives players lots of room for creativity and tension.  Multiple forms of "currency" to manage: money, workers, power, and multiple competing places to apply them.  The game has a good arc as one moves from just getting a toehold on expansion, to clawing out to new areas and coalescing around towns.  Add to this variable incentives to do certain things at certain times - which may or may not mesh with what you WANTED to do, creates many opportunities for intriguing play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
20+ plays.

Incredible variety and asymmetry.  Different factions (some requiring different skill levels to play well) and bonus tiles lead to quick ramp to enjoyment (~2 games) but a ton of content to explore.

As would be expected, balance is not perfect (3-6 factions form a clear top tier, a few should only be selected in specific scenarios, and a few are significant underdogs).  This can be mitigated by auctions/handicaps, and making even most of the factions competitive is a feat.

The game is a brain-bender, a beauty to look at, and a lot of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Terra Mystica is one of these games where you think and discuss about the game afterwards which is a promising sign. There are a few strategic musts depending on the race (e.g. getting the giant / nomad fortress asap)  but the tactics to get there and accompanying targets can differ. There are plenty possibilities each turn which is the strength of the game but contains the danger of serious AP. The 100 minutes mentioned on BGG can easily be doubled on first play with a higher player number. Player interaction is present in the indirect form of claiming something first which will match the taste of eurogamers. It's a heavy eurogame which might have appeal to other gamers as well for its depth and flavour of the different races.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
lånat av Pontus
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best game there is. The races add the theme to the game, and the mechanics have the best balance between helping out and blocking other players. The interaction is so nuanced. The pieces are amazing. The only thing that I could see them doing to increase the theme immersion is giving a name to each round bonus tile. I think that is where people feel that the game lacks theme. In my opinion it's just as thematic as Caverna.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Okay game, but far too much of the game is in the planning / placement and too little is in the rest of the game. Resources are exceptionally tight (thus requiring an early plan), and never ramp up. I want this to be an empire building game, but it isn't -- a few resources here and there which need to be carefully managed. Probably a great game for people who enjoy this style of game, but not my taste.

RATING: 10
Pros - Infinitely replayable.  Sets the standard for widely asymmetrical factions while remaining incredibly balanced.  Every decision is important but options restricted by resource availability to limit AP.  Currently plays in 1 hour or less for 2-3 experienced players in my group.

Cons - The theme is practically nonexistent.  Steep learning curve where it is nearly impossible for a new player to beat an experienced one.  Adds a tactical element at 2-3 players that I enjoy but some others do not.

Conclusion - Outstanding.  I've played this 100+ times and this would still be my "one game on a desert island."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A resource conversion cube pusher, but not at all your standard one. A very strong spatial component (with blocking as interaction) and strongly assymetric player positions from start to finish due to each player having different special powers and different terrain preferences.

I just love the asymmetric races. Played with 5, which felt just right, so can see how 6 might feel a bit cramped. First game felt like it went rather fast (under 2 hours with 5 newbies). I'd worry about the turn order mechanism, except that at least in this case the turn order didn't feel like it played a role all that often.

Note: this game has a lot of special powers and production bonuses that are clearly marked on the components, but that are also easy to forget. Luckily if you forget to use a special, you'll basically just be harming yourself.

RATING: 9
A game, in which you want to do more, than it is possible. There is never enough time for everything. Another interesting mechanics is about grabbing land - you need to change it to the terrain, required by your race. However each race has its own required terrain and the price of change differs by race... There is many different rules, however player board presents them quite concisely and clearly. A good game of good quality.

RATING: 7
Rules might feel a bit overwhelming, but that's because of one of the weakest game rule editing performances of 2012. The start of the game might also feel a bit overwhelming, but you soon grasp what you can do and the amount of possibilities is actually not that wide. There seems to be a high level of replayability and lots of different ways to aim for the victory. Mechanisms are interesting and mix well together, the spoons being possibly the only awkwardish concept. Especially fascinating is the constant need to be close to other players while at the same time trying to create your own space to grow. Feels a bit like a Feldian game, because points are coming from many directions all the time. Could drag towards the end.

RATING: 8

Some minor quibbles: I wish the various races were more evenly powered -- clearly, there are some that are much better than others (which is unfortunate). The theme of the game is so thin that it approaches Knizia-levels of theme thinness.

Overall a great game: tense, fun, satisfying. I've played all player counts and 3-4 is where it's at.

RATING: 10
I love Terra Mystica, I love love love it. Out of all the games I own, I feel that it provides the most room for growth as a player—every round of Terra Mystica is an education in what works and what doesn't, in what could work with a bit more planning. It's a beautifully crafted set of mechanics with a beautiful board and wonderful tactility.

I have no real complaints, but if you pressed me on it, I would say that the bits of "lore" or "story" or "background" (using those terms loosely) in the manual are not terribly interesting, though there is an amusing joke about a certain race's ability to blend into their surroundings being used both when foes are present and when relatives are visiting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
When Terra Mystica was released I wasn't really interested in it since it's as Euro as it gets.

Several months later I had begun to appreciate Eurogames again, tried it and loved it.

It comes in a big box, filled to the lid with replay value. This game has darted up the ranks over the last to years for very good reasons.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Terra Mystica throws at you five currencies, one set of faction-specific powers and bonuses per player, one set of city upgrade bonuses, one set of city completion bonuses, one set of composite round bonuses, one set of composite role bonuses, one set of standard actions, one set of limited access resource conversions, two types of efficiency upgrade investments, an income engine with spatial constraints, a generic resource conversion scheme, and five long-term majority goals. This barrage of gauges and options offers a lot to claim your attention but also feels constraining given the tactical goals of matching resource acquisition to expenditure in order to clear efficiency thresholds and collect as many conditional bonuses as possible. The game suffers to some degree from "count backwards from the end" syndrome, where you will be highly rewarded for taking the time to make sure you won't be missing 1 doodah as you mean to close a high-scoring chain of actions at the end of a turn or, critically, at the end of the game.

Random selections of bonuses and factions provide variation, but also leave you wondering what a "vanilla" game in mechanical terms would be like. As for flavour, there's some of it in the faction presentation and abilities, but overall the proceedings remain quite abstract and faceless. As an example, there is no attempt to explain the "roles" in flavour terms; they're just another layer in the resource acquisition and conversion machinery. The elemental cults give you points, magic and random bonuses, nobody knows why. Anyone who cares to ask becomes the first sacrifice.

(Note: VPs, not spades, are the fifth currency. Spades are actions.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
✅ language-independent game components
PL/CZ
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A current favorite and a game that lodges itself into my mind long after I put it away.  For a game with a lot of initial complexity and rules overhead, it plays remarkably smoothly once you're over that initial hurdle.  It can seem like a puzzle when you look at the initial board state and try and figure out the best faction to choose.  And although that's obviously a big part of the strategy, the best laid plans often go by the wayside once you get around to, you know, actually playing the game and interacting with your opponents.

Ah, there's that word, "interaction."  Even without any direct attacking, I find this game to be extremely interactive.  The fundamental and brilliant strategic crux of the game is that you need territory to expand, but you need to build next to your opponents so that you get building discounts (for trading posts) and resources (power income).  There are also 6 actions that can only be taken once per round first come first served.  There is the significant spatial element with jockeying over terrain types and buildings.  And finally there are the endgame scoring bonuses with players competing over largest connected territory and advancement on the cult tracks.

While the game is certainly not dripping with theme, it's there if you wanna look for it.  The faction-specific powers and abilities are all mainly thematic.  Religious buildings give you priests, which you can send to the cult tracks to increase your religious standing, etc.

Now with 14 different factions, there is no way that all of them are or even could be perfectly balanced.  But I see that as a trade off between balance and depth/replayability.  And boy is there a lot of depth and replayability.  There are people who practically play this as a lifestyle game.  That being said, given the rules overhead, and huge amount of asymmetry in the various factions, this may not be the best game for you if you'll only play it 4 or 5 times a year (or total).  But for those willing to sink their teeth in, and fans of heavy euro games in general, you are in for a treat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I would play again, but I won't seek it out, and I don't think I'll buy it.

RATING: 6

2017-09-11 - 7->6 - I don't miss this game at all. I could play it, but I can list five to ten medium, medium-heavy euros I prefer. And those variable powers rather force you to play in certain way than give you more opportunities.

RATING: 9
Really enjoy this at 3-4 players, was a bit slow at 5 but very tight (haven't tried 2 player yet). Actually surprisingly easy to teach because so much of the information is provided by the player board. Gameplay even with new players is pretty smooth after a couple of turns. I've introduced this successfully to player who always play Catan and they took to the game really quickly.

Only some people in my group enjoy this game so it doesn't hit the table too much, but when it does I really appreciate the tightness of the play and crucial decisions every turn. It's satisfying when you can pull off a big scoring combinations while scraping by with just enough resources. It's always so tight with resources that waiting for someone to give up the round bonus tile you need can be excruciating. Every decision matters and makes the game very tough and enjoyable.

RATING: 8.52
Fantastic economic euro. Amazing depth of strategy without much AP. Beloved mechanics from other games (Puerto Rico, Go, Eclipse, Settlers) intertwine with new ideas to create a clockwork of head-scratching fun in a manageable play time. Lots of replayability through 14 different factions. Recommended for euro-lovers.

RATING: 9
Played my first game of this in 2017 and at time of first playing, this game is 5 years old which in the gaming industry is quite old, but it still feels fresh and new and its exactly what I feel a euro game should be. I play this two player with my wife with both players controlling two characters and then at final scoring only our lowest character counts, it forces you to balance the two players and not just piggy back of the one character and then sink the other. For our money it works absolutely amazing as a two player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is fantastic. My girlfriend and I both enjoy it. The almost complete lack of luck is great. Too many games have high luck, leaving little room for the players' skill to come into play. 

Unfortunately, due to there only being one side to the world map, this game loses a few points. Another map on the reverse side would have been nice, but instead it's just recycled art from the box/player boards. Dumb. 

My suggestion for the forthcoming expansion--add another map. Or try to providing alternate layouts in the rulebook--there are more than enough terrain tiles to reinvent the map--so play test some layouts and make them available. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I haven't even played this yet, but I'm so excited after reading the rules and watching some videos that I want to rate it preemptively.  I can see this one going to 10 if it's as fun and engaging as I think it'll be.

10-07-2013 - I got kind of terra mystica'd out.  It's a good game, but not what I expect it to be, and it's hard enjoying it immensely for what it actually is.  At least for now, maybe that'll change.  Down to a 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the best heavy Euro out there, period. It is replayable, but there is zero luck. The game is tight, you never feel like you can do all the things you need to ensure a victory. Every action seems like it is taking a step back and two steps forward, but everything is clearly laid out and the decisions are very dynamic. There isn't much direct interaction, but plenty of indirect interaction. What parts of the map you choose to let other players have can and will have an effect on the final score. The fantasy really comes across, the map is clear. Just wish it was easier to get to the table!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Well I finally acquired terra mystica and it quickly found its way to the table.

I knew there were different races. So I thought this would involve fighting. too few games with direct conflict. 
So I thought great... Well was I mistaken. this game is an engine building game (with some sort of worker placement as some actions can only be executed once in a round)

It played much quicker than I thought it would. And unlike Kohle and Kolonie that also has a few rounds of play we all had the feeling that we could accomplish something.

Another thing that is pretty amazing is that the game doesn't really take so long.
Awesome design!

Edit : second play took much longer because of my deliberate planning. It worked since I scored 111 points. Really like the decisions and the importance of these.
The power bowls make it stand out.
However despite the races it is dry as hell. I have no problem with that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
High expectations transformed to excitement after the first couple of plays of TM. Every play after that and I'm realizing that it's not as great for me as it seemed to be. It's not that I dislike it; I would gladly play it when brought to the table, however I would rather spend my time playing my other heavies.

The things I like about the game are a lot. Here's what I don't like much: 
-It's a struggle to get your economy going, and despite the game's length it ends right when I feel like I could start expanding more freely. Yet it does feel that it would drag for too long if it had extra turns
-Pasted on theme
-AP. Serious AP
-Setup time and rule explanation time

RATING: 6.5
Complex, no random elements whatsoever, challenging.  This is a monster of a worker placement game.  Every step forward seems to put you two steps back, and when you fail to win, there is no random element to blame it on.  While I initially enjoyed the depth of play, the frustrating parts of game play are more noticeable to me now.  One never has enough resources to do what one wants to do.  This alone wouldn't be so bad, but when it's your fellow players who are depriving you of the necessary resources, it makes for a tense, head-to-head several hours of gameplay.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lots of optimizing and micromanagement happening on a Eclipse-esque player board, building (for more income), land grabbing and blocking on the map. Some races are a lot trickier to play than others, and depending on what others are in the game, runaway leader/-loser situations are bound to happen, so I see the potential of it getting frustrating sometimes in a 2 hour game. Also the combination of race and the round bonuses can dictate your strategy somewhat. They can decide the outcome to some extent sometimes as well. But I still have this feeling that it probably offers more with repeated plays, need to play some more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
It didn't quite live up to my expectations. It's a good dry euro, but it didn't leave me wanting more. I'm just not a big fan of games where you constantly have to search for weird ways to get basic resources in order to get anything done. Still, I had a good time playing this and I certainly understand why it's highly rated. Also, the artwork is good and there are lots of quality components, such as thick player boards. 
NB! Rating based on 2 player game but according to BGG many people don't recommend this as a 2 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have played this a few times now but only 2 player. A very nice fantast themed resource management game where it is easy to step off course or be tempted to do the wrong action. There is plenty to do and to keep an eye on and Victory points are not always that easy to come by. It also works as a solitaire puzzle (this is my opinion not the publishers), but do not expect to be overly thrilled playing solo, its strength is in multiplayer mode. Sadly the rules let the game down a bit, the 15 pages of rule queries on this site alone indicates the lack of clarity and confusion caused by what at first appears to be a comprehensive rule book. That is not to say they are badly written it is more a matter of some parts are open for misinterpretation.
The game works smoothly with several strands running through it to make it engaging with plenty to think about, I highly recommend this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Heavy strategy game. AP can be a problem. Long.

RATING: 7

With Fire and Ice expansion.

RATING: N/A
Terra Mystica is a game with very little luck that rewards strategic planning. Each player governs one of the 14 groups. With subtlety and craft, the player must attempt to rule as great an area as possible and to develop that group's skills. There are also four religious cults in which you can progress. To do all that, each group has special skills and abilities.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent euro game involving terraforming and unique powers to each of the 14 possible races making each game a bit unique.  The game reminds me a bit of Hansa Teutonica in that one clears off his/her board and builds on a map.  What is cleared off the board will score the income whether it be priests, money, workers, or special knowledge tile, etc.  Each race can only build on one type of ground and there is some benefit to building adjacent to each other to leach off power.  However, this can also lead to conflict over common lands both can terraform cheaply.  Power is another special currency in the game which allows you to take additional special actions.  I'm not a fan of the box shape/size, but have no other complaints.  There is no direct player competition and you cannot remove other players from their spaces or destroy their buildings.  There is sometimes tight competition for certain lands as mentioned earlier.  

I do think this game is best with 4-5 players due to the competition over hexes that results.  Working to complete the largest clump of buildings proves more challenging and planning too far ahead can prove more difficult since you don't know if the hex you want to terraform will still be available.  Playing with 2 or 3 would be too wide open in most cases for my preferences since you could likely plan everything out well ahead of time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Kauf 10/2015 43,-

RATING: 3
[u]Comments:[/u]
So this is a game. A game made up of mechanics and a setting that have absolutely nothing to do with each other other than the fact that one mechanic can influence the other. Its just a hodge-podge of mechanics all thrown into a blender to see what came out at the other end. It is functional, and is a game, but it surely wasn't anything remotely close to be fun for me. This is the poster child for the dying breed of Euro style point salad games that makes absolutely no sense other than to themselves. Components are okay, but the graphic design is horrendous. If I never play this game again I will be happy. Agricola is even better than this fun murdering game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I started getting a feel for the game towards the end of the first game.

I like the quick individual actions.

Another euro: I see this game as yet another set of cogwheels (you turn the "action" wheel, you get something, you get the cog of this something along with another cog, you get something else, etc.—very different from, say, Magic: the Gathering). Not a bad one, but just another one, in a different style.

I am not a big fan of the fact that there are many ways to make points that it seems to be fine to just grab them anywhere as the opportunity arises: I don't feel the need to have a consistent strategy (something that Race for the Galaxy gives me), I mostly make efficient local choices. So, despite the fact that there is no obvious single strategy (so many moving pieces, so many little opportunities!), it feels like the choices are kind of always the same: many tactics, but kind of always the same. The path to victory seems more like a brownian motion: just push in the best direction for you, from about the samey set of options. Sure, no two paths will be the same, but choices look locally very similar each time.

I was relatively confused by the power bowls mechanic: I understood the rules, but did not especially enjoy playing with them.

I just decided to try to be quite efficient in anything I was doing: one gets points for many different things (goals, cults, and many little special things,…), so I mostly tried to maximize the local use of whatever action. At the end, the points were so close (except for the winner, maybe only due to a double counting of 18 action points) that a specific strategy indeed did not seem to matter so much…

There is no way of destroying the buildings of an opponent. We can mess up a little through terraforming places adjacent to the opponents, but that's not much.

The theme is quite absent: I did not feel like a Nomad at all, I could see one connection between the Mermaids and their special seafaring ability, I did not really see the theme behind the halflings, but I did not really pay attention to their special powers. I fell the theme less than in 7 Wonders, or Settlers of Catan…
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

Ich kann mir jetzt auch gut vorstellen warum es nicht so oft auf den Tisch kommt... es gibt noch 1.000 andere tolle Spiele und dafür dann zuwenig Zeit!!!

RATING: 7
I tend to agree with Temelin [article #23867893] > Terra Mystica - Man did I think this game was going to be amazing. Turns out it's just a cluster#&$% of mechanics that make no sense together. This game has everything: Changing terrain tiles, neighbor bonuses, doo-wop groups, moving people down hallways, tweekers, skeevies, Spud Webb, shovels, moving disks around in bowls, hobo-cops, and bonuses for doing random $&!# in a certain order. This game is what would happen if Kingdom Builder, Small World, and Hansa Teutonica had a threesome on top of a Stefan Feld point salad. I hate this game so much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Terra Mystica is a strategic game with a simple game principle, where luck plays a small role. You lead one of the fourteen peoples who try to change the terrain on the board to put down buildings. On the one hand it is not good if there are other players in the neighborhood, because this limits your expansion possibilities, on the other hand this can be advantageous because it can give you a number of advantages in the game. It is this tension that makes Terra Mystica a unique game, so you are on the edge of your chair right up to the end.
Buildings can be improved to get even more benefits in the form of workers, priests, money and strength. Build temples to gain more influence on the elements of water, fire, air and earth. Make your own castle to use the special characteristics of your people. Expand your territory and create new settlements, so that you have many workers at your disposal, or ensure a steady stream of money by building trading houses.
The fourteen beautifully shaped peoples each have unique and special characteristics. In combination with the bonus cards, which change hands every round, this creates a lot of variation which makes the course of the game always different.Terra Mystica is absolutely for people who want something different than Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I was a little intimidated by it at first, but this is one I could really enjoy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While I wish the buildings and workers weren't abstracted as blocks, I've never seen a game about terraforming before, and the shovel wheel in that regard fits with the theme. 

There's a balance between wanting to be adjacent to an opponent so that you pay less for settlements but also having to compete with theme for space.

If it weren't for the different faction powers I think this game would start to feel samey (not that there doesn't seem to be more than one path to victory especially there are several different things you can get bonus points for having the most of, just that I really like my variable setup), but faction bonuses seems like they are different enough to at least coax you to alter your strategy.

I wonder if certain factions have significantly better match ups against other factions, and wonder why the board size doesn't scale with the number of players.

EDIT: I think previously I bought a little too much into the BGG hype train and so had confirmation bias. Still a great game, but when I finish it I don't look dowb ar my cities and feel "wow, I built something really cool this game", especially sincewhile the different factions have different engines their end product are quite similar.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[microbadge=5][microbadge=670]

Sometimes a game requires some work to play that game.  Other times the game is entirely work.  Terra Mystica is work.  It's gone full-throttle into the scarce resource, need-to-do-more-than-have-actions genre, mixed it with fourteen distinct factions, and then tacked on a 2-3 hour play-time.  Now there are many games that do a few of these things.  Many of them are good old German-designed Euros, but those games tend to be in the 45-75 minute range, not the 2-3 hour range.  If I'm playing a game for 2+ hours, I want it to be an epic, chaotic, deep AT title.  I don't want to play a puzzle for 2+ hours.  Terra Mystica is elegant, but not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Terra Mystica is THE perfect Euro. Tight and tense, always engrossing, with each decision feeling momentous.  With only six short rounds to a game, planning is challenging and execution is gratifying.  Spatial aspect is very strong, and the constant competition for real estate, round tiles, and special actions gives the game an exciting vibe.  Extremely high replay value.  Most of the factions are exceptionally balanced.  Theme is more than adequate and component design is good.  More direction could have been given concerning faction selection among advanced players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I thought at first...this is a point salad. And all the mechanics?  This game should be a hot mess.  But somehow...it isn't?  I am not sure how they pulled this off.
This is a thinky, strategic point salad that rewards a very nice mix of tactical AND strategic thinking. Each round has a nice tactical reward, while area control and the culture track both add a nice reward for long-term strategy. Enough player action and blocking/helping and a it cut throat worker placement at the end (opponents grabbing actions you wanted).

The variability of the different races and figuring out how best to use their ability (fairly obvious, but easier said than done) is fun.  

Once I learn the races I expect my rating to settle down to a respectable 8. But now...I give this monster a 9. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Rahdo says it's an amazing game. Rhado says that it's almost like math homework EVERY TURN. Constantly calculating and balancing the options EVERY step of the way. Very dry. As dry as chess.


Might be a too deep game for my needs.

RATING: 5
This game reminds me so much of the old classic german boardgames: little theme with tense gameplay, interaction is there but no direct confrontation.
I know that this rating maybe affected by the 'cult of the new virus', but I just keep thinking about the different strategies available in the game. Simply marvelous!
Edited 23/2/2012: borrowed the game to a group for 2 weeks and the game has already been played more than 10 times! This speaks for the game's appeal. I played 1 more time and its problems start to show up: not repetitive, but the dragging of turns in late game and the very un-forgiving nature of the game. Sort of like a chess game, you win or lose by a single move. It's simply more difficult to notice in this game. Rating down to 8.5.
Edited on 3/10/2015. I have never played TM since 2/2012. MY copy has been borrowed by 1 of my friends and he has not played it either. It just lacks the attraction for me to play this again. However, there are quite a no of players who enjoy this game and keep playing it week by week till now. Is it just my taste? Rating down to 5.

RATING: N/A
Neat territory building game, the player boards are a little odd-looking, maybe even put-off-ish, but it's probably the coolest design of magic and fantasy I've seen in a while, being kind of gentle and not over the top.

Rulebook. Is. Effing. Terrible. WAY too detailed, not designed well, but a lot of that may be due to translation. That said, the game isn't hard to learn or teach at all, the mechanics are pretty obvious once you start reading, and further, the symbology is done so well you can see what everything does just by looking.

Bought from The Guardtower.

RATING: 10
Initial impression is that this game has a lot of depth to offer. It was slow to learn at first due to the large number of minor exceptions to rules, and we made at least one mistake (thinking that leeching power only applied to upgrades, rather than new buildings). Subsequent games show how steep the learning curve is, you'll be thinking about this game long after you finish a session. Frustrated that I've only managed 3 plays so far, the last of these being the best with a very tense finish (tied winners) and it is a game that I can see myself being happy to play for a very long time to come. 4 plays now and most recently a win with the giants, which seem slightly underrated, on about 135vp.

RATING: 8.5
An economic engine building game with variable player powers. The 14 different factions play quite differently, but it seems some are a bit weaker than others. The game has a high learning curve and AP prone players can really drag the game as there are quite many possible actions to do and you have to plan the use of your limited resources carefully. Each game is different because of the changing scoring tiles (6 out of 10) and bonus tiles (players+3 out of 9).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Terra Mystica... You are big. You are heavy. You take a good 45 minutes to teach. But there you are. Spread out over my table. Colorful and intimidating. And, I can not get enough of you. I'm now over 10 plays and can't wait for my next. You change you evolve. Now you can freeze and melt (expansion). Every play is different. The number of players changes so much about you. Yet, at your core you stay the same. You are deep and well imagined. You give me surprises every time I try a new (of the 20) factions. Observers see chaos... but us players, oh, we know. We know your dirty little secret. The fact you are an impeccably balanced A-symmetrical experience. Every race feels different even though the goal is the same for everyone. I love you so my sweet Terra Mystica. I can't wait to have you across my table again in all your colorful glory. Thank you Terra Mystica. You make me love strategy in a way I haven't in a long time. I will see you very very soon...

RATING: 6
This game has some great core mechanics, and I like the variety between the difference races.  However, despite the differences between the races, I found that after playing a number of times (I've played around 20 or so times), the strategy for winning doesn't really change substantially, regardless of the race.  This results in it becoming very mechanically driven and repetitive with each game not feeling much different to the last.

RATING: N/A
Adriano
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5


This game has so much to offer and tons of replayability. I have seen that there are optimal first moves for each civ and that's fine. I have also heard people talk about a pasted-on theme... I see their point but I don't care. The way that I think about the theme makes it fit for me. Different races live on different tiles and have different abilities / bonuses in religions based on their race. Seems to work.

The mechanics are super cool. I love how you use your player board to track what you are doing and how everything on the board makes so much sense. We spent 3 hours learning the rules on our first play when we really only needed a few minutes to look at what you can do, then read our player boards. I should be able to teach this to new players quite quickly.
I love the power mechanic, moving those purple pieces around in the bowls really gets me thinking about what I'm doing. I need to think about how I will be using my power and if it's worth it to burn some power permanently so that I can do an action on the current turn. Being able to sacrifice power to use other power is really great, without it the game seems difficult to complete. 

I have much more to say but time is not on my side. I will say that I love playing the Halflings. I know that there are "better" races but those dudes are my jam. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Its hard not to say that this is my favorite game. I really enjoy the decisions that must be made. While it has a point saladesque feel to it, poor decisions are crippling, and there is no real catch up. That is a big plus for me. 15/11/02

No longer my favorite game. Thanks Roads and Boats...
1/19/16
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I gave Terra Mystica my one and only 10 ever in my 800+ collection. I really cannot find any flaw in it's design. Even the 45 minutes you need per player pass by very quickly. Yes it is a heavy game. It is a true brain burner with tons of choices to make every turn. It is a challenge to the mind. And sure, that must be your cup of tea. Yet it is the only heavy game I found myself wanting to play right again after 3+ hours of gaming. It has no luck factor whatsoever except for the starting set up and that is not decisive for the outcome of the game. Try before you buy but do yourself a huge pleasure and play it at least once. It is a true work of art. A classic with a very functional graphic design. I find myself explaining the game in less than half an hour and all players know ,thanks to extremely well designed player boards, exactly what they can and cannot do. I thank myself every day for having a clear moment and visit the Essen stand late on sunday so I could pick up one of the unpicked preorders. It is simply the best game I have ever played.

RATING: 6
Where is the theme? Lack of creativity from the designer? 

Euro game all the way. Earn this, transform in that, use to gain points. Territory building. Engine that needs to be built as soon as possible. So the first few rounds are not really very exciting. Many strategies to score points. You can play with a different race every time you play.

Having said that, the game mechanisms are smooth, and enjoyable. But 3 hours for my first play + 1 hour explanation were a bit too much. Typically a game that becomes more interesting after playing it for a few times. But then preferably with players that have played it also. 

Minus: 2 - 5 - 7 - 9 (expert game)

RATING: 8
+4 town expansion

+Mini-expansion (4-Town/Shipping/Temple Round/New landscapes)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
While I missed two opportunities where I could (and should) have gotten this game earlier, getting it loaned by a friend who is on a business trip for a couple of weeks allowed me to get a good couple of games in nevertheless. Those plays confirmed the high expectations I had from reading the rules and, moreover, demonstrated that this is not only a deep and very varied game, but also one that can just zoom by if people know what they are doing.

This is especially true for the two-player game, with a typical play time of less than an hour including setup, but I feel that a lot of things that shine with more players merely twinkle in a duel. The race for the cult bonuses and the biggest network are decidedly less tense, and I’m not sure whether this can be improved by just distributing points for 1st and 3rd instead of 1st and 2nd place to steepen the slope. Likewise, the decisions of whom to help and to hinder are obviously trivial when there’s just a single opponent. After three two-player games, my possibly premature judgement is that this is a good way to learn how to optimise your building tree, but you’re not getting the full game this way.

The good news is that all the subtle interactions get cranked up as soon as you add a third player, and the full five player game is just pure joy for me. Weaving an aspect of good neighbourship (cost reduction for trading houses and the magic boost from nearby construction) into the usual competition for building space is the key design decision that sets Terra Mystica apart. As far as I can tell from eight played games, the good design is coupled with good development and excellent graphical design. The latter greatly contributes to smooth play, since there are many subtle reminders of how everything works on the board.

About the only thing that would hinder my current estimation of Terra Mystica as a great game, not merely a very good one, would be the discovery that some of the available factions really are more powerful than others. So far, however, I feel that the impact of player skill is higher by orders of magnitude – there might be some factions that are more straightforward to play and therefore seem to be better in the first and, possibly, the second game (which, let’s be honest, is the typical amount of plays a game will see from the majority of the BGG population), but with a bit more experience, it all seems to even out.

Update: Rating settles at 10 after 50+ games. Fulfilled all expectations and then some.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Pretty damn complicated. A bit too much, honestly. And with only 6 turns (which nonetheless each take around 20-25 minutes) it's also one of those games that ends right as you're getting going, like many Euro games, a mechanic which I don't care for at all. You can easily make a mistake early on which completely screws you over, with little to no chance of being able to recover. Therefore, you have to be extremely knowledgeable of the game to even begin doing well at it. And with an average game taking about 2.5 hours, that's a lot of time commitment. I don't personally like the game enough to warrant taking that much time to get good at it.

RATING: 5
Boy I don't know... I definitely appreciate the design of the game but it may not be for me.  I just may not be smart enough for it.  I had a hard time figuring it out.  There are multiple spendable "currencies" if you will: money, white cubes, meeple dudes, and purple mana discs (Yes, I'm getting all the thematic names wrong.)  So there's different ways to get all those, and different structures to build, that only build or upgrade in a certain order, but you have to terraform first, which also costs stuff, and if you upgrade buildings it lowers your income of some of those resources, and one of the currencies has to be cycled through "bowls of power" (or something like that) in a certain way before it's usable...  I mean, I like it and it's awesome how there's different races that all have different abilities and advantages - but man, maybe I'm just too dumb to see it all, and put together a plan that would help me play well.

So yeah, I say cool game, but too much stuff going on for me perhaps.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Our first play with four took an hour to set up and explain and three hours to play, making this unlikely to hit the table often -- which is too bad, because it's a really good game.

Playing it made me feel dumb, but I still came in second. It has a lot of knock-on effects and levers to pull and things to manipulate, and everything in it -- absolutely everything -- is important to your score. And of course it's not possible to do everything well, making for plenty of enjoyable turn angst.

Sometimes individual actions are quite clear, so turns are fairly brisk. But every rounds take longer, and is a more decision-rich environment, as the game progresses.

There are elements of two other games I love in it, Small World and Castles of Burgundy, but it's heavier than either of them. The balance of strategy and tactics is excellent, though I didn't always feel like I knew why I was doing things (unlike either of those two games).

The rulebook and iconography are some of the best I've ever seen. Every inch of the player mat tells you something in shorthand, and the same goes for the other components. With a poorly written rulebook or bad graphic design, this game would fall completely flat; there's too much going on for that.

For me, it'd be tricky to introduce to new players (at least for now). I asked everyone to read the rulebook beforehand, and I don't know that I'd feel comfortable teaching it cold. That plus its length makes it a tricky sell, but I'll be holding onto it for those chances, however rare they might be, to play it again.

---

Second play was much smoother and more in line with the expected play time. Such an elegant game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

I was worried about the map not being modular, but see now why that doesn't matter.  Each game has enough variation and with no luck after setup it makes for an interesting time.  The players are the luck, not the game.  I can see this getting 50 or more plays easy.

RATING: 9
So far, so good. It's still not my final opinion, because I got to play it more.
Likes:
- It is rich! There's so much going on that it really makes for the luck of any randomness. You can focus on different things every time you play. There's money, and workers, and priests, and power, and...
- It's variable - you have different bonus tiles and scoring tiles and of course different races. It never feels (so far) the same game.
- It;s not only important what you do, but also WHEN you do it (because of the scoring tiles). It creates even more choices.
- It's very interconnected - every decision has impacts on other things.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Bought at Kingslayer Comics 2/20/16.

Initial reviews said that this had horrible 2-player gameplay and was fairly soulless.  However, the first weekend we bought this, we couldn't stop playing.  5 games in that first weekend, all at 2-players.  Interaction is less than what it would be at 4, but it's still there and it still matters - power bonuses, cult track, blocking all still count.

While the map is fixed, each race plays quite differently.  Round scoring and bonuses also differ each game, thus increasing replayability.  I now understand why this was rated so highly for so long.

Theme is definitely pasted on, but not as thin as I've been led to believe.  It may have been the result of lowered expectations, but I felt that some aspects - i.e. race bonuses to be thematic.  Nomads live in tents, which are easy to set up, so have more dwellings.  Swarmlings reproduce quickly, but require more income as a result.  These all make sense with a small stretch. 

The lack of race balances does, however, irk me.  We played a game of Darklings vs. Fakirs to see how much this affects gameplay, and it really does.  The Fakirs ability felt pretty useless.  They even start out with less Bowl 2 power, making them even more awkward to play.

---
Update 3/14/16.  I still want to play this ALL THE TIME.  This is entrenched as a solid 9.  May creep up as a 10. 

---
Update 5/6/16.  Rating increased from 9 to 9.5.  Played this at 4p with Michelle and Daniel.  It was awesome, and the interactions really shone through.  Game time was relatively quick for a 4p game, and there were plenty of difficult decisions.  I still want to play this even more.

RATING: 6
I'm not sure I get what all the fuss is about. The art on the player boards and main board is as bland as can be, there are balance issues, not just among the races themselves, but in what lands the mix of races in any particular game is going to be competing for, that power wheel is the dumbest, most unthematic mechanism I've ever seen in a euro, and the process of getting a cult track reward where you get one of a whole bunch of tiles brings the whole game to a halt as someone examines each and every tile.

I mean, it's not as bad as I'm making it sound, but it's an ordinary, flawed euro in my book.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite heavy games.
Awesome modern classic of heavy strategy games. Replayability is very good due to different races. I'll never want to play it with the online player crowd though, it's sadly a game that can be analyzed to death with best openings etc. I've reduced a rating since because of this. For same reason as Chess it'll never be a true favorite for me, they are games that attract unfun crowd for some reason. Sci-fi theme would be cool.

2-Player Comment:
* Terra Mystica works well with two evenly skilled opponents. Unofficial 2p variant: When setting up the game, put unused colour priests to spaces 3 and 5 of each cult track, and consider them 3rd & 4th player in final scoring.

Expansions:
+Terra Mystica: 4 Town Tiles & Spielbox promo

RATING: 8
Very good game.  A real gamers' game. Lots going on, many things to think about and different strategies to try. I think this is one that will reward repeated play.   Many moving parts to being able to play effectively - temple tracks, income streams, power cycling, area control, targeting bonuses etc.

Pieces, artwork and theme are very ordinary and those with colour blindness may have difficulty.

If you are looking for a light fun game to play, or a game to play with non gamers, then this is not the game for you.

RATING: 10
This game is near perfection.  TM is a game full of diversity of set-up, and always interesting and tense in-game decisions that never outstays its welcome.  4 player games can easily be completed in 2 hours (not counting set-up and teardown).

The depth of the game is apparent on first play, which can make it seem rather daunting for the first or second time player.  However, the play is so engaging, you'll come back for more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Terra Mystic is a game that offers so much depth and interesting choices, that you find yourself constantly coming back for more. This game really appeals to heavy euro gamers looking for an experience that is just as interesting the firsttime you play as the twentieth time. Once you understand the mechanics, the icons and actions are intuitive and easy to remember.
 
It might not appeal to everyone. There are mini-game like mechanics (cult track and power bowls) that add unnecessary complexity for teaching new players. The theme is pasted on. The factions are not necessarily balanced. It really shines with three or more players if you don't use the variant rules. 

Unfortunately, Gaia Project has replaced this game for me. I still think Terra Mystica is an excellent game and I would gladly play it, but Gaia Project does everything Terra Mystica does better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This heavy game gets much more play than I would have expected. Steep learning curve, interesting combinations. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome game, but it has a steep learning curve as far as strategy goes.  Awesome but complex.

RATING: 5

RATING: 7

Definitely only for the hardcore euro fan.

RATING: 9.1
Nearly perfect in balance, and board design. So many great mechanics.  

The only problems I have with it are that there are too many pieces, it takes a while to sit down and learn really well, and it does take a while to play.  

There are all good things about it too though..  lots of depth, lots to learn, and takes a little while, but it does end!  The game is on a "timer" of sorts, ending after 6 rounds.  It comes with enough races to make the game interesting every time, and can be played with 2 to 5 players.  

Each race has it's own play style, and the flavors are well thought out.  The cultist track was probably the most odd addition to the game, but still really cool.  

Definitely giving this a 9!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I am sure this one will be over-analysed eventually with 'best openings' and optimised play in given conditions, but the journey getting there will be a lot of fun. The situation reminds me a Puerto Rico in the sense that perfect information games are prone to analysis and suffer with unequally skilled players. Terra Mystica seems more open than Puerto Rico and the selection of races allow for some some tuning to player skill. 

The criticism that there is limited player interaction is quite fairly levelled in some circumstances, I feel the game is at it's best when played with the more interactive races than the solitaire optimisation ones, although I view this as a feature of having the wide range to choose from. I am generally happy to live with some games not having as much cut and thrust as others. 

This might well slip off the 10 spot, but for now it's a winner. I have enjoyed every game of this I have played so far.

RATING: 9.4
One of the most unforgiving games I've played, with wonderfully balanced gameplay. Very intimidating to look at, but once you get going it isn't so bad. Some rules are kind of obscure. Probably the best example of a 3+ player game that could be considered "competitive".

It's high rating here on BGG is well deserved.

I don't often suggest playing it to my game group because I play it fairly often online. This is probably my most played game at this point if you include online plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent intriguing game that blends together many familiar mechanisms and adds at least one new one (the way power works). Optimization game, interaction could have been more. Different races with different abilities keep the game varied. Each race requires a different development route. You need to plan for that at the start of the game to take maximum advantage of those special abilities. The bonus tile you choose each round can also be critical to your development. I like it better with each play, the game remains in my head. It is a challenging game, but for a spatial game interaction remains limited.

Update: played all 14 races. Now that I tried them all, the choice at the start to pick a race depending on bonustiles, roundtiles other colours and races in play etc. is great and challenging. I love this game more and more. It has lots of long term and short term planning. in some cases it is possible to largely plan your actions for the full game ahead to take maximum advantage of bonusses. And I love it when a plan comes together, some guy named Hannibal used to say in the 80's.

Further update: 22 plays and I still don't tire of it. Fascinating game, I love the short term and long term planning possibilities. Upgraded to 9.5.

Update: flawless perfect game. 37 plays, upgraded to a full 10 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The more i play this, the more i seem to like it. I only played witches until now, but i really dig the game and it isnt that hard to understand at all. Ok, the theme is totally pasted on, its the definition of a modern dry euro BUT.... it is a great game and i don't say no to it. Playing time with 4 really is 1.5 hours once everybody gets the rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After playing several times, the game feels disconnected and clunky. The different factions provide some interesting dynamics, however, the mechanics make the use of these different powers either difficult to use or overpowered. There is always more to do than you can afford, which makes a game challenging, but there doesn't seem to be a balance between what you can do and what you need to do, and made the outcomes of my plays feel less earned and more happenstance. Over all, a decent game, but there are far better worker placement games on the market.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Good, solid area dominance euro with unneccessarily fiddlish rondel mechanics thrown in loosly set in a fantasy world with abstracted fantasy races. 

Features a bucketful of simultaneous mechanics and competitive scoring tracks yet they are coherent and make sense together (unlike that vile croc of offal Trajan). 

Manages a rather high degree of interaction in that positioning next to other players have advantages in percolating up more wildcard resources to spend. 

A bit long but offers decent entertainment for the time it assumes. Not a true brain burner, it ranks in middle-depth euros, about the same difficulaty and demands of concentration as Power Grid.

In mijn bezit sinds 24-08-2015

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Strategic heaven. A multitude of different races with their own special abilities, variable set-up, no luck or hidden information, a balance between staying clear of opponents to avoid being built in, and staying close to benefit from cheaper building costs and gaining power from opponents.

To avoid players choosing the same race/faction over and over again, I recommend mixing up and randomly assigning everyone a board. Players still get to choose which of the two factions on the board they want to play, but it often means they have to adapt to a different play style than their usual, which keeps things interesting and can help players discover new fun ways of playing the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Had to teach myself this game so I could teach the people I play with. Made getting the first game going daunting due to the sheer amount of options that are available even with the recommended first game setup, but after one full game you got the sense of the flow. Will take many plays before it is fully understood and how the races interact. Look forward to peeling back the layers of this game.

Update - bumped up to 9 from 8 (7 games in). I knew finding people to play this with me would be a challenge and almost made me not get it, as it might not see many plays. However, when you are able to get someone to invest in learning the rules, I have had success in getting them to play again. Currently the game I would pick first if I got to pick a game.

Update 2.0 - Bumped this from 9 to 10. After many plays of this game, it is still my favorite game I own. It has had a staying power that almost none of the other 40 games I own have achieved. If my house was to burn down, this is the first game I would replace.

RATING: 7.5
Takes the lighter and faster playing [gameid=107529] and adds an action wheel, powers and building upgrades. They certainly are different games but it's hard not to compare.

So what do I think? Well, first I wish I had my opponent's powers instead of my own. Second, the wheels are neat, the buildings are cool but a pain at times to time their placements correctly. Not as free-wheeling as it looks, certainly a bit of a brain-burner at times. Interesting thematic/euro blend.

RATING: N/A
B
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This very well-designed eurogame is my current favourite. It's very satisfying to place big wooden pieces on the board and watch your empire grow.

With 14 races and variable round and bonus tiles, replayability should be good. I would guess that some races are unbalanced, at least in some combinations with other races and number of players. I would have liked an option of bidding for races, rather than just choosing them, but that can be house-ruled.

Also, I would have liked a second map on the back of the board, or even better: some kind of variable board. Still, as it is, I don't know of any better game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favorite game. It has a great mix of strategy and tactics, rewarding the player for making choices based on the initial setup but also reacting to the moves by his opponents. It features a ton of direct player interaction without involving combat or destruction. The replayability is off the charts. Every choice requires the consideration of many factors and is so weighty. Timing is critical.

Almost always want to play. With our core group we can play a 4p game in 90 minutes, though I'm happy to teach it and play longer learning games as well. Great game.

RATING: 8
A relatively long explanation is required for this one, as the game has a good number of rules, but you're rewarded with a meaty, planning-heaving game that has some player interaction (but no attacking or destruction of other players' items, which is refreshing).

I've played this once, and enjoyed it, but ended up making two key mistakes in the placement phase which hurt tremendously.  After the rules explanation I didn't realize how powerful it would be to be a) close to other players, to get power, and b) how important it would be to be able to connect up my independent cities later in the game.  So, while the game was fun, it was mildly frustrating to realize after a turn or two that I was almost certainly destined to lose badly :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Theres a careful balance that needs to be kept between which buildings you go for. Ideally you want to maximize the bonus points from tiles and cities, but getting them isn't always easy. Probably the best euro of 2012

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
What a delightful game.  

The core of the game, that as magical factions we each have a chosen type of terrain and will use our magic to terraform the world around us to meet our needs and thus be able to build settlements there, is already a more fun derivation of the Settlers of Catan hexmap idea.  But the (for new players and veterans alike) dizzying array of options and possibilities.  The learning curve is a bit steep at the beginning of the game, but I have found that all people I play this with end up loving it once the rhythm of the game makes sense to them.  The expansion is not necessary - but makes an awesome game even more fun by virtue of further replay value!

(Written 5/4/16)

RATING: 7
Szép játék, rengeteg komponenssel, nem rövid, de érthető és logikus szabályzattal. Ennyi a pozitívum.

Nekem valahogy a téma nem jön át, messze nem kapott el az a flow érzés, amiről sokan írnak internet-szerte. Túlságosan steril, mondhatjuk, hogy kunyhókat (házikókat), kereskedőházat, erődöt, templomot és szentélyt építünk, de ettől ezek még - kifejezetten - ronda kis fakockák lesznek, amiket rendkívül szűkös erőforrásainkból kell kigazdálkodnunk (már-már kényelmetlenül kis mozgástérrel). Gyakorlatilag a játék 90%-ban azon agyalunk, hogy miből termeljük ki a következő építkezést és még a játék felénél is azon frusztrálódunk, hogy még egy nyamvadt erődöt sem tudtunk összehozni, pedig... Túlzott AP hatás bejátszik, már-már élvezhetetlen, pedig nekifutottunk párszor.

Röviden: rossznak nem mondanám, mert akinek bejön a patikamérlegen kimért stratégiázás és 2-3 órán keresztül a folyamatos számolgatás egy absztrakt pályán és komponensekkel, annak ez legalább egy 7-8-as játék lesz. A játékot körülvevő hype (és az ára) alapján ennél jóval többet vártam volna. [Ha egy 6.000 Ft-os játék lenne a BGG 500. helye körül, egy szavam nem lenne rá...]

Bennünket nagyon nem fogott meg, nekifutottunk háromszor, de továbbra sem értem, hogyan lett ebből top10-es játék pár hónap alatt...

UPDATE (2017.02.27.): szóló variánst kipróbálva - 3 ellenfél ellen - már egészen jó volt, fel is pontoztam (lehet, hogy két játékossal volt csak ennyire béna?).
