=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't think this one's going to last much longer for me. The key to this game is recognizing your group's special ability and how to best play it, but I'm not sure how interesting repeated play with the same group will be. In my second game, I was fortunate enough to play the Nomads, which everyone said were "easy," and I guess they were, since I was just one point away from winning. I had everything planned out two rounds in advance through out the game, so I spent most of the time just waiting on other players. Playing for the round-by-round building bonuses seems to be a pretty solid strategy, but it could be that it's solid only with certain groups (like the Nomads). The only thing that would draw me back in would be the prospect of playing a different group, but if I find that the building bonus strategy works yet again then my interest in this title might conclude.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I WANT to like this a lot more than I think that I do.  People keep comparing it to Eclipse and Hansa Teutonica (and even Kingdom Builder), games that I like but I just don't feel the similarities that much.  They share one similar mechanic (which I really do like), removing pieces from a board to uncover increasing supply.  But otherwise, these games feel nothing alike.

I've played it twice now.  I did alright with the Nomads, but had a horrible time with the Engineers.  It was brutal trying to get workers and feeling like I had substantially less options than most everyone else.  So I don't know if this is a problem with the variable powers not being well-balanced or if I just wasn't able to determine the dominant strategy.  But as I thought over my moves, I really couldn't see a way to increase the worker supply that I desperately needed (and which others seemed to have plenty.)

The game looks beautiful, and I usually love a game with a good spacial element, so I feel like I owe it a few more games.  But it does feel a little long for what it is.  There isn't much to do between turns and there's a lot of information to process, including what other people have resources and ability to do, their position and whether you can afford to wait a turn to do something.  There's a lot going on and you can get cut-off at any number of points along your decision tree, which can derail a well-thought out plan.  I'm sure this is all part of the fun for some, but for me my decisions felt more arbitrary than interesting trying to guess what others were trying to do and feeling powerless to change them when I did know.

I WILL say, that though it may be a decent game, I think the general response to this game is way over what it deserves.  It may not be my type of game but neither do I think it's the kind of genius everyone seems to think it is.  I'm afraid it's mostly hype for a game that is in short supply.

BUT, after 2 plays, I still am intrigued enough to want to play again.  I'm hoping familiarity will increase our speed of play and improved strategy, my enjoyment.

RATING: 7.5
This is an extremely punishing area-control game with a very restrictive economy & a tight, linear strategic path.  The tightness of the economy (limited money & limited access to bridges ) & screw-factor from other players make this extremely frustrating.  Bad moves can leave you in a position where you are completely locked out of options:  meaning a bad player can get into a position where they are denied having any more fun. In the best of cases, the game-play is rather dry. Finally, the starting races do not seem well-balanced, which can add to the frustration.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fantastic game with deeply layered strategy, multiple paths to victory, asymmetrical player factions and even some light player interaction, which many heavy euros lack completely. The player boards and various components are littered with symbols and your first play-through will mostly be about acquiring literacy in the game's symbology and mechanics, but once you do, the beauty and fun of this game shine out like a silver dollar in a chimney-sweep's ear.
HOWEVER, this is NOT a game for everyone. While I really appreciate the subtle layers of strategy that build upon themselves and the many different ways to acquire VP's, for some folks it will just be too many choices. Even the most astute players will suffer from some level of AP (Analysis Paralysis), and those who already have a problem with AP will be absolutely dazed (in our first play, it took one player 10 minutes just to realize they had nothing left to do and pass).    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A crowd pleaser. The game almost has it all for small groups of friends: rules are streamlined and easy to grasp in the first match; you can lead a strategy and leading a good one is rewarding; it has a lot of replayability because of races and goal randomization; it lasts for a decent amount of time to fill an evening; it is rewarding to see what you built and achieved in the end.
Probably one of the games that will see more table in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A solid euro game. What I like the most about Terra Mystica is that most actions make you feel good even though they were not optimal. Also, using spells helps you to correct your mistakes later on. At the first glance races felt quite balanced (because the differences are not that big) and they surely make every game feel a bit different.

Even though Terra Mystica is an euro game, I was left hoping the theme was strapped onto the mechanics more. I know this is common in the euros but this game mostly felt themeless. Some mechanics of Terra Mystica also felt overly complicated for not a specific reason (for example, the magic power management).

I will surely enjoy playing this game many times but if looking for the all time favorite, nope, I need more theme for that.

RATING: 7.5
Beautiful but busy map. Interesting game with lots of submechanics interrelating. Its like someone merged Eclipse, Dominant Species and a little bit of small world but left out all the conflict and randomness to make it Eurogamer friendly. 

Would definitely play this again with experienced players who move quickly. I doubt it would get played much in my usual gaming circles as I can see the AP-inducing range of options causing downtime blowout, turning what should be a quick 2 hour game into a 4 hour game.

RATING: 8.1

After a second play my rating has increased to 8.1. This is a really great game, but needs to be played by gamers who don't suffer from AP.

RATING: 8.2
Solid, offers a nice point optimization puzzle, although I'm not sure whether I'm a huge fan of the cumulative point churning mechanisms these kind of heavy euros rely on. But at least the different races with their different powers provide you with a gameplan.

Maybe a bit too long considering the payoff; it IS just point collecting with very little interaction and a completely pasted on theme. It's also very unforgiving: mess up your economy and there's nothing worthwhile for you to do for the rest of the game. Six turns is very little. This scarcity of money seems to make two of the actions (money, double-shovel) much more important than the rest, thus the competition is mainly for those two.

RATING: 8.5
1/6/15 Update:
Hmmm..., well I've played it my 3rd time now, and I have to say it is growing on me, and it is a very good game, even though I'm not so sure about the theme.  Still not sure that I need to pick up my own copy.

Update:
Only played twice and it's a good enough game, but not good enough to warrant a purchase from me.  Little too dry and heavy for my tastes.

Original comment:
Someone described it as a "soulless Euro", and I have to agree.  The theme here is very weak.  Stefan Feld games that people complain have a pasted on theme, have much better theme and theme integration than this game.

Very much an abstract game, which I don't mind, that didn't really resonate with me on my first play.  

Bottom line, an intriguing game that "appears" to be a good.  However, "I" did not find it all that exciting or fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I finally got to play one of the highest rated game on the BGG. Terra Mystica has an intricate economy of buildings for income, mana for special powers and cult tracks for endgame scoring. This is combined with a unique take on area control, where you need to transform areas before taking control. Unfortunately, the designers added a point salad of various scoring opportunities and variable player powers that detract from the economy/terraforming gameplay. The strategy is often dictated from the start ("use your powers to maximize A round 1, B round 2 etc.") and much of the game become an exercise of mathematical optimization, particularly in the last round which can really drag. Terra Mystica earns its reputation but I would personally have preferred a cleaner design, focusing on the core mechanisms.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
An excellent engine-building game. I like how it encourages you to keep your opponents close - but not too close. If someone builds next to you then you can get magic power, but they may also block you and prevent you from expanding!

It is impossible to fight in this game. There are no combat mechanics. So you must use sneaky tactics to foil the plans of your enemies. This gives the game a very unique feeling compared to the other civilization games in my collection and I like that a lot.

This is a very heavy game. I would only recommend this for experienced board gamers! There are many rules to learn and remember. But once you figure it out, it's extremely good.

RATING: 8
Enjoyable, though the rise to BGG's top 10 still seems like a stretch.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Hardcore, but an extremely satisfied gaming experience. 
The learning curve is high, partly because of the complicated rule-set, although everything sounds quite intuitive once you know the rules. Game play is swift and smooth after a few play as well.

What I like about the games is its characterization - as you are leading different tribes, you need to play differently. The round bonus cards and players' tribe choices and position affects how you choose your tribe, and then different tribes might in some way affect each others. 

This is a game of deep planning, but at the same time ask you to be opportunistic when situation comes up to take advantage. It's very dynamic, as a player's choice would affect another player, and subsequently the other players. The good thing about the game is while it's interactive, it is not chaotic - everything can be cauclated. There's basically zero random factor after all the set-up is done. It's the players that manage the outcome of the game.

With more expansion in the future, I can only see its appeal goes up and up. This is what a modern Euro should be - with a touch of thematic elements, characterization, cutthroatness while retain the need of planning and calculation in most Euro game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
There are two major flaws for me with this one:
1. Game feels "empty". Its lore is probably one of the worst I have ever seen. It never felt that the witches were conquering lands to the giants, while trading with the undead... if that could ever make any sense. The boardgame being so ugly to look at does not help either.
2. Game mechanics feel too complicated for what the game delivers. Don't get me wrong: I love some heavy games when the complexity actually makes sense. But with this game, it feels like it was pretentiously made more complex than it should, just for the sake of it. 
I am probably giving this another go in a couple of weeks before trading it out, but I do not have many expectations that this will change my mind (sadly).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Deep strategy, FFA
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A colorful, but utterly themeless game about transforming one type of points into other types of points in order to score points. It's quite depressing how pasted-on the whole 'factions'-flavour is. The game is an extremely tedious accounting/optimisation exercise, where even the slightest suboptimality will lose you the game, despite going for an elegant strategy. There is something hypnotic here, but the lack of theme is a killer, since the game doesn't really tell any story. 

I could make a better game by reskinning an excel spreadsheet with a quick goblin theme. The player board itself is a total mess... There's nothing intuitive about changing one type of vp to another there: it's all for the sake of itself. It feels like unpaid dull accounting work where there are a few optimal ways to complete the optimisation problem, and deviating from the path leads to an embarrassing so-what ending. The different factions are different, but they have no human character or artistic merit. It's all barebones fog without anything underneath. They made the equations, but they forgot to make a Game. It has so much excess stuff that just increases downtime but not enjoyment: the tracks are like an afterthought. 

Spending the purple disks permanently has little penalty... It makes no sense. That whole cycling mechanism is just a terrible gimmick, like siri on smartphones. It's cool, but pointless. For a game that is all about interchanging points of different types, the game feels pointless, and has no intuitive feeling of achievement. This game isn't made for humans, I think. It has no humour, no soul. Just slow monotony.  

The theme could Not be more mismatched, I'd probably play Lords of Waterdeep as an rpg before getting into any mood with terra mystica. Even The name is pretentious. Rock paper scissors is more mystical. I think that a board game that has no 'human' non-stat-sheet dramatic arc to convey better be really Damn short and free of fiddliness. I don't just hate terra mystica, I think it is the worst kind of pretentious nonsense, failing in every strength that it purports to achieve. Different ways to win? Illusion. Very little luck? That's because there's very little of anything exciting. Strategic planning? Until someone permanently spends all the purple disks and everyone does it. The cost of terrain? Tedious gimmick... Nobody will ever build on more than a few terrains then.

The suboptimal path is so suboptimal that there is neither luck nor choice. Players Might as well be in a coma then. Finishing the game was like waking from a bad stuffy dream or finishing a dull day of labour. The opposite of refreshing. It focuses on all the gimmicks and needless mechanisms (made for the designers and for all the cogs themselves, not for people), but not on how the different phases are supposed to make the player Feel! That is just terrible design, for my taste. Even abstract games like Hive or chess make me Feel something. But playing terra mystica makes me feel depressed, like I ate something wrong or the bureaucrats accidentally sent me a 1000-page archive of aborted short-term initiatives. Great games make the board and the space of play around the table feel more alive, hyper-alive even, in a heightened state,,, and then there's Terra Mystica, a numbness better known as brain gangrene.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The team I play felt that the Halflings are overpowered (I won my first game with them), but I see this as situational because of the turn bonuses and the order in which they came.

I see a lot of replayability value in this game because of the random setup, though it can seem a bit dry due to the components look and feel. Other than a few images on the race-sheets, it seems not so "fantasy-like" as it perhaps should. Especially the terrain on the board and buildings are "Settler-of-Catan-ish", which is a bad thing in my book.
I would definitely get a deluxe version of this, should it ever come.

Even though the rules look overly complex, it was only necessary to check the rules for racial benefits, other than that there was no checking of the rules. It plays fluently.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome and deep game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Each player starts with a unique race, that has special abilities. Players start off native to a particular terrain, and will transform neighboring terrain into their terrian so that they can build their own structures on it to form cities. 

Each player has a player mat, where there are three bowls of power. Cubes taken out of the third bowl allow you to spend power points on resources in the game. Building beside an opponent will allow them to get power points, at a cost of some victory points. 

When you build dwellings onto the board, they uncover income for the next phase. When you build a religious dwelling you get to take a favor tile which gives you benefits during the game. 

There is a cult track which rewards points for those who are highest on the four tracks. Finally, there is end game scoring for those who have the most connected dwellings. 

There is a ton of stuff going on here, and you have to decide which bonus tiles you want to choose, and which scoring tiles to take advantage of. I've only played one game, but I'm looking forward to more plays. Game does clock in toward the longer side, but I was immersed the whole game. Rating likely to rise with more plays.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Build and expand your empire across the map by terraforming lands into your home terrain. I no longer enjoy teaching the game for the return. 

PROS
-Variable start abilities (14 races available).
-Lots of replay value.
-Minimal luck.
-Alternate paths to victory.
-Lots of important decisions to make. 
-Great artwork and components.

CONS
-Game is difficult to teach; there should be better summary guides/ player aids. The one included is terrible. 
-Game is not intuitive.
-Empty theme.
-Minimal player interaction (mostly solitary).
-The cult track is separate from the main board, which adds more confusion for new players. Also makes it seem less important and looks like the game is incomplete. 
-Bowls of power seem an unnecessary account keeping resource. Slows the game and could be implemented much better. 
-Forced cooperation to gain power/ cheaper buildings makes it more difficult to expand (thus longer game). Also a hard concept for new players and makes little thematic sense.  
-No catch up mechanism. 
-Runaway leader: game is a puzzle that can be solved quickly and the winner determined early, making the latter half of the game boring. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I generally prefer euros, but some just go over my head, and this was one of them. I would like to try this again though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A perfect ten, now in my top ten.

There are so many things that I like. Just to mention a few of them:
- No luck, no hidden information.
- 14 different fantasy races that with small difference in their special rules allow for a great difference in playing the game. Besides allowing a huge variability and replayability, this attracts family and friends alike because the theme comes through.
- Variable set-up further enriches the replayability.
- Strategic deep decisions, with a lot of choices, some subtler ones shoving themselves with more plays.
- The way magic power is managed allows to recover from tactical mistakes as a consequence speeding up play (e.g. one coin is missing because of miscalculation, just transform a magic power in a coin and nothing is lost).
- Original in so many ways. I like very much the above mentioned use of magic power, besides so many other things. Maybe some other mechanisms have already been seen, but they are integrated in such a new way that this game is very different from what I have played before. There are games that are milestones, and this is one of them: in the story of boardgaming there is a point in time that divides the flux, before and after Terra Mystica, this is how much it is different IMHO.
- There is interaction without screwing up. I had read negative comments about the game being too much a solitary thing. I don't agree with this at all, it is a game where one has to watch very carefully at what the others are doing and react if one wants to win.

I can't imagine a gamer not liking Terra Mystica, unless he/she has some aversion for Euro games and stops beforehand trying to like or even trying to play it.

Very recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 9
The most bland-looking game of all times (which may be an exaggeration) reveals itself as an outstanding strategic game. No, there is no theme at all here, but you won't mind it while you're struggling with every single step you take, brilliantly creating new strategies to defeat your friends. While you play the game, only the board matters.

It's not a 10, however, for one reason: the cult board. The main board feels so intense and so amazing that it makes me cry every time I remember that I have to divert my attention from it towards that ugly little appendix there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played it 4 times in real life and have 3 games going on terra.snellman.net and it is absolutely wonderful.  The theme gives it nice color and it does make some sense for the races the abilities are attributed to but what this game comes down to is the amazing amount of directions you can take your strategy, coupled with the randomized bonuses that really are the drivers of how you should play a race.  It's easy to learn even in it's complexity because it is elegantly designed.

Once you've played it a couple of times you will learn how to pick your race based on the round bonuses and available pass Bonuses.  I don't think it would be possible to win if you aren't using these bonuses to your advantage.  Each race has minor tweaks that make the timing of what you build for that race different.  One race you might go straight for the stronghold but another you might go Sanctuary.  One you might want to upgrade your dig right away, others you never will.  So it really depends.

On top of all that, every turn and every round you are faced with figuring out how to maximize the turn with your resources and with some luck, getting more power bonuses and not having critical things you need stolen from you right before your turn.  It's really a game of infinite possibilities and it's just beautiful to look at and has lots of texture to feel as well.  I see why it is the #4 game and it will be my next game purchase.  Also I love that it can be played with only 2 people.  Often games like this are min of 3. 

LOVE IT!  Perfect score.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
My favorite game and has been for over 2 years.  I really love how the game guides your strategy (with the round markers) for a different feel each time.  I also love how even when the markers don't feel like they will play to your race's strength there are other options and excelling is still possible. RATING: 8.5
Es uno de los juego que más me ha sorprendido este año. Aunque se editó el año pasado no había tenido la oportunidad de probarlo hasta hace unos meses. 

Me gusta como combina las diferentes mecánicas entre sí (algunas novedosas) e integra todos los elementos para que quede un juego redondo y equilibrado.

En cuanto a los aspectos negativos, es muy difícil hacer un juego asimétrico y que todo esté en equilibrio al ciento por ciento. Puede ser que alguna raza esté un poco por encima de otra. Aunque la verdad es que creo que puede ser que no he dado con la forma de jugar para las razas que veo más débiles.

No me gusta que no hayan pensado en alguna manera de jugarlo decentemente a 2 jugadores o incluso en solitario. El precio debería de incluir este "pequeño" detalle. Un ejemplo de esto es el Hansa Teutónica, en una cara del tablero 2 y 3 jugadores y en la otra 4 y 5. Es sencillo.

En todo caso para mi es un juego que sin lugar a duda me compraría.


http://mesasdejuegos.blogspot.com.es/2013/06/trajan-frio-como-el-fuego.html

RATING: 6
The factions in Terra Mystica aren't equally balanced, (some definitely need a few plays before their strategy can be understood), but there are so many that players can choose to play a game involving only the strongest factions or the weakest and then play will equalize.

A minor quibble that might get addressed in a later edition of the game involves the game board. The back of the board has a the game's name and some artwork from the box in full-color on it. It would have been nice if this surface had instead been used to create an alternate map to provide further play variation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A masterpiece, A must have for any fan of the genre. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent deeply strategic game.  I want to own this game, but with other deep, long playing time games I do own never finding their way to my table...it would be hard to justify this purchase...but I may anyway...I did!

14 different races, with their own special abilities, try to establish their colonies in this barren world.  You have to terraform the terrain tiles to a terrain that your race can live on.  As you build your town for every building you build you get an extra bonus income, sometimes a special ability.  When improving a building you need to remove the older building, so you lose that bonus, the way this feature is handled reminded me of Hansa Teutonica, a game I love.  You also are vying for gods' favors (cults) and managing your purple power discs.

The game is really deep and lasts a bit long, but it is great fun.  After my second play I am eager to keep playing.  This game is really fun, deep, and has just enough to scare away non-gamers marking this my top 'gamer's games'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love this game and everything about it. I like the choices you have to make and how those choices effect you in other areas. Thin theme but an amazing worker placement game.

RATING: 7.1
A sparkling game, but my appreciation outstrips my actual enjoyment of it by a good margin. Yes, the game is fathoms deep; yes, the variation in starting setup and faction abilities offers extraordinary replay value; yes, even the artwork is gorgeous. But resources are so pinched, largely because upgrading beyond a humble dwelling requires losing a previously constructed building. I cannot love such a miserly game, especially when the theme, though present in some attenuated intellectual sense, is in no way palpable.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
exciting complex development game. the hansa teutonica style development of taking cubes off the board and revealing better abilities has an important new twist: here buildings are taken off the development board, but when a building is replaced by another(upgrade) on the main board it goes back to the development board. The effect is that if no further development happens until the next round then a resource that is revealed on the development board becomes available and now there is less of another resource that is now covered by the building taken back from the main board.
(there are 14 different development boards, there is a special ability on each that can be exploited by development and require different strategies for players to pursue)
the development itself is forked and includes 5 different buildings, and it can provide 4 different resources that can be used to develop terrain, build buildings that form cities on the main board, upgrade water routes (to allow more distant building) and terraforming abilities on the development board and helping climb higher on 4 cult tracks.
building next to an opponent's building could provide a resource to the opponent if (s)he elects to give up victory points - this was an element that vaguely reminded me of Kaivai.
there are 6 rounds. each round the players pick from "bonus" tiles (1 out of 3 a slight resemblance to Puerto Rico), that provide additional resources or victory points.
at game set-up round cards(replayability) selected (6 of 8). for each round they show available scoring opportunities and cult track climbing bonus resources for that round.
cities that form from 4 neighboring buildings are scored in-game.
at the end of the game continuous network of buildings of players are compared and the three largest are scored. each cult track also score three of the highest climbers.
I enjoyed the game, it has the elements of a nice meaty euro with enough player interaction without too much confrontation. The game is best with 5 fast, experienced players (should play well under 3 hours) , it is also great with 4 and good with 3. I would avoid playing it as a 2 player game. Avoid AP players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of my favorite games. Just don't get to play it much.

RATING: 7
Building euro with asymmetric player powers. The asymmetric player powers are by far the most interesting thing about this game, as they inform players' playstyles. Otherwise it seems to be a solid but not outstanding build-economy-and-buildings game.

The power mechanic seems to be needless innovation, although it looks nice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's got resource management, which is probably the main push of the game. You need to maintain a balance between your different resource generations and getting your higher value buildings out. It's sort of area control, since you are competing with other players for space on the board, but not being isolated benefits you, so it encourages a certain amount of conflict and cooperation.  The different player powers really do make the game more interesting since there are many ways the powers can interact with each other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.65
What I love most about this game are the mechanisms. The terraforming and the power points system are the original things, but the best part is how the mechanisms interact and the effect they create. The art and graphic design are very nice and the gameplay feels faster than it really is. Also, the races are very different, the game is really asymetric.

Playing Terra Mystica requires a balance between strategic long term planning and tactic optimization of each turn. There's some degree of randomness caused mainly by the actions of the other players: The initial start points and expansion of the rest of the players will affect you greatly; but also, the order of the turn tiles will benefit some races more than others.

Overall, it didn't seem that complex to me. I thought the competition for spots and actions was going to be more tight and the decisions much harder. There's indirect interaction, the kind of interaction that spices up the game, but doesn't allow players to gang upon someone; still, it will not be enough interaction for some players.

People complain about the turn markers dictating your strategy. I don't agree, they offer you some points in order to deviate or adapt your strategy. This is part of the cool stuff about this game.


Some things I didn't like:
-> The map has real balance issues. Some terrain types have very easy expansion points and some others will make life very difficult. And this seems to be a VERY IMPORTANT issue.
-> Snowball effect. If you fall behind early, you will be out of the win race for good.


Maybe I will improve my rating if the things I dislike prove to be less serious than I think. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The undefeatable champion of Spiel 2012.

Dennis Lohausen has made an amazing job on the user interface: Absolutely everything (actions, prices, conversions, tech tree, special powers, starting resources, etc.) is shown on the boards using very clear graphical presentations and in an easily digestible way. (Except for the end game resource scoring and the 1-step priest track action; Also, the action summary card seems like a rush job since it's not even grouped by the type of resource needed.)

All these visual cues are definitely needed, since the game is very complex and has lots of details that are easy to forget. I would recommend not trying the game with people who tend to do rules mistakes on first playings. Even though in this game, forgetting something usually punishes the ignorant player only, and leaves others unscathed.

Rating is very likely to rise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Scatolone pesante dovuto ai grezzi 'edifici' di legno, tabellone non particolarmente curato o accattivante. Così si presenta Terra Mystica. Poi si aprono le plance delle diverse razze (14 tipi) che sono studiate molto bene. Perfette anche le illustrazioni che rendo immediata la comprensione dei poteri e il gioco risulta completamente indipendente dalla lingua. Le razze asimmetriche con poteri e setup differenti rendono il gioco molto longevo e originale. Ogni razza dovrà terraformare i territori adiacenti rendendoli abitabili per la propria popolazione. Il bilanciamento tra le razze così differenti e le diverse strategie per fare punti vittoria rendono il gioco molto vario e coinvolgente. L'interazione apparentemente assente è invece forte sia nel piazzamento iniziale che nella scelta dei favori...  Un gioco profondo dalla durata non eccessiva che necessita di buona pianificazione. A mio avviso il miglior gioco del 2012.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

It doesn't help in being an amalgam of borrowed mechanics with barely anything original of its own. I'm happy to play it a few times and experiment with the various races. But each one seems to have a pre-set strategy, and the lack of direct conflict does little to prevent that.

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game. It has so many strategic layers, and though it may not be as technically "deep" as TI:3 or some other heavy wargames, it has a lot more personal strategic element to it. How are you, personally, going to play all of the cogs correctly this game to come out ahead? All the pieces are laid out for everyone to see. There is no hidden information factor. Thats what I find so impressive about this game design. It is so elegant - a game with nothing hidden - everything is right there for each other player to see and figure out. It is Chess^2.

RATING: 8.9
Score after first two games. Score will be updated later. Rised to 8.3 after third play. I lost 2 out of my 3 games. 

Score increased to 8.7 after 5th play. I lost 4 out of 5. Become second in 3 of my loses. What a great game. Nearly perfect game design. Its like a modern time chess. It has a great community and online play & tournaments/leagues.

Score increased 8.8 after 7th play (4 online-3 offline). Now I got 3 wins:)

Score increased to 9.0 after tons of online play, online tournaments and leagues. What a great pure strategy game. Huge replayablity. Not very complex rules. My first score of 9.

Score updated to 9.1 after maybe 60th play, (50 online). This game is awesome!

Score decreased to 8.9. Maybe it is not that much fun. It is pure strategy game. To pass 9 it should be also very fun to play.

Latest update : I still play game. Especially online tournaments. I completed 62 games online. I won 18 of them(29%), at 25 of games I become 2nd (41%). All played 4 players. This game is best at 4 players. Even you are better than other players you can lose a game. A bit luck and player reaction is involved, every decision can change result in game easily. These are not so bad. My online rating is 1132 after 62 game. I expect it should be around 1200. I was a bit unlucky at lots of game. I am sure I will be 1200 rating soon. I will edit here then.

Edit 28/3/16 : I finally got rating which I deserved after 90th play. My current rating is 1217. Maybe 1250s in future but I do not deserve 1300s. Anyway my rating is not important of course at online terra mystica. This game is simply best.

RATING: 8
[b]Terra Mystica[/b]

[i]- The first thing you get is your own faction to play, each with a very distinctive set of powers/ play style.
- This game is heavy, but it does not take long to understand how the game works.
- There are a lot of variables in the game which will make each game a unique experience. 
- There is so much you want to do, but your actions are limited really forcing you to focus on how you are going to score points.
This particular aspect of the game reminds me of Agricola and is something that I personally love in games.

I've loved every play of this so far and my older daughter is getting to the point were I think she could handle playing it. If it played well with 2 it would already be in my collection, as of now I'm probably going to probably wait. I'd like to get a play in with my kids before buying it, maybe I can get a game in with my kids and Mat.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A dozen plays in, the replay value is still very high. The more you play, the more you see what others are trying to do and the more you start to try and mess with them. Yes, it's hard to completely hose the other guy, but Terra Mystica is more a game of paper cuts - make your opponent pay more / do something in a less effective manner enough times and by the end of the game you've gotten more bang for your buck.

Wonderful design. Shines with 5, which is a not insignificant feat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
種族變化不少
各種不同的起始會有不同的打法
挺有趣的遊戲
規則:
*起始各種族拿對應圖板跟建築物，起始20分，起始資源看種族圖板(還有宗教軌位置)，魔力軌12顆按圖版數字放置
*隨機起始，回合板塊隨機(最後兩回合不能是鏟地加分)，最後一回合沒信仰收入，每回合獎勵板塊也隨機按人數一開始選好(人數+3張)
*正常選種族方式，回合獎勵板塊選完後，由起始玩家開始選種族，放房子由起始開始放一輪，再由尾家開始放第二輪(渾法最後放)，之後由尾家開始選獎勵板塊，沒被選的上面放一元
*分數來源
1.回合板塊上的獎勵動作
2.獎勵板塊上當你pass的結算建築分數
3.信仰板塊當你蓋建築或pass有建築的分數
4.形成城鎮分數
5.升級航行跟鏟地能力
6.遊戲結束，地最大連結排名給分18-12-6，各信仰排名8-4-2
7.3元1分
*遊戲進行六輪，最後計分，每輪三個階段
1.收入階段 個人圖板收入，獎勵板塊收入，信仰板塊收入
-獲得能魔力一定都是從最低的往上提，只有1沒有才能轉2到3，只有3的能用，用過就跳回1，
2.行動階段 八行動可選，沒動作想做就pass拿獎勵板塊，第一個pass的成為下輪起始玩家
A 建築 付錢建築在你的相連(直接或間接)顏色地上，轉地形要花鏟子，可藉由工人轉換，獲得多的鏟子時除了轉換你要蓋的土地，可再多轉相鄰的但是不能蓋，只能轉換建築物相鄰的土地，魔力或獎勵板塊獲得的鏟子可配合工人增加來鏟到想要地形，回合獎勵的不行
-鏟地要做完，才能蓋房，不能交替做
-靠航行相連的都視為間接相鄰，橋視為直接
B 升級航行軌 獲得分數
C 升級鏟地效率 獲得分數
D 升級房子 升級到交易所該房如果有跟其他人相鄰只要3元，升級到聖殿或神廟都可獲得一信仰板塊，同種板塊不能重複拿
-當相鄰的人蓋房或升級房子時，所有相鄰的建築物根據自己建築魔力可拿魔，並扣魔力-1分，要拿就要全拿，可不拿，但如果到頂，則分數依然之扣魔力-1
-信仰軌頂格只能有一個人，要上去也要拿到城鎮鑰匙，一個只能上一個
E 送僧侶去信仰軌 可選擇拿回僧侶前進一格(回來的要再供應區)
F 魔力行動 每個動作每回合只能被做一次
-魔力可隨時按表上轉換成僧侶工人或錢，不算行動，僧侶工人錢也可向下轉
-可移除一顆魔力把一顆往上提，不算行動
G 獎勵卡 或種族特殊行動
H pass 第一個成為下輪起始，拿場上現有的獎勵板塊並還上次的，下位玩家可以拿你還得
*城鎮形成 四棟以上直接相鄰(神廟可三棟)，魔力超過七
3.信仰軌獎勵跟清除階段 根據回合板塊跟信仰軌狀況獲得獎勵，所有行動重置，獎勵板塊上放一元，當回合板塊翻面
*異教徒 如果沒人要魔力時，自己獲得一個魔力
*****平衡起始分數 基礎地圖****
15 Darklings魔族
16 Cultists異教徒
16 Engineers工程師

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A mini-review I posted to https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/111229977945579240171/stream/7962fa50-b545-49b3-92b5-c8e579218f06

Okay so who wants to know all about Terra Mystica? Here's the straight poop.

First off, what you probably already know: asymmetrical area-control cube pusher. Very euro-style. Indirect interaction, largely in the form of thwarting one another's efforts while grinding out solutions for your turn. There's a fantasy theme that isn't pasted on, but it's also not really deeply integrated into the game either. Two to 5 players, allegedly 30 minutes @ player (not tonight; five of us took 3.5 hours to play).

Here's what you don't probably already know: all that asymmetry adds up to a really deep exploration of strategies and tactics. So far I have played 3 of the 14 races that come with the base set: The nomads and witches in a couple 2p games, and the much-hated giants in our 5p game tonight. Each game felt substantially different. 

The learning game is a set starting map setup, with pre-chosen scoring tiles and pre-chosen bonus tiles. These tiles are where all the replayability and "randomness" lies -- all other information is 100% open, which may make you bonkers or it may be awesome. Dunno. 

Each turn, your race gets a bunch of different assets: money, workers, priests and power. Power is interesting, and it's not like...magical power, not really. It's more like, I don't know, social influence maybe. Hard to say. It's the least themed element of the game and also the most interesting: Everyone has 12 little purple chits indicating their total power, and it gets cycled between three different "bowls", until it settles into the third and final bowl, where it can be used and returned to bowl 1. What the fuck are these bowls? What the fuck is this power? Doesn't matter; the actual economy of it is very clever, and forces interesting decisions all game long.

On your turn, you get one action. You have a little menu with eight options, but many of those eight options themselves have subsets of options. For example, there's a set of eight sub-actions that can be taken only once each round, which is why you want to be first player: first come first served. I think on any given turn, I was evaluating between five and twelve actual choices. I'd put this in the "pretty heavy" category.

Scoring happens throughout the game, according to the order of "scoring tiles" you drew to start the game. You get paid for building certain kinds of buildings, or terraforming the terrain into something more hospitable to your people. I think there are other things that pay you but I can't remember what they are off the top of my head. So that shapes a lot of play right there: the turn were you get 5 veeps for building your biggest buildings, expect to see most people angling to do just that.

There are other scoring opportunities as well, mostly keyed into "cult favors" you earn by building sacred buildings (temples and your sanctuary). I think a couple races have bonus scoring as well. Like...the witches, I think, get paid extra points for completing towns. Why do witches want to build towns? Who knows! Some of the thematic decisions are head-scratchers.

At the end of the game, you have some more scoring opportunities: biggest contiguous civilizations, and control over each of the four elemental cults, and leftover money you might not have spent. It's all pretty straightforward and like I said, there is no hidden information. 

I thought the game was pretty fun, in a very euro kind of way. There's very little drama to the game, no sudden surprise swings or bold incursions. It's super-thinky, especially as the game moves into its final round or two. Probably the most "fun" plays are where you thwart someone's delicate plans by taking the last town, or the one opportunity for money, or whatever. I think this is definitely in the category of games that a very small, very very hardcore group will delve into so deeply that it may cease to be "fun" for more casual players (like the hardcore Through the Ages folks, for example). 

In terms of design, it feels very much evolutionary and not revolutionary. I can see signs of all kinds of prior designs hidden throughout the game. It all works very well! The materials are clear, the procedures are unambiguous. There are a few dumb little edge cases you have to memorize having to do with individual racial abilities, and I do not love that. It's also the kind of game where each of the three rather simple "phases" of play actually require you review lots and lots and lots of fiddly little steps, and it's very easy to forget one here and there. It was never game-breaking but was still annoying to know we had probably fucked things up several times.

I'd rank this one a very solid 7, possibly moving up to an 8 due to all the exploratory opportunities. I am very much looking forward to digging deeper into it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game I can admire, and appreciate why many people rate it as high as they do. It's a simple game of expanding your territory and building on your territories. And then it gets complicated because there's a ton of ways to go about it. Each building provides a different type of income. The twist they pull is that to build a new building you must upgrade it from an older building. You get the new type of income, but the old building goes back into your supply and you lose the type of income it was previously providing. There are multiple currencies, each used for different things, so losing worker income means less buildings, losing power income means less spells, etc. So you're trading off what currencies you want to earn in. And of course there's a ton of ways to score points, so it becomes an efficiency game ... if I do this, then I get this, but I no longer get that, so I won't be able to do that. And you cycle through a bunch of options to determine which nets you just one more VP (end-game), or provides you better options during the mid-game. So don't play with AP'ers, it'll drive you mad. While I like having a ton of options to explore, efficiency decisions for minor gains aren't a lot of fun, and neither is the downtime they induce for your opponents. The theme is tacked on and doesn't provide an edge, making this a pure abstracty Euro, so while I'd rate it higher for the game space it provides, a few issues for me give it a slightly lower rating. While I wouldn't mind playing if it was at the table, I'm not itching to.

RATING: 8
Mix Agricola, Catan, and a Feld game together, add in handfuls of variable player powers, top it off with a fantasy theme, and the resulting game might feel like Terra Mystica. Steep learning curve. Much replayability. 20 to 30 minutes per player.

As quality a production this is, as beautiful and well-designed this is, the theme/story doesn't come out enough for me, making this feel more mechanically abstract than fun.

I wish someone would design an app for this!!

I have had to up my rating quite a bit. This is a game I've played a lot lately, and never grow tired of.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In Terra Mystica you choose from one of 14 factions and you terraform, build, expand and upgrade your buildings on hex terrain map along side other players (factions) while also trying to compete (climb) on 4 cult tracks (religion). For that on your disposal you have 4 different resources: money, workers, priests and power. 
Power is quite fresh way of resource collecting and management. You have 3 rondels. When you get power you move power first from rondel 1 to 2 and then from rondel 2 to 3. When you spend power you are spending it only from rondel 3 back to rondel 1. You are getting power actually by building close to other players among other things. So game awards building close to other players.
Game is played over 6 rounds. Every round has randomly selected round tile with bonus points for some specific thing you can do and bonus for specific cult track position at the end of round. There are also bonus tiles (special actions, extra income,...) picked every round after passing, favor tiles which you get if you build "religious" buildings and there are tiles for founding cities which is automatic when your connected territory expands to prescribed size.
When you learn rules for this game it may seem a bit daunting but after you start playing everything is quite intuitive with the great help of visual representation of board and player boards. Actually game is quite simple in what you can do which is essentially: terraform and build (expanding your territory or starting new settlement), upgrade one of your building and going higher on cult track with a help of your resources which you get through also simple ways. But heaviness and replayability of it lies in 14 different factions who have small differences between each other regarding special rules but great difference in playing the game. You have to take advantage of your faction characteristics to win the game while being aware what other factions in game weaknesses and strengths are and how to take advantage of randomly selected round and bonus tiles.
Interaction in this game is how i like it it's there but not totally "screw up your friend" kind.
Components are great and game is visually stunning. 
If you like euro games, just go buy this game.
The best game of 2013 and one of the best games off all times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
3-4 players, 5 okay if players experienced

Also Fire and Ice expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good game - some fairly simple mechanics to grasp but so many different strategic choices to make. One of our group's favourites.

On the down side - it is possible to make mistakes early on that can completely remove you from the running even thought you have another hour's gameplay left. It is very easy to run low on power/priests/workers and find your options severely limited.

Some of the races are very hard to get the best out of too. Not as balanced as they first appear no matter what all those 'experts' who have played 100 games claim.

I also think I'd prefer less ways to score but more complex interaction between the various elements.

It isn't very combative either - there isn't a whole lot you can really do to mess with other players if they know what they are about.

Housekeeping and adding of scores is messy too.

Overall though, this game has a nice feel and the great range of races gives us lots to go back and try out. Plenty of learning too, which is mostly fun.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a building game in which you're trying to build the various buildings on your player board to increase your income, Hansa Teutonica style.  The higher-level buildings have increased costs and require you to replace lower-level buildings, which will send the lower-level buildings back to your board and thus increase your income in some ways, but decrease it in others.  The game encourages players to get in each other's way, as there are significant bonuses for being next to an opponent.  Turning this all into points is the tricky part, because while some of your points may come from having an impressive city during endgame scoring, most of your points will come from performing certain actions during certain turns, taking roles that may not be as beneficial income-wise, or using your special ability.  Oh yeah, and there are 14 distinct races each with their own special ability, that will really define how you play the game.  There's a lot going on here, and I love every bit of it.

(5+ plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

it makes for painful choices.  Some races aren't as good as the others, but I play those with less experienced folks.

RATING: 9
Rather heavy euro game with really straightforward mechanisms. Trying to connect 1 and 1 though is the tough part. I feel like this game can be best described as Kingdom Builder meets Small World with a dash of Puerto Rico and a scoop of Settlers of Catan. 

I really like how different all the races are and I feel like you could easily get 14 plays out of the game without breaking a sweat and that's not even playing each race more than once. Lots to explore and seems to play better with more players. Really want to dig deep into this one.

I see this game rising in rating for me. It's good but it has a ton of potential that I don't think I've even remotely seen. I've already tried a couple completely different strategies and all have seemed to have done fairly well. Hopefully I can bring this week after week to FFG to get in more plays of it.

Includes 4 Stadtmarker promo tiles and Meeple Realty insert.

An instant classic! Very, very impressive.

RATING: 7.5
Terra mystica is what most would consider a "Heavy" euro game. I've played it quite a few times and with every play you develop new strategies to win victory points, but your strategy will mainly depend on the race you use and the turn tokens (selected randomly). Learning to play isn't that difficult, however, I highly recommend playing Catan, Puerto Rico and Agricola before getting your hands on TM. What I dislike the most and the reason I'm giving the game a 9 is that setup time is pretty long due to the amount of tokens and ziplocks you need to open.

EDIT 10/04/2015: After several plays with the same group we have started losing interest in the game, it does not have the same staying power as other games. Mainly due to the set up time.

RATING: N/A
Cults & priests
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I didn't understand this game at first.  It seemed to me to be a city-building game or a resource management game, and initially it looked like nothing more than multiplayer solitaire...until you get good at it.

There are in essence two types of scoring in this game - in-game and end-game scoring.  In-game scoring occurs during your turn as you accomplish tasks related to your player board, the role tokens, and the turn-based rewards.  Endgame scoring rewards long-term investments for largest contiguous bloc of building, towns erected, and favor chart advancement.  

All of our early games were determined by in-game scoring.  Players who were efficient scored gobs of points, and while they also excelled at endgame scoring, the game was decided long before those were awarded.  We all struggled just to get our own things done, and that dominated our planning.  We barely looked at each other except two of us obviously needed the same hexes.

After we understood the game, all of the games are determined by end-game scoring.  We finally came to understand that the game is all about who controls which hexes, blocking each other, and controlling pivotal hexes.  In-game scoring flattened, and the games started to look like train games...building networks (long routes indirectly connected and foursomes directly connected) and investing in stock (the favor tracks, which pay out critical VPs at the end and dividends in the form of power in-game). 

There's nothing "multiplayer solitaire" about this game.  If you're not actively attacking the formations of other players to prevent them from growing their networks, you haven't learned how to play yet. 

Top game.  Raising my rating to 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A pure resource management game, with 4 types of resources that can be converted into each other, one more flexibly than others. It's all rather abstract, arbitrary, and not very realistic (like converting deserts to swamps). No feeling at end that I developed a civilisation. The mechanics are good (although not original) but that's all: going through the usual motions, no theme. Plus, it took us 4h, incl. setup, rules explanation and cleanup. Not a game for me, sorry.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wonderful, complex web of resource management and choices, so many choices. Nothing is done in a simple, elegant way, but everything offers multiple directions.

Q: So what do I get again, when I build a temple?
A: Whatever you want: Pick one of twelve different bonus tiles.

Q: So how do I get money again?
A: Well, in one of six different ways...

Even gaining victory points depends on your race, the turn, and bonus tiles. And they're different every game.

There's no limit to how many or how few actions you can take: simply continue until your resources are spent, or pass early and carry everything over to next round. A lot of choices, few restrictions.

There's plenty of competition, but also lots of ways to simply happily build without people getting in your way. It's always possible to advance your position, but to see what to do when, takes skill and experience.

Because the basis is building dwellings and upgrading them to trading posts, to gain the resources you need to keep building, the game is not actually all that hard. You don't have to focus on everything, and your race and the turn bonus will give you some direction on what to do. There are also plenty of 'accidental bonuses'. You may build a trading post for the extra money, but you also get extra power which gives you the option to maybe build a bridge. Oh, and you're one step closer to a city, which gives you more bonuses. There's always plenty to do.

Lots of freedom, lots of options, building and expanding without many restrictions or frustrations, and you're still heavily invested in what your opponents are doing. And every game will be totally different.

Recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very engaging. A lot going on and lots of interesting decisions to make at every turn. But not for those who don't like long games (4 hours with 3-4 players).

RATING: 10
Favourite game at this moment. 

It's one of those games where you can always find ways to get points.  If someone builds where you were going to build then you will most likely get power, which will then benefit you on your turn.  

There are bonus tiles that you get to choose from each round, the same person can't hoard the same bonus tile for the whole game either which evens the playing field.

My favourite game to this point was Agricola, but I think that taken that spot for now.  We'll see if the rating changes after a few plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
Rating after 3 plays. Game has dropped from a 9 to a 7.5 for me. Although a basically good, thinky, strategic game. This game suffers from the downfall of all games with variable player powers; it creates far too many questions that aren't addressed in the rules. When these questions are addressed by the designers in the rules forums it has led to inconsistencies between the factions. (Ex. Halflings CAN overpay shovels to gain terraforming VP bonus; Dwarves/Fakirs CAN NOT tunnel/fly to a space that is adjacent to currently occupied space for additional VP -- both pay additional resources to do something but I have to REMEMBER which faction can do the illogical thing to gain VP.) I prefer a game that doesn't require me to remember arbitrary rules about who can do what different in what situation. I sat down to play a Euro not a thematic game.

Bottom Line: Increased Factions = Reduced Elegance

I am also not convinced that certain factions are not more powerful than others. I have played three games with players of equal experience. The green faction has won all three games (2 Witches/1 Auren). The green faction was played by a different player in each game! If you look at the board, it appears green has the opportunity to start with a much stronger board position than any other faction. 

Good game but not great. Luster will soon fade. Doubt it will be remembered 5 years from now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.901
What a game !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[floatleft][ImageID=1450866][/floatleft][b][u]Initial Impressions:[/u][/b]
As of late I have subscribed to the Cult of the Old. I make very little effort to follow whats trending at Essen, nor do I go out of my way to seek out the new and exciting games to try. I figure if a game is worthy of my consideration someone else will bring it to my attention. Terra Mystica (TM) is one such game that was off my radar but was recommended to me by someone else. I knew nothing about this game before sitting down to play it, but I sure am glad that I did. TM clicked for me instantly because the rules made sense, the mechanism interactions seemed amazingly fluid, and strategies appeared to be boundless. Right out of the gate TM is high in my ratings and I could easily see it becoming one of my favorite games. I look forward to more plays of this game.

[floatright][ImageID=1450485][/floatright][b][u]What I like:[/u][/b]
The thing that really sets TM apart from other games is the Power system and the Bowls of Power. Having magic in a game isn't anything new but the way TM handles gathering the Power is just so damned inventive. I really like the "staging" of the power between bowls where power is only usable in the 3rd bowl but you can burn power from bowl 2 for a quick boost at the loss of overall total power. It's freaking brilliant.

The best twist of this game is that players gain power by building adjacent to each other. This basically encourages people into their own mutually assured destruction. If you want power you need to build adjacent to your opponents but that is a double edged sword because you are restricting your ability to expand easily and you are also giving your adjacent opponents power in return. 

[b][u]What I dislike:[/u][/b]
I really dislike the rule book. Its good for learning but trying to look up something specific can be difficult.

[b][u]Overall:[/u][/b]
I know I love this game but with the infrequency that I get to actually play this its hard to internalize the rules. Despite only getting this to the table once in a blue moon I have bumped my rating to a 10. The TM app that just came out might help with keeping the game fresh in my mind.

[i]Nomads are a$$holes.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
P: 2-5, T: 1-2 hr, KenSdJ-N
+No luck outcomes, all based on player decisions. Many paths to victory and paying attention to other players actions. Encourages many strategies and adapting to game conditions mid-game. Scoring round tiles and different factions keep things different every time. Interesting decisions about building proximity to opponents.

=Not as good with 2. Strategy trumps tactics

-Some factions seem unbalanced
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Impressive resource management game where all the mechanics flow smoothly into the other mechanics. It scales really well being just as fun with 2 as it is with 5. I love the dynamic where you both want to be next to your opponents to benefit by taking power from their constructions, and you want to be far away from them so you can have enough room to build and expand. Each player board has an option of two different factions to play, which gives the game a ton of replayability. Unfortunately, to play the game well, you really need to have already played your faction once before, and on top of that not all the factions are completely balanced with each other. This was sort of addressed in the expansion, where they expect players to bid for the faction board they want, which is a terrible solution as it requires people to be so familiar with the different strengths that it's not a reasonable amount of information for a new, or even not so new player to have on hand at the start of the game.

Gameplay wise, the game also suffers from forcing you to focus in on 'that thing' you are supposed to be doing with your faction, rather than explore your options creatively.

:star: Art, Iconography and components functional
:star: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:nostar: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Raw enjoyment

Very good and complex game partly similar to puertorico or agricola but far more abstract in components and therefore not very intuitive and hard to learn as you would fight with components (what represents this generic shaped wooden piece?). Replayability is in trying new factions that each has 1-2 unique abilities passive or active but they do not feel balanced at all but game board is unfortunately only one and with fixed layout. This game would be great with better and more distinctive components.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
There are a lot of moving parts so the game takes a while to explain. However it was fairly easy to play in practice. It is a fairly long game, and I could see that analysis paralysis could be an issue. Most victory strategies are visible throughout the game ie what buildings score this turn, the elements, building towns especially the largest town. 

On your turn you have a multi-tier economy (workers/money/monks) to spend converting terrain to your liking and building various structures which provide income and other bonuses. The interesting part it the most structures are built as an upgrade, recycling the old structure. The other economy is power that has cyclical mechanic which accumulates and after a point can be burned as a substitute for other actions. This is a nice mechanic.

Game variability is provided by the races, I think I would prefer to randomly assign the cards rather than allow a player to always choose the same race. Not much in your face competition, it is mostly through cutting off town growth which is one of the victory points. The focus on the game is managing all the various currencies against your land and building development and what is being rewarded on that turn.

Ultimately this style of repetitive efficiency with all sorts of moving parts to hit the game turn targets just doesn't attract me.
Friend calls it best as Terrible Mystica

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Terra Mystica did not disappoint. This is an excellent game that I may up to a 10 with further plays. As is, this has everything I want in a game: Many paths to victory, variable set up, unique player powers leading to great replayability. I can't wait to play this more often and further explore this game. 

The one drawback I have is that is that it seems difficult to learn. The player boards and iconography are great, but mostly seem to assist with remembering. There isn't much in this game that intuitively happens, so the first game was pretty much grasping how everything works. This isn't really an issue for me as I plan to play my games plenty, but this isn't the sort of game I'd bother playing with anyone who just wanted to try it once and didn't plan to play ever again. 

Still, the actual gameplay on this one is great and well worth the time for Euro lovers to experience. There is an app rumored to be coming out in early 2017, and I am eagerly awaiting it now so I can play more regularly. 

UPDATE: Moving this from a 9 to a 10. It's well deserving of hitting that point. There is so much strategic depth in this game and so many ways the game can play out, all while being pretty easy to grasp after the first game. Not to mention the variable factions offer a lot of replayability as well.

RATING: 10
What should be by right the most drab game is without a doubt one of the best puzzles assembled in a box. Intriguing, witty and quick, Terra Mystica might just be the ultimate Euro in the way it serves up a deliciously varied strategy game that has everything from end game bonuses to asymmetric player powers. It doesn't even take that long to play, and you won't notice the time passing as it absorbs you during your other player turns. Love how clever the concept of getting power is, which negates the rather tacked on cult board.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The biggest surprise of recent years and my boardgaming Grail. This is hands down the best medium-heavy eurogame I have ever played - an amazing, elegant design with huge replayability. And to think I almost passed on this one! Never bothered to try it, because I've heard opinions it's not so good with 2p (and that's how we play most of the time). But then got it as a Christmas gift and what a gift it was!

So what's so good in it? 1. Multiple factions and variable player powers. 2. Not too long. 3. Random scoring conditions in the setup, no luck element later on. 4. Strategic and tactical at the same time. 5. Gives a great feeling of fulfilment when you're creating your little empire. 6. An ideal amount of interaction for such a brainburner (you CAN screw other people, but there's no direct confrontation). And the mechanics are just lovely! Exchanging low level buildings with the high level ones means you really need to plan well and time the conversion, and the power mechanic introduces some interesting dillemas - you want to be very close to other players, but you still need space to expand.

Still, words can't convey the warm, pleasant feeling of your brain burning in every single turn of this wonderful affair. This is definitely my "what game would you take on a desert island" type of thing. Just can't get enough of it! Cons? It is a bit less exciting with 2p, but still great, and the theme is paper thin - but who would expect theme here anyway...

RATING: 7
The strategy in this can be very allusive but the game is incredibly fun and deep. 
My only complaints are that the races are not balanced evenly and that the way turn order works is stupid like Agricola and not awesome like Caylus (both of those complaints will be addressed in the expansion).
~11/05/14 

The lack of balance in the faction is very frustrating. I realize that the base games faction balance is pretty good considering the number of factions but it is not as good as I would like. The game is already complicated enough to make it difficult to know why I am doing well or poorly. Having some factions be really good and some really poor is a major bummer. I had hoped that the expansion would improve this but it did not. It made it worse. Instead of adding some fun well balanced factions it provided factions that are at the top and the bottom of the charts. That is the worst kind of expansion. So frustrating. I really wouldn't mind if i didn't play this again. If they adjust the factions enough on Snellman to get them more balanced then my tune would likely change quite a bit. 
~6/22/15

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If your group craves both complexity and quick turns, this is your game.  I've played this game at least 100+ times with different player counts, and almost everyone (of people who like the more complex games) is a big fan.  Once everyone gets a few plays in, it's also pretty good with a few drinks (unless you're super competitive and want to win).

I have to give this game a perfect 10, something I very rarely do.  I really have a hard time finding anything wrong with this game.
Pros - 
Player conflict is not direct, so no one has a very competitive rivalry to make them angry.
Downtime with experienced players is minimal because turns are very short.
You can easily plan actions on other players turns because their actions most of the time do not have much affect on you (but when they do, it can really hurt or help)
Almost no luck at all involved in the game, which means people can't get screwed over by dice.
Component quality is amazing, this game weighs like 5 pounds
Rules seem complicated, but after 1 play you realize they are very straightforward and leave almost no need for any FAQ to address weird scenarios (like fantasy flight games :O)
Play time with experienced players is not incredibly long, but the game keeps you interested the whole time either way

Cons-
Direct Player interaction is very minimal in comparison to other games, but this doesn't hurt this game due to other factors
Too many options during your action, sometimes it's really hard to choose
Not investing in something early in the game can sometimes really hurt you for victory points.
Some races seem way better than others (this has been statistically proven, Faqirs are literally un-playable if you want to win)

Although I did list some cons, they don't really seem to hurt gameplay that much, and I realize that no one game can be perfect in every way.  It's just that this game is probably the closest to a perfect 10 I will ever see, which is why I give it a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2017-12-07
This is such a wonderful design! 
This game has so much depth, none other could compete with it in my opinion. Everything counts.
- The initial draft for races is a game in itself. You have to consider the available bonus tiles, the available scoring tiles and the order of them, your opponent's choices - just everything!
- then there is the order in which you take your actions. You have to think with your opponent's head, your have to predict, what she is going to do, and plan accordingly. 
- already at the very beginning it must be clear which are the hot spots on the map. 
- When you pass is also highly important. It defines turn order for next turn, so it is important to anticipate when your opponent pass. Sometimes it is better to forfeit an action or two just to be the start player next turn. 
- There are so much more: the scarcity of the recourses, the favor tiles, the different player powers add so much to the game.
- Player powers: it is boardgaming best puzzle to tinker with them, to try to find the best possible strategy with each of them.
I think this is a game with depth enough to warrant strategy guides in book format; you couldn't tell that about too many games. 
True, the art is more practical than beutyful, but who cares...
A modern classic!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My favorite aspect of Terra Mystica is just how many factions I can choose from. I like the idea of trying a different strategy every time I play. That being said, I don't love this game as much as my gaming group. The style of the board is reminiscent of my least favorite games- same old tired wooden bits connected across hexes, etc. 

In the end, I always enjoy playing Terra Mystica, but I can't ever see it being a favorite unless an expansion adds something more. The terraforming mechanic was a great start, but as it stands, it's a great game that needs to find more identity.

RATING: 9.6
Good game.  Deep, but not overly complex.  The "right" course of action is fairly obvious and driven by the bonus tiles for that round.  But being as efficient as possible is not easy.

Need to balance town creation, maximizing bonus each round, building the 'right' buildings to maximize bonuses, manage the amount of resources spent on the cult tracks effectively, etc... etc....

Good, engaging Euro.  Recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game is awesome! It's all about managing your resources and making the best use of your race. Each game is different in the random power tiles, and the round tiles will always be different (and in a different order). There are many ways to victory, and utilizing each the best way is the only way to win. The game is just an absolute blast, with NO LUCK. It's all strategy. Yes, it can feel like multi-player solitaire, but it's the indirect interaction with players that makes this one shine. Plus, for a heavy game, it plays very quickly. 100 minutes is a very good estimate. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a complex game but very obviously well thought out. Hard to learn what an optimal strategy looks like, really. Like Kingdom Builder in many ways. Much better though.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Description: Euro, engine building, resource management, area control, worker placement, action allowance, civilization building in a fantasy world.
Weight: Heavy (to medium)Euro game. 3 to 4 hours.
Number of players: 2 to 5, best with 4 and 5.

Impression: Game tuned to my taste. Perfect mechanics, perfect game length, perfect complexity, huge replay value. It's a great middle to heavy weight euro brain burner placed in fantasy setting where 14 (20 with expansion) different factions build their empires on different types of terrain through terraformation. Every player has his own type of terrain on which he can build and they are also competing for the favor of gods in 4 cults: Fire, Water, Earth and, who would know it, Air. It is fairly complex, but perfectly designed. The components are beautiful, artwork is quite appealing and most of the factions factions are so perfectly balanced with many paths to victory. Few factions are broken, however, but that is addressed by official rule changes and errata.
People mostly criticize the lack of player interaction. For me, there is pretty enough of it. Although there are no any direct conflicts, we were constantly competing to in a race for different objectives and goals. Also the mechanic where it is much cheaper to expand your city next to other players while it also gives them power points to use their magic is fantastic. The game is just awesome!

Likes: It has 14 conceptually different races (20 with expansion) and choosing your race is a game within game; variable player powers, 3-part variable setup making every game different, cool power point mechanic, 2 different maps, list goes on.

Dislikes: Learning curve is quite steep and not everybody will enjoy that. Some races are so broken they needed official errata and rework.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A masterpiece of area control, euro engine building, and asymmetric player powers melded into a timing-based scoring system. Greater than the sum of the parts, it's like how carbon fused correctly becomes a diamond.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game with lots of replay-ability with so many different races. It's a game on strategic positioning and optimal building and resource management. Many different tracks to victory but certainly the initial placement and plan seems critical.  Each game has been fun so far and abit of a brain-burner.

RATING: 10
