For me, the best game to come out in the last few years. One word of warning - this is a complex one! There's so much going on that there's a danger of rules overload when teaching it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Have Played - K
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've played this game four times. It isn't as 'heavy' as some people suggest and I've seen first-time players win it. It just requires a lot of attention.

It is amusing how the game tries to tempt you (with immediate victory points etc) away from your smooth, sustainable economic pathway.

Player are often competing for tokens, areas etc. It may not provide a lot of 'direct' interaction (but see below), but it does provide a lot of enjoyable tension while you work hard to try to grab whatever you need before your opponents do ... and hope they haven't noticed what you desperately need.

It's one of those games where, afterwards, players burst into conversation about how they could have played more efficiently.

The game gives many players a huge buzz because of how competitive it becomes, especially in the final two turns. You very much feel you've earned your victory.

I like its focus on common recurring abilities/options rather than on things like flipping random tiles etc. It means you can plan ahead quite rigorously, although the 'human randomness' element can force re-planning.

The game provides additional nice opportunities for planning. For example, the first player to decide to end their actions each turn automatically becomes the first player to act in the next turn ... which is great because they know they'll get 'first dibs' at a particular one-use 'power action' etc (which all become available again at the start of each new turn).

It also has excellent iconography etc. It's exceptionally tidily designed.

My only concerns are:
1) No information is hidden in the game. This means that players can begin to play VERY slowly if they are desperate to calculate the best possible move. The speed of the game depends a lot on how competitive players are and how good they are at calculating efficiency with a lot of simply cube-counting etc.
2) Interaction between players is quite low. Having said that, it is a lot of fun when you DO find a good opportunity to mess with another player because it can really damage their chances. A lot of it depends on how much you can be bothered to stare at everyone else's piles of cubes, money, income, buildings etc and calculating their weaknesses and probable actions.
3) You do strategise, but mostly it's about mathematically making the most of your resources.
4) Starting positions/options are an important part of the game. So, if players are very robust throughout the game, the starting positions might largely determine who wins.
5) As others say, it's fairly abstract.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun: 9
Quality: 9
-many options (+3).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Absolutely wonderful game. Fixes problem of many area control games by giving 2 incentives to build next to each other (cheaper TPs & leach). It is enough for people to want to pile up, creating a dilemma between being close to each other vs having a lot of space to expand. I wouldn't play this with 2, since it breaks that. Probably will raise this to full 10 when I have time to play this more (I have played quite lot, but currently my 10 needs a LOT of playing - TS got there after 2000 plays ; Eclipse a lot less (about 100), but all FTF & some with up to 9 people).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Very good modern Euro. High replayability due to the different races (most of them are well balanced). Nice art with excellent iconography. First step is to learn how to build a good economy/many buildings. Second step is to learn how to score points effectively. 

While the scoring at the end is quite thematic (you get points for the expansion of your race or much you praised a certain god, i.e. cults), pretty much all the other scoring is rather abstract and pasted on. This is even true for some race bonuses. So Terra Mystica seems to be a perfect mix of theme and fitting mechanics, but after a while you recognize that the focus is rather on the mechanics. Unfortunately, because of the all the different mechanics this game takes about 40 minutes to explain and usually overwhelms beginners.

While there is some interaction (race to certain spots on the maps, race on the cult tracks, limited mana bonus actions), the major part of the game is solving the puzzle how to accomplish what you want to do this turn. But there is enough interaction to not call TM a multiplayer solitaire game (but the 80% of the time it actually is). I really appreciate that when you look at the board at the game's end, you really think you have created a little kingdom (the typical Catan feeling).

RATING: 6
Yet another baroque conversion machine. Like Hansa Teutonica and Luna, it's a smart, elaborate, abstract euro which offers all sorts of levers to pull. It all works, and the presentation is well thought out.

However, these games will never use a two step process when a three or four step process can be shoehorned into the design. And there's almost no interaction. I have very little desire to play these sorts of games anymore. Yes, euros are abstract. But they used to be elegant as well. The trend towards ever more convoluted VP puzzles leaves me cold. There's isn't any table-talk and joking in our normally garrulous group with Terra Mystica. That's not a good sign.

Another landmark in my growing disenchantment with modern euros and the BGG hype machine.

RATING: 6
An interesting remark was made about the 'cult of the new' and how a particular game might only get one or two plays. It came in the context of this and Ora et Labora and it intrigued me because neither are light games. There is a lot to learn in this sort of game. First there are rules, then once you have mastered the rules (clearly a couple of games) there are all sorts of different game effects that need to be taken on board before you can really begin to think about tactical and strategic problems. It seems an odd situation that as popular games get deeper in terms of their complexity and learning curves most players seem to spend less time playing them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really don't know where to start describing my absolute favourite game - suffice to say that there are dozens of games I really like, and a handful that I love, but that this is head and shoulders above all others. It's hard to explain precisely why, but it is easy to list several of its great features. The no fewer than 14 different factions (or 20 if you have the expansion), all of which play completely differently from each other (and all of which, with perhaps 1 exception, have a chance of winning if the game conditions, randomly chosen when setting up but before players pick which faction to play, are moderately favourable to them). The many different ways the game can be set up (that is, the bonus tiles in play, and the order of scoring tiles) which mean that every game is different, even though the game itself has no hidden information once setup has been completed. The great tension arising throughout over so many things - players vying with each other for key hexes on the board, for the often crucial power actions, for the most advantageous favour tiles, and for the largest network and highest cult positions for endgame scoring. On top of this, there is further player interaction based on wanting to have neighbours (but hoping those neighbours don't steal key hexes from under you!), for cheaper upgrades and more power coming in - as well as the decisions regarding whether to pass early or late to try to get the bonus tile you need for next round. (Those who claim TM is multiplayer solitaire have either never played it or were asleep when they were playing.) The power system itself, which is simple enough but to my knowledge unique and means that spending too much too early might mean you lack the ability to spend lots later in the game. And the resource management headaches over all the resources in the game - while having your income each turn determined by what you have on the board is hardly a novel idea, in TM you really never have enough of every resource you might need, and are forced to plan things sometimes a full turn or more in advance. Until of course another player steps on that plan.

It all adds up to a game which I so far played over 200 times when including both "real life" and online games - I have not tired of it in over 3 years since I first played, and cannot see it ever happening. (And this would be true even without the expansion, although that adds an amazing amount to the game as well.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

All the different factions, scoring tiles, and bonus scrolls add a ton of replayability. It runs a little bit longer than most games my group likes to play, but I'm going to pushing hard for this one every game night for the foreseeable future!

RATING: 6
i'm not entirely sure why this is sooo popular. it's a euro game that does it's job of converting things, network building, converting other things, area control, and upgrading. that it does this with so much asymmetrical struggle and without action points (!!) is certainly to it's credit. but, there's just a heap of complication going on. it's difficult for me to hold a strategy in my head when someone drives a spike into an unanticipated cleft. but, should everything be anticipatable? i suppose it would be only somewhat of a race with much more getting in each other's way if you could otherwise plan out yours and your opponent's moves at the same time. okay, fine fine. but, still, there's so much fiddle! fiddly in the sense of moving a few small wooden pieces each turn and so much going on that seems to be so minor. it's like hunting rabbits: mild petting zoo rabbits, but you're armed only with paper cuts. maybe that's not fair. okay, definitely not fair. but, i guess i'm saying i never really ever feel all that ahead or like i've done something worthwhile in the game. there's room to be clever, but every advance comes with a setback that just keeps it from feeling like an engine builder to me. it's rare to feel like i outsmarted anyone, rather that i managed to make something more expensive. if that's all i wanted, i think i'd rather play Concordia. at least it doesn't have those damn bowls.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
21-09-2015. Surprising for me, I really liked this euro. I am not yet sure why.

In TM you are building towns, upgrading them to other buildings. You get more income the more stuff you have on the board. Each time you place something, you unlock more income. The twist here is that 'your' race of people you're playing, can only live in one type of environment. If you build in a different environment, you have to pay 'shovels' to modulate the area to your favorite environment.

You try to optimize your actions to build correct stuff quickly. If you build certain things, you can get power back. Power is a resource that comes in three levels. If you have lvl 3 power, you can spend it for resources, but it then reverts to leve 1. From there, you can upgrade it back to level 2, and to level 3, but you're only allowed to increase to level 3 until you don't have level 2 stuff.

You score by getting cities, racial abilities, having most points in the 'temple' tracks.

I surprisingly, really, really, really enjoyed this game. There are MANY things to monitor, but the scoring is relatively straight forward. That said, there are ways to compete for scoring. Yes, it's not direct conflict.. and the game came from a slow start but I really enjoyed it.. and I find myself wondering why.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Interesting, puzzley eurogame where you are basically trying to figure out the best way to get your resource engine going with your particular race.  As it's one of the those games where a wrong move early on can cripple you and you learn how you could have avoided your mistakes as the  game progresses, new players often want to play it again to try to get the resource engine right, but I can see it losing its replayability after that relatively quickly. Completely absent of theme (ok, some of the races' abilities are slightly thematic, but many other aspects like priests allowing you to upgrade ships or terraforming are anti-thematic) and relatively little player interaction (there's some competition for which spaces to build), so steer clear if that's what you're looking for. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My favorite game. I love that each faction is so unique, and on top of that, each game varies based on the order of the scoring tiles, as well as what other factions happen to be in the game. It's a different experience every time, and the only game in which there's so much to think about that in the end I can always think back to things I would have done differently in retrospect.

RATING: 9
This game hits all the right spots for me. Variable races with unique powers. Individual player boards. Territory area control. Resource management.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is such a perfect strategy game because there is never any right answer. Every advance you make is causing you to give something up, and every decision has several valid choices.
Do I build a Stronghold this turn, or Wait until I'll get bonus points for building it? Should My Preist go onto the Cult Track so I can dominate there, or Am I better off dropping the cost of my shovels? Do I keep expanding with settlements and so I have lots of workers, or do I lose some settlements so I can build Temples/Trading posts and get Priests or money? 
You also feel like the other players matter. Even in a 2 player game you wont want to build far away from the other player, because that costs more gold. So you are always on top of each-other, blocking each-others plans with your own teraforming actions. 

This is my Favorite BG right now. Even though I lose most games, I always enjoy the experience of playing. In some ways I'm just trying to build a more perfect world each time I play, It's literally impossible to have a 'perfect' game - but it's great to see how close you can get anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.2
Good medium-heavy optimization game with some original ideas and no randomness except for the setup. Not my type though: not thematic enough, some mechanics have no connection with theme, and points are awarded for practically everything, requiring constant careful calculation. Quite penalizing: if you don't think your actions through carefully, you can easily find yourself with no money/workers/power and it's VERY difficult to remedy that. If you like having many options you can't possibly pursue in one game, it might be up your alley.

RATING: 8
I don't remember playing a game for the first time and liking it this much. This is a heavy Euro of building a machine of resources and points, with a high dose of area control. The different races can only build in a certain sort of terrain, where no one else can. So players have to terraform in order to construct, and keep and eye in their rivals in the fight for the best spots and the different ways of scoring points.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
Really enjoyed my first few plays of this, but around play 5 felt the game was formulaic. Not "solvable" but that the strategies of the individual races and the order of the bonus tiles chained you to a strategy. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have very conflicted feelings on this game. As of today, my single playthrough went horribly, it was way too heavy a game for me and I couldn't see ever wanting to play it again. But much like my experience with Panamax, I've had a couple of days to stew on it, reflect on what the mechanics are, think about what I could have and should have done, and am now anxious to try it again to see how I would do after grokking the rules. 

Make no mistake: this is a heavy, HEAVY beast of a game. I can see this being a lifestyle game for some people, with the amount of strategic and tactical depth and crazy replay ability. Is it for me? Not really sure. Were I to buy this, it would probably occupy a space in my collection next to Agricola and Panamax as games that I love but no one will play with me. 

So my current ranking is more of a sign of respect and curiosity to revisit. Will hopefully solidify my feelings soon. Maybe not until after my new-dad brain fog has passed, though. 

Update 2017-01-20: After my second game in which I scored even less points than I did on my first, I realize more of the tactical/strategic errors I made and how I could improve my play. And yet, I think I can accept that this game might not be for me. I have the utmost respect for it mechanically, and I'll be happy to play it any time I'm asked, but I think it's just too heavy for me. But my feelings may change once the app comes out and I can get a few more games under my belt.

Update 2017-06-15: I've now played the app several times and played another game on the table, and I'm bumping my rating from a 7 to an 8. Yes, it's heavy. Yes, there are so many possibilities of what to do on a turn that it's completely overwhelming on the first several plays. But I've now come to respect this as a classic of the Euro genre. The amount of replayability is staggering; every faction plays differently and requires a completely different strategy. The balance of tactical moves and overall strategy is pretty difficult to get on top of... I can't say I'm good at it, but I'm better than I was.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
A lot of mechanics that work very intuitive and simple. 

This is a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat, trying to figure out whether it's better to build a trade post now, or wait for the next round. It's a constant attempt to optimise your path of action. At the same time, the other players do the same. Beware, though. It won't be long before you're in each others way.

For the big rule book and lots of pieces, the gameplay itself works rather quick. With 4 people, the game took about 4 hours (including reading the manual from cover to cover).

RATING: 8.5
Brilliant game. After 2 plays I'm thirsting for more and wanting to try out all the different factions and so on. For such a deep strategy game the rules are surprisingly easy to teach, but of course mastery will be much more difficult to attain - which is as it should be for a great strategy game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A 3X game that removes eXterminate and clunks up the eXplore and eXploit. I love what they did with eXplore, not so much with eXploit.

I've been waiting for a game that does spatial play like that in Settlers of Catan, and Terra Mystica comes very close, with early settlement expansion and a key 'Longest Road' bonus. Towns (clusters of your stuff) remind me of Taluva, another paragon of cool spatial play. But the coolest thing, and unique to this game, is Terraforming. Get digging in that space into your favorite color before you're allowed to settle there, and heck, go dig holes around your opponent's area and not settle yet if you can't afford it yet. It is visually arresting to remake the world in the world-view of your species, as attempted in Dominant Species (but the visual wasn't strong enough there), and it's awesome to shit on your neighbors' garden.

Unfortunately, the economy and player boards are too overwrought for their own good, and it remains to be seen if I can grow to tolerate them. The 'peel off and see which resources you gain now' Euro flavor du jour is totally unnecessary.

What I hate most about this (and lots of Euros) is that you get VPs for everything, including scratching your ass. Heck, this one further devalues the meaning of VPs by letting you lose it to gain magic.

Ah, magic is cool. I like the idea of it in Magestorm, but it got buried there, and it's good for it to gain a wider audience here.

Variable player powers are nice, Dominant Species / Eclipse style (small but significant gameplay-wise).

This game feels like Catan, Taluva and Dominant Species had a threesome (and Hansa Teutonica / Eclipse are uninvited voyeurs with their peel-off player boards).

[hr]

After 5 plays (2 were online), I find the stilted player interaction extremely disappointing. Caring about the others is limited to competing on cult tracks and longest network (puzzle interaction), some timing with drafting bonus tiles (hard to manipulate, more just a bonus if it synergizes), leeching (which is just build-where-opponents-are, that's it), trivial blocking, and drafting power actions. Only the latter is of any value, and even that is just raise your head and trivially check who wants what (you have no coins and you have 4 power in reserve, I see...) or just grab the popular ones that always disappear with the first action each round. This really is an overly strategic game where you spend a ton of time at the start shaping it (including which faction to choose, which is not offered by a lot of other games simply because it's too strategic), then implement it, with your only obstacles being poor math-ing and getting locked out of a power action because you passed too late the previous round. It's not surprising that people brag about their highest scores with each faction, not their win rate, because this is a masturbatory game. I do find the interlocking slightly interesting and will hence tolerate this, albeit purely to show off, not for meaningful enjoyment.

This game could have been so much more, but as it is, Eclipse and Hansa Teutonica are far more fledged-out designs with respect to player interaction and actually being a game, not a puzzle. Lowered design from 4 to 3.

3+2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Oh dear, where do I start?  First off, it's ugly.  The races are nicely rendered, but aside from that, the buildings are plain and the map is blech.  Secondly, there are lots of mechanics that don't seem to go well together.  There was potential right from the get-go for me to have crippled one of my opponents, but I couldn't do that to them as no one wants to spend a three hour game without being able to do anything.  That's a problem.  Also, the races are not well-balanced.  When you get repeatedly told that this race is too good and that one is lousy, that's a big warning sign - asymmetric starts need to be well-done and handled properly and they aren't in TM.

It wasn't that I didn't understand what was going on, it was that I didn't really enjoy what was going on.  I find it very hard to believe that this is the 6th best game on BGG at the time of this writing.  Wow.  It totally devalues the rating system for me.  I think my opinion of this game was higher before I played it.  After playing it, I can certainly think of countless other three-hour games that I'd rather play.  It's just another case of a 5p game that I really didn't like.

If you like fun games, then this is definitely one to avoid, because it certainly wasn't that for me.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
[i]And you may find yourself living inside a spread sheet
And you may find yourself behind a panel with many levers
And you may find yourself in the cogs of a large resource engine
And you may find yourself with beautiful plans making beautiful points.
And you may ask yourself
Well...How did I get here?[/i]

It's amazing in how smoothly everything works and avoids the usual euro clunkiness. Very good at what it does. What it does however is being a humongous resource engine. Period. So you're living inside this huge machine, catering to its demands and needs. Interaction, while there is some, isn't as tight as you always have plans B, C, D when plan A fails. While the game ticks many boxes kinda along the way (a little theme, little blocking, little leeching, little narrative) it's just you and the spread sheet machine. And you have to keep it running.

Other first impressions: races felt pretty samey, even if they probably play differently, I found art to be a bit dreadful, the building aspect is neat, but not where the gameplay is (huh?).

[i]There's too many cubes
Too many meeples
Making too many options
And not much talk to go round
Can't you see
This is a land of confusion.[/i]

After a few days I've finally came to a conclusion: it's the new breed of perfect euro clockwork machines that all purr and hum happily and give a crap about players. The trick these games pull is throwing sand in player's eyes with so much complexity, giving you so much stuff to do, handle, explore that it totally overwhelms a player and give them an impression there's a lot of going on, when it's mostly just racing your own engine (or rather the engine races you, yay). If you check the game's forums you'll also notice the crazy level of optimisation execution this game brings out of people. Sigh. When did our hobby become playing optimisation puzzles? When did somewhat enjoyable become good enough? It works. So what?. As always: the system works because you work.

RATING: 6.5
Played twice. A very ambitious and heavy Euro which offers 14 different races for players to choose and play to their strengths. I actually like that idea, as it gives a lot of room for players to explore the variety of strategies in the game.

What rubs me the wrong way is that there are one too many bonuses and distractions that demand the players' attentions. There's a wide range of bonuses for achieving cities, there are end-round and end-game bonuses and temple tracks as well. At some point I feel that the game is overstuffed.

RATING: 10
#3 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2016)
#3 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

This game is off the charts good! I don't often feel up to playing a two-hour game, but if I do, I wanna play Terra Mystica! This game takes some mechanics from other games and works them into a masterpiece. The many available factions all feel unique in the way they work. There is hardly any luck to this game- just pure strategic goodness. The replayability is tremendous. I adore the power mechanic- gaining power when others build around you and various ways in which you can use it to gain advantages. I wish I played this game even more. It's so dang good!

RATING: 9

The game itself is fascinating in that whilst the turn by turn objectives which reward building certain structures or taking certain actions lay out a 'map' players can follow, its often not in your best interests to do so. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
+ Fire & Ice
+ Bonus Card Shipping Value Promo

This game is still played a *lot*.

It is really strategic, full of interesting choices. When I first opened the box, I got scared looking at the number of components thinking that it might be too complex or fiddly, but its not like that at all. It takes a little while to learn, but its quite straightforward once you understand the rules. If you like deep strategic games, then this is a must have.

* Highly strategic, very little luck
* Essentially a resource management game. Very innovative way of putting buildings on the board gives you resources for the next round. And upgrading puts the old building back on the board. So upgrading opens up one resource, but it block another one. Your brain will be occupied just thinking about the way resources interlock
* Cycling of power is very nice. Power gives you a bonus now, but it will be a while before you get it back into bowl 3
* Tons of variety. Each faction plays differently, and there are 20 factions (with Fire & Ice expansion)
* Different board setup means the game is subtly different each time you play, even with the same faction
* Fantastic components

More than 75 plays so far, that says it all!

[75+ plays]

RATING: 7.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
- This game is a boring and solvable mathematical puzzle with often massive downtime between turns.
- The theme in this game is basically non-existing.
- The gameplay mechanics are an incoherent mess, I have no sense of achievement while playing.
- Multiplayer solitaire: there is no interaction in this game, everyone plays for themselves, solving their boring puzzle.
- Terra Mystica is a prime example of a "victory point salad": most of the scoring mechanisms (e.g. cult tracks) are tacked on.
- No luck factor: As this game is solvable from the beginning, it is nearly impossible to recover from errors made.
- The different playable factions are [url=http://terra.snellman.net/stats/]imbalanced[/url]. Since there is no luck in this game, this really is a problem.
- This is a horrible 2-player game because of the static map, which is equal for all player counts.

This is one of the driest and most boring Eurogames I have ever played. I would rather do someone's tax declaration than play this ever again. I simply cannot understand the hype about it and I hope that the high ratings won't encourage game designers to come up with similar junk.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is really becoming a favorite of mine.  Now played games at all player counts and the game really seems to shine at 4 and 5, 3 a bit behind.  Probably would choose something else at 2, but mainly cause I have a lot of games that play great at 2.

Really want to keep playing and working on improving and playing different races and figuring out when is good to play what race.  This seems like a hit with friends too so I see lots of plays coming.  Decent amount of interaction in the way of competition for spaces, power actions, bonus tiles etc which make for some interesting decisions and planning.

Really hard to resist playing this a lot online like I have been doing with TTA, but I don't want to get to far ahead of friends/wife in learning curve like I did with TTA.  Luckily this one is much easier to get to the table than TTA.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Initial impressions from 2015-05-19
I would say about half of the factions are exposed to limited favorable conditions in regards to bonus tiles/round scoring bonuses. However, where it gets interesting is that the variability of this game greatly compensates for it. For the other half of factions, many approaches, possibilities and strategies appear to be possible. This is going to be exciting.

Update on 2016-02-06
After around 85 games total (currently at 60 finished games on terra.snellman.net with a rating of 1233), this is still my #1 and favorite board game. A big part of the game takes places in the choice of factions and in the placement of the initial dwellings at the very beginning of the game. Biggest lesson to date is the choice of your faction clearly must be made considering the following factors:
1- Other picked factions before AND after you
2- Round scoring tiles
3- Available bonus tiles. Extra emphasis on this one with the first round bonus tile that could be available for your opening.
Many strategies are available for each factions, even more than I thought, depending on the round scoring. Some factions are easier to learn and play with than others, but I would say that every faciton has a chance to win if the round scoring fits with their overall strategy.

Update on 2017/06/14
After now what amounts to 160 completed games on terra.snellman.net and 200+ plays total I still feel like I could learn greatly with about half of the factions and explore/develop/optimize new strategies. I am also still discovering openings which is the most crucial part of this game in my opinion. Combinations of the following elements: 1) Faction pick, 2) 1st round bonus tile, and 3) potentially available 1st round power actions lead to more and more interesting starts with some factions that would otherwise have poor opportunity to score well. In my case the most recent example and biggest learning curve would be Alchemists.

Toujours de loin mon jeu préféré, même après 2 ans depuis ma redécouverte des jeux de société et le début de ma collection. J'ai extrêmement hâte de jouer à Gaia Project mais je ne crois pas que mon intérêt pour Terra Mystica soit diminué dans un avenir rapproché.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[2012-10-23]
Az első 2012-es esseni játék, ami kezem közé került. Nos úgy tűnik egyre jobban a másolásé lesz a főszerep, mert nehéz újat kitalálni. A Terra Mystica egy nagyon erős koppintása a Hansa Teutonicának. Megpróbáltak egy témát kreálni, amiben különböző fajok érvényesülését kell minél jobban menedzselnünk. Területek formálunk át és épületeket építünk, amivel felszabadulnak különböző erőforrásaink. Érdekességet a rengeteg faj és különböző képességeik jelentik. Az ilyen hátulütője mindig, hogy nehéz kiegyenlíteni a különböző képességeket, elsőre úgy tűnik itt sem sikerült. Bőven van erősebb és gyengébb faj a játékban, ami a különböző köri bónuszok miatt mindig változó mennyire jó vagy éppen rossz, de így nehéz egymáshoz mérni a játékokat és teljesítményeket. Mivel a HT-nél hosszabb így még azt sem lehet mondani rá, hogy könnyed, sőt kicsit talán gondolkodósabb is, bár az egyes fajok előnyeinek minél jobban való kihasználása könnyen vezet a követendő játék felé. Egyáltalán nem rossz játék a Terra Mystica, a Hansa T-t kedvelőknek biztos kellemes időtöltés lesz, akinek pedig a nagy előd nem ismerős biztos még kellemesebb élményben lesz része a játék során.

[2014-10-24]
Pont két éve játszottam vele, így örültem, hogy előkerült. Azóta top3-as játék lett, sőt volt top2 is kis ideig. Ha nem is jó ennyire, de már én is jobbnak látom. Tényleg játszható minden faj, csak van amelyikhez több tudás szükségeltetik. Jó játék a Terra Mystica. Hibája talán az AP veszély, öten eléggé elhúzódhat. Emelek egyet a ponton.
7->8

[2015-02-14]
További játékok után egyre jobban érzem a játék nagyszerűségét. Lehet, hogy a fajok nem teljesen kiegyensúlyozottak, de több játékos esetén van olyan kis szerencse benne, ami ezt kompenzálhatja. Minden faj megismeréséhez minimum 3 játék szükséges szerintem, illetve teljesen más egy adott faj kétszemélyes és ötszemélyes játékban. Emiatt óriási az újrajátszhatóság.
A játék egyedüli hibája tényleg csak az AP veszélye.

RATING: 9
The only reason I don't give it 5/7 is that I both like and don't like the overall "none interference" in the game, but sometimes it feels like that's more my group than the game, or maybe not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[u]2013 Impression[/u]: Pure sophistication. Enough depth to keep me exploring for years.

[hr]
[u]2015 Update[/u]: This one has, sadly, fallen from grace. Used to be one of my few 10's, but now downgraded.

For a long time, I had ignored complaints about faction balance. The long development process (started in the late nineties!) and rigorous playtesting made me believe that the final product is fairly well balanced, and any remaining discrepancies are inconsequential. People just hadn't explored the depths enough - the big swings in faction statistics at Snellman's site reinforced this belief.

Upon the release of the expansion with the "fixed" board, the truth dawned upon me, and my misconceptions shattered. Fourteen factions with wildly differing abilities are just too many to balance. And now they have chosen to make the situation worse by adding yet more factions?!

Anyway, it's still a sophisticated game, and I should still enjoy it, right? Unfortunately, no. What I enjoy most about strategy games is pushing myself to get better. I have no desire to struggle against a system where the deck may be stacked against me (or my opponent) from the very start.

Once the game falls out of favour, smaller gripes get amplified. What's the deal with the ridiculous theme anyway? Engineers versus fakirs... really?!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
[b]Upgrades[/b]:
-Insert (Game Trayz)

RATING: 8
Very cool abstract, with deluxe super powers.  It is like a cracked out Kingdom Builder.  Lots of fun objectives and ways to manipulate your growth.  I like the incorporation of the Hansa Teutonica/Eclipse tracking, where your abilities become revealed as you build.  

This is a game that absolutely rewards players knowing the comparative strengths of their character powers.  It would help first time players to know what the standard would be for a character sheet with no powers at all.  Who knows if these are remotely balanced...

My only big issue with the game is the tremendous potential for downtime.  If players are courteous and know what they are doing this should only last an hour an a half to two hours.  I was stuck in a nightmare game of this where after three and 1/2 hours I was ready for the game to be over.  There is little that you can do when it isn't your turn, so some minor assessment after each player's turn is about all the engagement that is required, but those with AP may have a difficult time of it, and kill all the joy of the participants.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I recognize that this is a good/very good game. There is a lot that I like about it. 

One of my main gripes in this game, and the reason I don't love it, is the cult track. It feels like a distraction from what I find interesting about the game (namely, developing the board). Advancing on the tracks is really boring to me.

I feel similarly about Airlines Europe/ Union Pacific. There are interesting things you can be doing on the board, or you can get caught up in the boring race to have the most AE/UP cards. 

In the three aforementioned games, it just feels like there is a pressure cooker of interesting activity that someone keeps releasing the valve on. In many cases you can't ignore these boring races or you will lose out on crucial VPs.

I don't care about moving my meeple up the track, just let me build the board! I understand there is a crucial timing to when and how to move up the tracks to create synergies, I just can't get excited about it.

RATING: 7
My gaming group has two of the most AP-prone people I've ever met. One is quietly AP as he sits there and analyzes every possible outcome, where the other is always saying 'if I do this, then I can do that, but he might attack there, so maybe I won't....'

I can think of at least a dozen possible choices on each turn, if you include the 8 actions listed on the reference card plus the 6(?) power conversions and the special actions you can have after building your upgraded buildings. As a result, a 4 player game lasted almost 3 hours, which is, quite frankly, way too long for a medium-heavy and somewhat mechanical euro. Now that I've played it once I'd probably try it again, but not with this group.

I missed a few key rules that cost me some points at the end, which I find irritating in games like this. So, not bad, but not one I'm going to rush out and buy or suggest we play, either.

RATING: 8
Fantastic game centered around variable player powers. There are 14 races to play, and each race must be played to make the most of their strenghts and weaknesses, making this a very srategic game. This is probably the most fun part of the game, figuring out how each race plays out and interacts with others.
This is a game that rewards planning almost the entirety of the game in advance. Player interaction is completely indirect. The full game highlights this as races will be drafted according the starting set-up. As such, the game is quite AP-prone.
Nevertheless, togethe with Tzolk'in, this is the Essen game of 2012!

Played as the Nomads, Chaos Magicians, Witches and Alchemists.

RATING: 4
Fantastic strategy game that isn't too difficult to learn, filled with variable player powers, alternate paths to victory, different scoring tiles, etc. A huge amount of variation and replayability packed into this game.  The type of game that takes many, many plays to master.  It is for sure unbalanced, but a skilled player will win over an unskilled one.

EDIT: I'm rethinking that last comment as I learn more about the game... A more skilled player will win over an less skilled one MOST of the time. :-/

EDIT: The more I play the less I like this game.  There is not enough player interaction for the length of the game.  It is more of a race vs a battle.  And, I have been a part of too many games that were doomed before the first move based on map placement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Terra Mystica is a million and one design ideas grafted onto a long resource management euro. That's not normally my thing, yet I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. For what it is, it's very good, a culmination of several older games--and, in many cases, lesser ones--taking the best ideas from sources as disparate as Settlers of Catan, Small World, and Through the Ages. I could identify others, I'm sure. It's a fusion of much of what's come before, most of which I'd probably pass on. But the result is impressively intuitive given the complexity, and surprisingly satisfying too.

Having said that, because there isn't much meaningful manipulation of other players' incentives, I suspect that repeat play would reveal less interaction and more optimization. One experienced player suggested that it's a game you can study by yourself at home if you want to do well, and I can see why. The barrier to victory is the complexity, not the other players. That's a lot less interesting to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It was not surprising how awesome this was to play. My first game was as the Alchemists, and I used the special money-to-VPs power to end up third in a five-player game.

There is a ton of interaction in this game. My biggest mistake was setting up too far away from the other players. This reduced my opportunities to leech power from their expansion.

RATING: 9
Pros: Very tight mechanics. At first I was weary of the power and cult system. They initially seem distant from area control mechanics. I was surprised to find that the terraforming and cult mechanics work well together, with the power system integrating these two main mechanics. Although difficult to teach, the mechanics are refined and easily understood after one playthrough. Be weary of teaching this game to newer gamers.

Cons: Sometimes it feels as if the race you choose and the round bonuses force you down a certain path. However the round robin style action sequence circumvents this problems. Other players can indirectly screw up your plays through their choices of power along with their placement on the main and cult board.

RATING: 7
FAQ: https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Terra_Mystica_FAQ#

Online: 
SOLO - http://lodev.org/tmai/
ADJUDICATOR - http://terra.snellman.net/

---
Update. After playing several more times (mostly at the Snellman site), it is clear that the most important part of the game is the beginning where you look at the sequence and composition of round tiles!, the selection of bonus tiles in the game, your position in turn order, and the races others have already chosen; then you pick your race. The rest of the game is largely execution. Certainly, there are key decisions throughout as you react to what others are doing. But I think the key choice is that initial decision. That's not generally my kind of game. It's still good, but I'm not sure it will keep my interest. At least not enough to work at getting my own copy -- PBW may be more than enough for me. 

Rating 8 -> 7
---
Wow, what a cool game! The rules take quite a while to get through, but game play is actually pretty smooth. I like how the leaching-from-neighbors works, so that you're encouraged to build close to one another and can't simply turtle (but too bad if you choose poorly at the start of the game -- you're in for a long, frustrating experience!). The way magic works is cool, the race abilities are varied and seem to be fun, and I think you simply MUST learn how to use those abilities to maximize your performance. 

There is a lot of variability in the races chosen, the random bonus tiles in the game, and the random selection and order of the per-turn scoring tiles. No wonder it was such a hit at Essen! The one downside for me, and after a bunch of plays exploring the various races it could turn out to be a major one, is the complete lack of any randomness after the initial game setup: I tend to like a _little_ bit of randomness in my favorite games (e.g., the cards in Twilight Struggle or Through the Ages, the production rolls in Age of Steam).

--- Summary ---
[u]Setup[/u]
- Shuffle the bonus cards and remove 6-n at random; place the rest (n+3) on display. Also, all Favor tokens and the 10 town tiles are available in display.
- Place 6 random scoring tiles on the turn track; these show ways to earn bonus VP that turn (e.g., dig, build dwellings), as well as bonuses earned at the end of the turn depending on players' positions on one of the cult tracks (e.g., for every space on the earth track, earn a coin).
- Choose random start player
- In turn order, players choose a race; the associated player mat has places for nearly all their wooden bits (all but their priests and bridges) and shows starting workers, coins, and/or priests, the initial distribution of 12 power tokens, and a summary of their two unique race powers (one becomes available only when the Stronghold is built)
- Players place their track markers on the starting spaces of the shipping and digging tracks, the specified spaces of the 4 cult tracks, and the 20VP space
- Switchback style, players place their starting dwelling(s) (take from left side of player mat) onto their home terrain spaces on the board
- In reverse turn order, players take one of the bonus cards (these generally increase your income; some give you VP at the end of your turn, or give you an extra action option during the turn); add 1 coin to the remaining 3 bonus cards.

[u]Overview[/u]
6 rounds:
- Income: as players build structures, icons are revealed on their player boards = income in coins, workers, priests, or power (move power tokens from bowl 1 to 2, then 2 to 3). In addition, the players' bonus cards may provide additional income.
- Actions: in turn order, players take one action or pass; the first player to pass becomes Start Player for the next round. If passing, some bonus cards may earn the player VP. Players immediately choose a new bonus card, returning their previous one.
- Cleanup: players earn bonuses based on the current turn's score card and their positions on the matching cult track, then flip the card over; add 1 coin to the 3 remaining bonus cards

[u]Actions[/u]
- (Terraform and) Build: transform terrain adjacent to any of your structures, paying with shovels (number based on how far it is from your home terrain) which you acquire by spending workers (1-3 per, depending on your status on your digging track); you may transform to intermediate terrains. To build, pay workers and coins (as indicated on your mat) to place one dwelling on a space adjacent to one of your pieces that is in a space of your home terrain type. Shipping and bridges make hexes further away "adjacent".
- Upgrade: player mats show costs for upgrading a Dwelling to Trading Post; TP to either Temple or Stronghold; Temple to Sanctuary. When building Temp or Sanct, immediately take one of the available Favor tokens (advance on associated cult track; may give you additional income or powers for the rest of the game).
- Tech Advance: advance on shipping or digging tracks, paying shown costs (coins, workers, priests) and immediately earning the VP shown
- Cult: send priest to one of 4 available numbered (2 or 3) spaces, immediately advancing that many steps on the track; passing over some spaces immediately earns you power. NOTE: the final space (10) only accommodates one player's token, and may only be unlocked if you have formed a town - one town per cult track 
- Power Action: there are 6 available spaces on the board, each available once per round; spend power (from bowl 3) to take one of these (to earn coins, workers, or priest; place bridge; or dig 1 or 2 shovels worth, which may be supplemented with your own workers
- Special Action: may be earned from bonus cards, favor tiles, or race abilities (when Stronghold is built)
-[b]NOTES[/b]
... whenever you build or upgrade, players with structures adjacent may earn power: x = sum of the levels (1-3) of their adjacent buildings; may pay x-1 VP to earn x power.
... Cultists rule change: if no one chooses to take power when you build/upgrade, you gain 1 power (instead of a temple step). 
... if you build a group of 4 or more directly adjacent (i.e., may not use shipping) structures with 7+ total levels (Dwellings are level 1, Trading Posts and Temples level 2, Strongholds and Sanctuaries level 3) they form a town: select one of the available town tiles, earn the indicated bonuses (VP and either cult advances, coins/workers/priest, or power)
... whenever needed, you may spend power in bowl 3 to earn coins, workers, or priests; also, may burn x power (remove those tokens from the game) from bowl 2 to move x power tokens from bowl 2 to bowl 3
... freely convert priests to workers or workers to coins

[u]End of Game[/u]
After 6 rounds (no cult bonuses at end of 6th round)
- Final VP (for ties, divide points between players):
... For largest contiguous grouping (shipping and bridges can be used): 18-12-6 VP for 1st-2nd-3rd
... For each cult track: 8-4-2 VP for 1st-2nd-3rd highest
- Convert all resources to coins, then earn 1VP per 3 coins
Most VP wins!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Terra mystica, I may not be entirely sure how to pronounce it, but I damn sure know how to play it! Or maybe I don't, considering the fact that I usually lose. But, you know what? It doesn't matter, because I still LOVE playing it! Terra mystica will seduce you with its Wiley charms while it simultaneously torments you with its brain clawing decisions of sacrifice and balance! Like a succubus it will blind you with its glamour and its promise of cunning play, but once it has you ensnared it will feast upon your very soul! Okay, maybe I got a little carried away, let's just say its the ultimate game of give and take, of sacrificing one good for another good, of balance and synergy of yin and yang, of 
Laverne and Shirley, its mind bogglingly AWESOME! And the best part is that there is no luck involved! Whatsoever! If you lose its entirely your fault! There are no dice Gods to thank or blame, there are no card draws to praise or curse! Its just you versus your own mind (and your opponents minds of course) you win or lose based on your own merits, hallelujah! What's that you say? You enjoy chaotic randomness and luck controlling your destiny? Then you can go straight to hell! You shouldn't even be allowed to play Terra mystica, for you are unworthy of its magnificence! In fact, I hereby forbid you to read this review, go grab a random dice game and be gone! Good.....now that those idiots are gone let me share a little secret with you...TERRA MYSTICA IS A GAMING GODSEND! Not since chess has there been a game that delivers this much of a brain fueled competitive orgy of thought provoking gameplay! Yes, its that good, its a cornucopia of mechanics served on platters of pure strategy! Yes, I love it, yes, if you value pure gaming euphoria you will love it too. And no, I don't hate all dice games
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

The game only allows limited player interaction, but this does provide a continuous sense of progress and safety.

RATING: 7.5

Thanks, 2013 BGGeexmas Secret Santa!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There are some games I swear were designed just for me.  This is one of those games and I knew I would love it before I ever even played it.

First of all, this game is "no-luck", which is out of the norm for me because I like a little bit of chaos and random elements in my games but this one is just so perfectly designed.  Like another of my favorite games, Mage Knight Board Game, this game perfectly blends several different game mechanics into one elegantly balanced experience.  There is area control, resource management, structure building and upgrading, worker placement-ish action selection, and variable player powers.

The variable player powers are what gives this game its teeth for me.  I love playing different races with different starting resources, building costs, and special abilities.  It gives the game variety and the fantasy theme gives it amazing charm.  The mechanic of terraforming surrounding areas into your "home" area so you can build on it feels original and exciting as well.

The amount of strategy there is to mine from this game is bottomless.  There are always costs and benefits to every action.  For example, there are some buildings that cost less when upgrading next to your opponents, however they get the same benefit, acquire power when you build next to them (which has its own cost/benefit since you need to sacrifice victory points to acquire this power), and might also cut you off from certain spaces.  Another example is you can sacrifice some power to move an equal amount into the "usable" 3rd bowl immediately, however this lowers the total power you can acquire to use abilities...but it also increases the rate at which you can recharge the 3rd bowl.

There is also a separate "cult" track to progress on, bonus points acquired for certain actions each turn, power chips that give you special bonuses for upgrading to certain buildings, competition for first player who also gets to select a special bonus for the next round first, and so much more that I can't even type it all here.

The components are also of the highest quality.  The boards are all beautiful and sturdy.  The wooden components are thick and really give a great sense of scale with the best buildings being large chunky boulders compared to the infantile dwellings.

The only (minor) criticism I would levy on this game is it is very fiddly.  There are a lot of moving pieces and it takes a while to set up and break down.  It is also a pretty heavy game (gameplay wise although also literally) so it's not going to be for everybody and even more hardcore gamers might be lost the first couple times they play trying to wrap their heads around the plethora of content in front of them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game that we'd like to play again

RATING: 6
Quite approachable for a gamers game. Looking forward to repeated plays. 

The races and random bonus and scoring set up create small but crucial differences to each game. What might work in one game could be hopeless in the next. The game gives large sign posts in the scoring and bonuses and special powers - they need to be exploited, though what I like about the game is that you can make the odd detour for tactical reasons.

Thati have no clue at all how to play some of the races is testimony to the depth and replayability of the game. 

What I have not figured out is why the game is so enjoyable yet appears programmable given the race powers and starting bonus/scoring.

7 games in and whilst I still really enjoy the game I do feel as if each game is a quite tactical battle, reprising the same tune in a different key. The skill and enjoyment seems to be in timing the use of the different 'currencies', all slightly differentiated by the races

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Terra Mystica was on my list for must try games a while back, but I sold the first copy I bought for a large profit. It was months before I could pick up another copy. I do like the healthy glut of races with different powers and that each race will have a separate path for building. Some take longer to develop, others must rush their stronghold in turn one to remain competitive via the use of their power. 

There is an excellent amount of variety in the box, but I feel the game was really hurt by the inclusion of only one map. There is also some serious imbalance with the races, with some being so bad that you will not win with them against even competent players. I am very intrigued by the bowls of power concept and hope a similar mechanic worms it's way into other games. 

I could likely have overlooked the above flaws and rated Terra Mystica a 9, but one problem crops up often enough to deflate the game for me. Your initial placement is extremely important to the point that doing it wrong will lose you the game even before it begins. Even with this warning, I have seen players fail time and time again after the "first play" game. Sometimes it is their fault because they isolate and don't build near anyone else, but other times they do and people just abandon that area or rarely upgrade there, assuring those players a bad game. This is not always easy to judge until it's too late, and it has soured me a bit on the game not because it happens to me, but because it can be such a bad experience for the players who get caught in it that they don't want to play again, shrinking my player base. Because of this, Terra Mystica is only a solid 7.

I kinda enjoyed my one play, but wouldn't mind never to play this again.

RATING: 6
It's really dry with no theme whatsoever.  A big mash up of déjà vu mechanics about resources conversion and bland tracks.
There's no build up because every time you upgrade something you lose something, but it helps keep the game short (with the predetermine 6 rounds).

On the other hand, you can really do what you want when it's your turn (with the choice of 8 possible actions) and it's not necessarily the same thing as your neighbors.

I don't get people comparing this to Eclipse.  This game is more related to Hansa Teutonica and just like HT it will be forgotten in a year.
A big meh for me.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Comparisons to Hansa Teutonica seem warranted because the style of play is so similar: individual micro-turns, uncovering a board with different wooden bits that grant access to new powers, light spatial play with strong leeching, many competing ways to score, many ways to specialize or focus to maximize those scoring methods. The bonus here is the vast variety and replayability: not only is every faction different, elements such as bonus tiles also change each round.

It's an easy game to like. It's not opaque and it's got nothing particularly novel to it; it's just complex and rock solid. The combination of spatial placement (including blocking), development and variety is right up my alley. It has at least enough replayability to get through every race, some of which require very different approaches. My only real worry is that it won't get the level of play it needs to shine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
At first i thought this would be another area control game.
Fortunately this is not the case.

It definitely has an area control element but the game is not all about this.

This feels more like a city building euro with many different paths to explore each time.
Choices and playstyle are influenced by your faction's special abilities and by each turn's scoring conditions and bonuses.

Some might say the interaction is low. I disagree.
Although there is not direct conflict like combat, there is a lot of competition going on for the cult track,terraforming,power actions and largest empire.
This amount of interaction is enough for me.

Overall i found it a nice game and i would like to play with every faction once just to find out how they play.

26/1/2016
After a year of zero plays we played it again thanks to our 10x10 challenge. We still like it a lot.
Rating increased 7->7.5

RATING: N/A
In Terra Mystica, players govern one of 14 factions seeking to terraform and colonize the landscape in their favor in order to build structures and preserve their race and culture. Upgrade structures to provide even more resources, like workers, priests, money, and power, erect temples to gain expanded influence in the four cults of Fire, Earth, Water, and Air, and fortify your stronghold to activate your group's special ability. Will your people prosper, persevere, and stand the test of time in Terra Mystica!

RATING: 9
What's interesting about this game is that, despite the complexity of the rules and the long explanation it requires to teach it to people, most people seem to get it by the end of the first round and move from trying to score points now to attempting a longer term strategy based on the race they've received. They probably won't win, but they'll feel like they can see what they did wrong and how to improve next time. There seems to be something intuitive about the way all the elements fit together that allow people to latch on to the rules and strategy quickly, despite the complexity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Best heavy Eurogame out there!

3-5 players, best 4. 60-150 mins.  Weight near 4 so complicated like war of ring!
At first, the game can feel a bit overwhelming with its many possible actions, rules and different faction powers (which often act as exceptions to rules). The actions themselves aren’t complicated or difficult, there are just a lot of them and it is hard at first to maintain a good overview. It is also easy to forget one of the many little details. Teaching the game will take about 30-45 minutes. 
Playing it can also be a long experience; 25-35 minutes per experienced player is realistic, but be warned: Terra Mystica has no randomness during the game at all. There are no dice rolls or card draws, the game is completely deterministic. In my experience, this leads to people thinking longer about their moves because they are able to calculate more accurately. Without randomness, there is less of a “let’s see how this works out”-attitude towards a game, so be warned that players prone to analysis paralysis can turn Terra Mystica into a 4 hour game (5 with a rules explanation), especially if they are new to the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
57
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
words cannot describe how wonderful this game is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played it more than 200 times and still find it interesting! Easy 10 :)

For me it is the perfect balance between optimizing my own economy while also having to fight with other players for positions and actions.

Incredible replay value because the setup is different every game, and there are 14 unique factions to play (with six more in the expansion). It takes 14 games just to try each faction once, and then you want to play more to figure out how each faction can be played optimally, and in which setup they perform best.

Can be played online at terra.snellman.net, and there is even a tournament at tmtour.org.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Civilisation building game that provides a lot of scope. Each player control a race of people, each with their own unique powers, and has to spread their areas across the board by using terraforming (to transform areas to their particular land type of choice) and through the construction of buildings (introducing extra benefits thereby making expansion easier). Players also need to use power from their individual pool and progress along four different cult tracks to aid their effort. Victory points are awarded for several accomplishment e.g. having built the largest town, placing a certain type of building on a given turn, progressing furthest along a particular cult track etc. There are numerous paths to victory and there's an awful lot going on at any one time to try and keep track of (perhaps one or two too many aspects making it difficult to strategise at times) but I admire the way this game works without resorting to direct conflict and the diversity in which a player can approach the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Dan John Sam dad 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are very few euros that are totally awesome but this is one of them. Even if you don't like euros I think this is one worth checking out.
My initial impression was that this was pretty complex but the more I think about it more I think this is a big, dumb game. And I love it! Or it might just be that there is a thematic and logical flow to the game and the designers didn't purposefully obfuscate things with silly resource conversion systems so that I think it's simpler than it really is. Regardless there's plenty of strategy, tactics and tough decisions to keep everyone engaged. There's no take that elements and only a little action and location denial. I do wish there was a second map but the variety of races will keep the game engaging for a while.
Production and theme are wonderfully handled though the box art is less impressive.
Unfortunately my love of big, long games (by euro standards) isn't universally shared so if I do buy this it won't get as much play as I would like.

RATING: 9

However, this game really deserves it's praise at is very well designed, and great to play. Felt drawn in, and I don't experience that a lot with a worker placement game.

Great game. Fan of euro's definitely should check this out. Predict this could be the next top 20 game on BGG [25-10-2012] within a few months, when it gets broader appeal.

RATING: 9
I love this one, the variety among the different races is impressive: you can play it over and over again and you'll never get the same result. The paths to victory are many, all equally effective. It also allows you to play tricky strategies (like building two close cities to get double victory points and then unite them in the last turn to obtain a massive settlement...). The rules are easy enough to be learned by everyone without much confusion, but playing the game can reach various degrees of complexity that make it really long-living.

RATING: 9
Beautiful components, intuitive gameplay that flows smoothly.  Game mechanics are fairly easily picked up after a round or two of play, but there is great enough strategic depth to satisfy heavy gamers.  It is ridiculously deep, and it5 has TONS of replayability!

This *was* my favorite game (for 5 years). *More edits* 50+ plays in, the game was every bit as good.

Simply the best boardgame ever designed, bar none.  Period.
*Or so it was -- supplanted by Gaia Project for certain, but Three Kingdoms Redux may also have a slight edge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
tl;dr: masterpiece

This game took off like a rocket when it came out. And people are still playing it way more than most games from 2012. And that was an EXCELLENT year with other masterpieces like [thing=119432][/thing], [thing=122515][/thing] and [thing=126163][/thing]! Man, what a year!!! There is a good reason why people are still playing this as much as they are despite the lack of new expansions: the game is very replayable out of the box and is a fucking good game! The different races and the way all the different game elements interact gives you an immense amount of game to explore, and each time is very enjoyable. And once you know the game, it's very doable to finish this in under two hours, which, for a game this deep, is very nice.
Yeah, this is a masterpiece, I'm so glad I get to play it every time I do.

RATING: 6
quite abstract - theme feels totally pasted on the game engine. Engine works well, even if I don´t like it (powerwheels, culttracks etc.) There is not much interaction between the players either. In theory you have a lot of actions in the game, but in reality the game forces you to act in the most point generating way. Due to the  few turns until the game ends, there is no room for real individual strategy. It melts down to determinate  how to get the most points with the individual strengh-bonus of your race and do than EXACT these actions in EXACT the right order. If you are ok at maths, you can calculate the outcome of the game after turn 3 or 4. My main problem with the game is, that it deliveres no story and no joyfull experience. I don´t feel like building a fantasy-empire, it´s just plain optimizing the pointgenerating engine. Therefore: for what it deliveres it is to long and adds unneccesary layers of complexity... but nice wooden bits though...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's interesting, but it's overly complex for what it wants to do.
I guess it wants to be a luck-free strategic game with advanced complexity and a thin fantasy theme.
I like the theme of fantasy races, although the game is quite abstract.
Asymmetric player powers are always great, and in this game it's done in an elaborate way. Every race has numerous properties that differ from the other races. It's neat, but also a lot stays more or less the same.
The idea of the terraforming is brilliant and adds a bit of special flavor to the game.
The materials look great. I like those massive wooden blocks of different shapes that represent different types of buildings, abstract but fitting.

What's not so great?:
- The "workers" look like stone bricks.
- 14 races but not every combination is possible (That's because every race is bound to a color and a terrain type, and there are two for each color.)
- not enough interaction between players
- expensive
- Do the races really feel different in gameplay?
- It feels like there is something missing in the game, that it could be better if it was designed a little bit differently.
- There are a lot of options what you can do, but usually not many that are good in a certain situation. So the game more or less pushes you in a direction and by that limits your decision making. Also, the races more or less dictate a main strategy that works best with the given race. And usually resources are very tight which further limits your decisions.
- The races aren't fully balanced. (There are auctioning rules in the expansion to mitigate that, but it works only for very experienced players who know exactly what the races are "worth" in a given situation.)
- Where are fun aspects? (Well, not by cool interaction and not by smooth and elegant gameplay, and the building aspect isn't all that great either. The theme is thin, and the luck-free competition aspect is not what I would call fun, and frankly, it isn't superb.)

in short:
+ fantasy theme with terraforming
+ many races with numerous different properties
+ good materials (and lots of them)
+ round tiles and bonus tiles make you think a little bit differently every game
0 luck-free strategy (not sure if I really like that)
- overly complex(!) and a bit too abstract
- not enough player interaction
- a strong feeling that it could have been made better
- expensive
- not really fun(!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
9->8
Many choices, but easy rules. No randomnes in one play, but high replaybility (different races, bonus tiles and turn tiles in every game). Many ways to get points. Turns should be fast (you make one action, than the next player has his turn), but sometimes there is some downtime (you must plan not only your current move, but also some next). The races are really very different.

Player boards in some way similar to Hansa Teutonica, but it is a different game. But like in Hansa Teutonica the theme is not very high.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A dice-less, moderately heavy game with tons of decisions to make. No turn ever feels like a waste, and every move feels expensive and important. I think the aesthetic could be a little better. Playing one race over the other emphasizes how you end up scoring points, which can make certain parts of the game less or more important. There is a strong dichotomy around playing next to other players, because it helps both you and them cycle your abilities in the game. Do I upgrade and help other players, or can I find another way to score points? If you have 3-4 hours to play, it's definitely worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I had to give a bad vote.
Why?
Because the outcome of this game is more or less defined during the first steps, by choosing races and placememt. After that you convert things from one to the other hoping that the game will end. No tension, utterly predictable and boring.

It was hard to give the bad vote.
Why?
The game designers did so well in some ways. The blending of some game mechanics is very well done. The rules are complex but yet easy to learn. The graphics support the intuitive understanding of the rules.

So the worst thing for me: with all the hype the game got, there is no way these guys will change their efforts.

If my vote would just reflect the fun i had (better say didn't have) playing this game it had to be a 1.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply amazing. Incredible, incredible game. An elegant puzzle, a complex, synergistic, interwoven connection of actions and mechanics that create a rich engine building game like no other. No luck, however variable player powers, but which make for varied and interesting play and can be balanced. Player interaction is a little minimal but the gameplay encourages it, and the more players the more interactivity will ensue. For me this game is like a work of art, and decoding it is pure joy. And yet the puzzle is matched with complex possibilities on the board, with players stealing actions, potentially boxing other players into a corner, and mutually benefiting one another through close expansion, which can be both helpful and dangerous. 

Personally though, the engine building is where this really shines. Every action and every construction will greatly affect the way your engine functions and what you produce. Sacrifices are encouraged, and will need to be made for efficiency. You really get a sense of it's construction as you go through the game, while at the same time having to make difficult decisions whether to build the engine or go for points. A good Euro forces that decision on you at every turn, and Terra Mystica does just that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really an entertaining game.  Thematically similar to Smallworld in art playing with many races who are asymmetrical. Gameplay is hard to explain, but definitely resource gathering mixed with a little bit of worker placement and area control.  You are basically building your races realm while your opponents do the same.  The board looks great as there are 5 different sized "city structures" for each race.  The catch is your race can only survive on one type of land, and so you are using your resources to "terra form" or change the land to a type that is hospitable to your race.  Scoring throughout the game, with the ability to sacrifice VP's through the game for power tokens to use is a neat addition.  Final scoring can making scoring a lot closer then you realize. Really a fun game.  3:15 for first play after rules with 5 players.  Easily could see cutting 30 mins off that time with repeat plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Terra Mystica is an impressive design.  It's a hodgepodge of player actions and VP scoring but it all works together seamlessly and organically.  The plethora of actions -- and sequences of actions -- would normally mean a complex game and bewildering initial experience.  That's not the case here.   The superb graphic design and lack of exceptions to the rules make it surprisingly easy to grasp and play. 

But it's not perfect.  There is an almost total disconnect between the theme of the game and player actions or VP scoring, which is unfortunate.  The requirement of upgrading magic before it can be spent, for example, is a very unique mechanism for limiting one of the game's form of resources.  But then magic is spent pretty much the same way as workers or gold or priests (and can even be converted into these other resources) and so it ends up feeling like "purple reources" and not at all like "magic."  It's clever, but not thematic.  The "now, for just this round, doing this action will be worth VP" is also pretty lazy, thematically speaking (and I'd rather not have the game herd players into particular tactics).

The game could also use a greater degree of player interaction.  I'd love to be able to compete for spaces in a way beyond the Settlers of Catan model of "you snooze, you lose" area control.

Regardless of its faults, this is a game I hope I have a chance to explore more thoroughly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Dr Frankenstein turns his hand to board game design - stitching together all the mechanics he can think of purely for the sake of it.  Tell me again, why am I moving these purple bits round in circles?

As cold and dry as three day old toast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is the game where there's just too much of "there's too little/too few of...". You always have the feeling that you're running short on workers, you're never close to having enough priests when you need them, money is always very tight and lore/might - don't even ask about it! You DON'T have it. And even if you're in the unlikely but favorable position to have some, it's spent sooner than you think. So think about spending it thrice/"quadrupleth"/"sillywordwith5...th"! Upgrading your buildings will give you some of the resources you're craving for, but not without reducing other resources you earn. And with more than 2 players the space you can expand into will most likely be brawled over too. Take the "turn-angstiest" game you know and multiply it by a billion: The result is not Terra Mystica, because you only multiplied it by a lousy billion! ;-)

Now despite being such a brainburner, the game plays very smoothly. I'd say you can explain it in about 20-25 minutes. There's some potential for downtime, but I wouldn't call it downtime. You'll be thankful for the moments when your opponents take some more time to think about their decision because you will be busy thinking all the time about your possible next move(s) and their timing. 
So is Terra Mystica deserving all the hype? No! Because calling it a hype would imply I think the game is wrongly and artificially boosted. If you askme, if Terra Mystica is deservant of its PRAISES, I'd have to go with a "Yes". 
I think the game is on a par with other great Euro games like Caylus (and no, they don't have anything in common) and has the potential to become one of the Euro Games classics. I'm very keen to try this with 3,4 and 5 players.
