=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent. The game is just fun to play, and the different player powers make it a different experience every time.

I also want to commend the iconography and built-in reminders. There's a lot going on in this game, but I haven't had to reference the rulebook at all after the first play. Everything just makes sense and is easy to remember because of the graphic reminders on the player boards and the main board. What do I get during the income phase? Just look for the hand icon. How much do I pay to build this? Just look at your player board. How many points for end-game scoring? Just look at the main board. What are my options on a turn? Look at your reference card. Great design, great layout, great game.

Update: I've now had this game since around the time it came out and I've played it several times with different groups. It's still a definite 10. This is the perfect "heavy" game for me. Some games (such as those by Vital Lacerda or What's Your Game) are complicated just for the sake of being complicated. Terra Mystica is heavy in the sense that there is no randomness (outside of the initial setup) and there are several different elements in play at all times. The difference, though, is that in TM everything flows smoothly and just makes sense. There are none of those "fiddly" rules that I hate and overall the game is pretty easy to explain.

[b]Player Count Verdict: 4-5[/b]
Two players doesn't work, and the game is just okay with three. You really need 4-5 to tighten up the board and the fight for territory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I hope you like managing resources. I do. I love that the only luck is the in the setup and the rest is all skill. The 8 actions you can choose from are each interesting in their own way and figuring out how to get them to work best with your faction is both challenging and rewarding. The asymmetry of the factions is both a plus and a minus. Adds variety and colors the game but some factions are definitely better than others off the bat.

RATING: 10

The game requires you to be both tactile and strategic in your gameplay. If you don't adjust to your opponents you may miss out on opportunities, but you can't lose sight of your long term goals for end game points.

RATING: 9
I really like this game. The way it combines a sort-of-fantasy theme with an all-out-Euro ruleset is spot on for me as a Euro guy. The factions add a ton of variety to explore and discover. I'm sure they'll come out with more factions in expansions too--it's just seems too easy they'd be crazy not to.

I love the way there's a bit of a race element, but how well you do is determined by how well you play to your faction's strength and to how the score cards are lined up in the turn display. I also like seeing all the scoring cards for the whole game immediately from set up.

I have a lot to learn; my 8.5 rating is only after one play. I suspect it will rise as long as it continues to impress with more plays.

The artwork and mechanics of the game are fantastic. I can see it being fairly easy to teach with maybe just one more play under my belt. 

Good game. I'm glad I have it.

3/4/13 - Bumping my initial rating from 8.5 to a 9. I suspect it will only rise with more plays. I really like it. My second play was brilliantly fun, even with two players. If you like challenging Euros with a mix of everything and a unique feel, this game is it for 2013!

6/27/13 - Bumping my rating from a 9 to a 9.5. It is officially one of my favorite games. I'm thinking in my top 5 for sure, possibly top 3 currently. The more I play it game, the more I like it. I love the way it rewards playing to your faction's strength. It makes it endlessly replayable and deep. 

Fantastic game with a unique feel that's both challenging, and rewarding.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A well designed interactive heavy euro with working variability.

Pros. High player interaction, fun mechanics that create constant tough decisions, unbelievable variety and replayability, a plethora of different strategies for each of the races, great flow of play, minimum luck (if any), small goals that create a sense of fullfilment throughout the game, a great sense of accomplishment and multiple competitive sectors for end game scoring (4 temples & the kingdom). This game even has a working theme.

Cons. The theme is pasted (I personally dislike fantasy themed games which means it's a poor package for me) plus it's a heavy game that is fairly difficult to play and less forgiving to mistakes. There are way too many mechanisms for me in this game, as I personally tend to like more simple designs.

Excellent game for those who love heavy euros, decent game for all. It's a game that has grown on me with every play, as the combination of great variability and complex, rewarding mechanisms is a killer one. Every game feels like completely new with the variable factions, mini goals and the combination of all, while the heavy mechanisms become more and more intuitive and the interaction steadily keeps you alert. Well done.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There is a good reason this game is ranked so high (Holy moly, it is up to #2!). It is an excellent game! It does a good job of introducing variability so it doesn't get dry. One problem that I have with many simple Euro games is that after a few plays, the optimal path becomes clear (I will go here, unless they go there, then I go here, etc.). Anyways, TM has variable races and abilities (of which I am a big fan), increasing the variability and the strategic depth. The game is intimidating, and there is a lot to think about, but it is fantastic. You really need to focus on the scoring tiles to plan your future turns as it is easy to get side tracked. Excellent game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-5 3h - strategy - char, network
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The gem of 2012 which has already become my favorite game- this one has 14 different factions to play, bonus tiles selected after passing, which give a unique advantage for the upcoming round and which increase in value ala Puerto Rico style for those not selected, passing first allows the player to go first in following round, building placement on board reveals increasing incomes as popularized in Eclipse, just the right amount of player interaction in competing on the cult tracks for majority bonuses, mini-actions similar to a rondel without the rondel to keep play flowing at a good pace, and some territorial placement urgency to establish cities on the board. Interesting mechanism to generate "power", a waxing/waning, recycling currency pool which provides flexibility in acquiring the other resources- priests, workers, and money. A bit daunting to learn/teach, but the effort is well worth the time investment. Once through the rules, the play is elegant and intuitive such that review of the rules is rarely necessary. To sum up, those who prefer thematic/Ameritrash designs may want to try before they buy. Eurogame fans can confidently place their preorders- this title packs more strategic depth in a fast-moving, relatively short play time than any has in a long time. Nearly endless variety, not only with the faction choices but also with the varying bonus tiles and the varying round bonus tiles and their varying sequence.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is a game with an evocative design. Very well integrated mechanics, a lot of choices, and a plethora of options for victory points. The variety of races provide a good debate around if the game is well balanced for each particular setup. Experience players can easily point out that for a given setup, certain races will do worst than others. You just need to recognize which race to choose (there is an option where you pay victory points to select your race first), or use the default setup. This is a gamer's game! Go and get your copy now!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[thing=120677][/thing] is, by all means, a great euro-game on the side of the medium-heavy ones. The game excels in variability: there are 14 groups/races from which to chose from - and the relation they have with each other are different: some will terraform the land in types closer to your own, so you will want to stay somewhat close, others will change easier terrain to terraform into tough ones, so you might want to stay away. And this is only one of the friction points between the groups/races. This don't mean battle - in [thing=120677][/thing] everything is friendly enough: the construction of the others near your own give you power points (at the cost of victory points) and the trading posts are cheaper to build when they are made near a construction of other groups/races. So this is a game of low confrontation - the dispute happens for the resources, much like in many euros (although not as cutthroat as [thing=31260][/thing] or [thing=18602][/thing]).

Every turn you have a selection of 7 actions to take: terraformation, build, special action, upgrade (buildings, terraforming and ships), pray, use power and pass. These actions usually demand a type of resource: workers, money, priests and powers - these are the currencies in the game. There are plenty ways to gain points and to change the enviroment of the game (you can acquire special tiles that give you one-off things or every round resources; the cities give points and one other thing; the round tiles, that you chose at the start of the game, and change for another everytime you pass, also give the player bonus stuff).

All the game is well crafted: things work in a good flow and the players are always wanting something and doing things - you can have rounds where you didn't do everything you wanted (as usual), but you hardly will have a round where you didn't do anything. Planning goes a long way in [thing=120677][/thing], since the game allows only a tiny amount of randomness - and this comes from the actions of the player, not the game itself - maybe someone terraformed a place you wasn't expecting, or took one of the favor tiles that, to you, don't make sense, or upgrade a build into a Sanctuary when you were sure he/she would change that trading post into a Fortress. Anyway this is part of most (if not all) games.

The theme is almost non-existent, even though the groups/races have abilities that have thematic connection with them - dwarfs dig, alchemists turn things into power, and so forth -, but during play I didn't feel that I was an Alchemists, nor that my opponents were Witches or Chaos Magicians - they were just player that could do some things that I couldn't or do better. I don't require theme in my euro-games, but it would be nice to have more.

The pieces are great and, oh, dear, you get a lot of them. A tree worth of them. The art is also pretty good.

A solid game that deserves the attention that it is getting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Anyway, the game was totally worth the enormous effort, hit our top 10 in a flash, and hasn't moved down yet :)

RATING: 9.5
Terra Mystica, what else?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This one is a real brain-burner.  It is perfect for anyone that wants pure, unadulterated strategy.  The game is completely deterministic, everything (except for your opponent's actions) is laid out in front of each player, there is no luck involved.  There are so many options on each turn and several different ways to accomplish goals for the turn, and this makes analysis paralysis prevalent (at least for me).  I also wish the theme was a lot stronger.  Sure, you play as fantasy races with different powers and terraform the land so that you have an advantage in certain areas, but it does just feel like moving pieces around on boards following slightly different rules.  There are several rules that simply don't make sense thematically, and the only reason they are there is to balance the game (and it feels artificial).  I think the reason this game is so highly regarded is because there are a ton of pieces to move around.  The implementation is fantastic, especially the player boards and iconography.  There are rules reminders with helpful clues all over this game, so once you play the game once, you'll find that the game is easy to understand and play.  The game is engaging the entire way through, for sure.  Those that enjoy figuring out the best way to maximize their victory points will love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The most played game in our group. The original balance seemed superior to the expansion. Excellent strategy game with no variance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A truly phenomenal design. I love playing this game--the only thing that could improve it for me is stronger thematic integration. The systems themselves, however, are so well-designed. The randomized setup ensures variety, but the lack of hidden information thereafter puts a high emphasis on both strategy and tactics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
bloated.  too much going on, and it felt like the side board in particular was 'tacked on'.  others in my group seem to highly disagree, though...  i would FAR rather play Puerto Rico, if i want a complex game.  i read/heard somewhere a comment that to the effect of:  choice of actions does not define strategy.  i would tend to agree.  LOTS TO DO seems to really jazz some players - and this has LOTS TO DO.  but i feel like it is an illusion of sorts - its really feeling like a bunch of mechanisms thrown into the blender.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
previously rated a 4.5.  bumped (for the moment?) to a 5.  i CAN see the appeal, but i still think that there is WAAAAY more going on here than is optimal for the fun quotient.  put another way:  the fun-to-time ratio is OFF and i would rather play Puerto Rico and a couple other games in the 2.5 hours than play this.  

another observation:  there is SO much going on that i often (mostly?) don't know the what i should do, but i can see something good to do.  and i don't mean this is "good complexity"; i still believe that this is a game that "jumped the shark" of complexity.  (e.g., that damn sidboard!  TOO MUCH!)

still, mermaids were fun.

RATING: 10
Euro plus fantasy equals my ideal game. I think every aspect of this game is superbly done. Plus, it was a wedding gift. How cool is that?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The leviathan is now in the house. In fact, I've been terrified yet strangely drawn to this game since it came out. The mystique surrounding the depth and complexity of it was truly intimidating, but now that we have it in the collection and watched a couple of run thru videos and read the rules, I think the hype is justified but the terror threat isn't. The rules in TM actually make more sense than some supposedly very simple games I read thru recently (Ivor The Engine i'm looking at you!) and all work very logically and the sheer numbers of visual reminders on the player boards is really impressive. Some of the mechanics are devious, like the 'power cycle' bowls. All the systems add together very elegantly to give you a game that is certainly deep and very very to feel your way through what may or may not be the correct strategy for your chosen tribe, but there's nothing that's genuinely 'difficult' as such. It means that once you've got the fairly simple rules under your belt, you can go off, pick up a spade and start digging!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like this and find it rewarding and interesting but the long term strategy is lacking.  Look at the bonus tiles and plan around them.  It's kind of fun to do this and see how efficiently you can budget your resources and tactical shots but I'd rather play a pure worker placement game.  Still solid and strong design that I will keep on my shelf, but a little too bloated.  

The worst characteristic of eurogames is that they tell you what to do.  Figure out the puzzle.  This game is exactly that with no rewarding engine.

RATING: 8
Rating after one play - might very well rise after the next time we have played it. Very good heavy euro, that combines elements of Eclipse and Hansa Teutonica with original mechanics of its own. In terms of rules there is a lot to take in on first play, but they are intuitive enough to remember and the artwork on the boards really helps to keep overview. Very, very well done. The different races prevent it from becoming too dry and seem to be very well thought out in terms of balance. Buy it if you have a group to play this type of time consuming board games with tons of options with. Looking forward to my next play.

RATING: 9
My first play of this was quite simply a revelation. It's been quite evident that at the time of writing this, that we're in the middle of the light to middle-weight Euro revolution. After playing a lot of light to medium-weight games, this wowed me with the various interconnected mechanics and fantastic gameplay. 

The thing was, we played some of the rules wrong and it was still fantastic! I'm so ecstatic that people continue to make games like this! As a slight aside, this game buried Kingdom Builder for me. Whatever interest I had in that game died when I played Terra Mystica.

I can't wait to get to play this more and learn the ins and outs of all the factions. The expansion looks fantastic as well and I can't wait to get my hands on it! What's really crazy is, I actually had this on my shelf for 6 months; I can't believe it sat on my shelf for that long.

Expansions: Fire and Ice, 
2 x Terra Mystica: Erweiterungsbogen

RATING: 7
76.00
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
Jogão, fantástico. Muitos caminhos para vitória, rejogabilidade maravilhosa, "cobertor curto", ações em sinergia, e uma das coisas q mais gosto em um jogo: te dá opções de estratégia a curto (recursos), médio (pontuação/bônus da rodada) e longo (pontuação por área e culto) prazos simultaneamente. Isso tudo com regras a princípio assustadoras, mas que se tornam simples e orgânicas em 2 ou 3 turnos, com uma iconografia excelente. Li algumas críticas citando que a partir do momento que a pontuação das rodadas e as facções são escolhidas, ele se torna determinístico, pois não há mais aleatoriedadde em jogo. De fato isso pode existir, mas para jogadores profissionais de campeonatos, para reles mortais como nós, calcular isso é doideira, oq vale é o desafio e a diversão, e isso TM tem de sobra!

RATING: 9.8
A smart Euro fully deserving of the praise it gets. A creative blend of Kingdom Builder and Puerto Rico. The downside is the number of potential actions you can take each turn is staggering (more than the advertised "8").

It takes about 30 minutes to teach the game even if you've played it a bunch because it's just got so many different concepts. Still, it is clean and pure with its lack of random elements and pure strategic gameplay. Made its way on to my "favorites" shelf with a small handful of my large collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This 3 stars is based on personal appeal and the fact that we are unlikely to play this one again.
The game looks great, and there are some really fantastic mechanism at work here. I really wanted to like this one.  After reading through the rules, we gave it a go and played for over an hour without finishing a round.  There are so many things going on,  it was very difficult to know what we were doing and had to continuously return to the rule book for clarification.  This is a pretty common occurrence the first time playing any game - but the rules are so layered here it would take considerable time to find the singular piece of information we had questions on. And many times the answer didn't make things easier to understand.
I did watch a couple how-to videos to try and better understand it, and we gave it another go.  Again, the individual elements of the game seem very promising and I really wanted to like it.  But even with the better understanding of gameplay, it seemed disjointed. Almost like the game was missing something, but the thought of adding anything else to this is a little crazy.
It may be that the game is just beyond our comfort level of complexity, but I am disappointed in this one.  I'm glad we were able to test drive it without buying.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is very good, and after setup there's no luck element, which I particularly like.

The race balance question is an interesting one- I think they're very close to balanced for top-end play, but if you're a new player, some races are much much easier to grasp their optimal (or close to optimal) build paths, so the bottom-to-mid end of play doesn't evidence the balance well.

  At first glance, the power mechanic and shovels mechanic are interesting, but once you see them in action, they are much less so (the bowls essentially means each power gain is really 1/3 of a power a gain, and you should burn off half your power ASAP, no question.  In-game, the digging mechanic usually means you're only looking at terrain that's within 1 of your type).  And the game is just a touch long.

However, despite these gripes, it's still very good overall, and I would definitely play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Sweet spot is 4-5 players. 2 player TM is not as fun in my eyes.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has been quite an evolution for me.  Initially, the components just really turned me off and I had zero interest in it.  I ended up playing a game and was happy to find out that it almost has a bit of a Settlers of Catan feel in that you're building up colonies on a map, something I've been missing in games.  Overall though it felt a bit dry and overly thinky to me to really enjoy.

Fast forward several months as I ended up with the game in a trade and started playing multiple games in a row, it has begun to blossom.  There are definitely some thinky moments where you get stuck crunching numbers, not any worse than Power Grid though.  What I really enjoy is the friendly competition for space on the  map, I love that sort of interaction where you're trying to outguess your opponents and beat them to the punch, or forcing them into positions where they have to help you out.  The multitude of races are really great also, maybe a bit restrictive some of them, but I love the variability of being able to try different strategies.

RATING: 10
A deep game, each race plays entirely different. However, I would not want to play this with AP prone players.

After my second play I was not sure I ever want to play again as it felt like a lot of work and no fun. It was so unforgiving that depending on which race you go with the tiniest mistake kills you and is impossible or at least hard to play well on intuition. I want a logical, intuitively playable and fun game, this is the opposite.

However, after my third play this game shines. Now the rules seemed intuitive and I felt like my game was going well all the time. It also seemed like everyone else at the table were doing fine as our scores all ended within ~95-110. There were some differences now, everyone seemed to play at least semiefficently with at least some clear goals trying to use their racial advantage.

This is in the heavy category and it is very nasty if you make a mistake that puts you out of the game. But it is not as bad as the first plays indicated. In fact once you get the hang of it this may very well be the second best game ever, as it is now ranked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
From the box and title, looks like an overly dry euro, but it isn't.  Instead, this is satisfying civ-building in 2.5 hours, reminiscent of a combination of [gameid=554] and [gameid=9216].  There's enough competitive interaction so that you're not playing in a vacuum.  The races are different in a great way, enough that they play very differently but aren't imbalanced.  TM also has that tightness that good euros have, where you want to do everything but have to pick and choose.  One of the most inspiring euros I have played in a long time.

RATING: 9
Terra Mystica is a heavy game, figuratively and quite literally, there are lots of pieces in this thing. It's strategically deep, but it doesn't feel fiddly, which is great, and the learning curve is not as steep as one might think, when playing with one of the "easier" races. Should be tons of replay value with all of the different races as well. Essentially a zero luck game, so it can be punishing if you aren't efficient with your actions and don't think ahead. This one is aptly described as "elegant" I think. I very much enjoy it. Also the player boards are some of the best designed I think I've ever seen, basically all of the information you need to play the game is on the boards.

RATING: 10
+.5 until I get more plays in to solidify a 10. Almost everything about this game is my jam. The mechanics are tightly interwoven, every turn you have a lot of viable options, your engine doesn't take the whole game to implement, and it has a great ebb and flow when taking actions. In fact, timing your actions is at the heart of a good, winning strategy and will change each game due to the random set-up. 

 The art is colorful in it's own way and the theme is not necessarily STRONG, but the trappings of the game all work together nicely so that the gameplay isn't entirely divorced from the theme. And PLAYER RACES! So good and distinct! Each new race you play as is almost like a different game! The length of between 2.5 and 3.5 hours is right in my sweet spot for a single game as well. 

My only complaint that comes to mind is that the cultist/gods track being a separate board tends to mean that half the table struggles to see what's going on there in the bigger player counts. No (good) solution really comes to mind though. If I get up to 5 plays and still love it this much, that'll be an easy 10 from me.

Update: I have played it over 10 times now with the app and on Tabletop Simulator. It's been great every time unless you get a VERY AP player. Still love it. Rating of 10 it is. Even got to try the expansion and new map.

5p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This isn't a difficult game, by any means; it just has a lot of stuff to remember and track.  Add in variable powers for each race, which break the standard rules of the game, and it creates a mish-mash of details, which in turn create a lot of options.  It certainly feels like a deep game, but it's really just an optimization game of getting your engine going faster than everyone else, based on how you can earn points over the course of the game.  That's not a bad thing (it's not an openly hostile game; you really only interfere with other players through the limited actions on the board and where you place your pieces), but I have to admit, I was expecting something a lot more intense and unforgiving.  That's not a bad thing -- it's a good game, and I enjoyed the experience -- but I have to admit I expected something a little different.

2 plays: 3 players
2 plays: 4 players

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm not entirely sure how I rate Terra Mystica. I know I like it and that every play feels very satisfying, but there are some things that hold me back from truly loving it. For starters, it is really abstract. There is no true storyline to the game, you are simply racing to either build the most structures or send the most people to the temples. There's no reason for it, so I have a hard time getting invested in its story.

Looking past its lack of plot, there are a lot of neat things going on. The player mats are brilliantly designed and make record keeping a breeze, not to mention they act as a solid reference to help players plan their turns. The magic system is very interesting too, rewarding you for interacting with your opponents, even though VP-wise it is clearly in your best interest to stay isolated. It's an interesting tactical puzzle and certainly makes the game feel stronger than the sum of its parts. I gut check rate it as an 8. I like it, but don't really love the theme. The tactical puzzle is first rate though, not to mention that mechanically, it is better designed than most of the other games I rate an 8...so I think I'm going to bump it up a notch, even though I am not in love with the setting. It's just too well designed not to give it a little extra love.

UPDATE: With the help of my group, which has taken a real shine to it, we have gotten into this one deep. There are so many variables that come into play depending on what factions are in any particular game and which rewards come out and in what order that it feels almost impossible to master, yet our scores improve every game. This means it is a game of skill, in which consistency can be gained, yet relying on patterns is almost useless. I'm sold, bumping it up to 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the most intricate and finely subtle games I've seen. I am drawn more to this game than any other I've seen in a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a tough game to rate. It's very well designed and I can understand why it's so highly ranked.

I had commented while playing it that it sort of reminded me of Warcraft III. My friends played that and Command and Conquer for RTS games, and I would only play C&C because of the resource system. C&C had money and electricity as "currency", if you will - Warcraft added wood to that, which meant I always ended up balancing them incorrectly and being short in 1 of the 3.

In this game, there are 4 currencies to manage, plus your unique abilities to consider, plus the unique abilities of as many as 4 opponents (one thing of which I'm fairly certain is that I'd like this more with fewer people). Given that human beings can only hold 7 things in working memory at a time, I suspect that this is a game that rewards memorization. My play of this was with people who all had a small handful of games under their belts, and still the winner (the mermaid player) won in large part because none of us realized what she was doing until it was too late to do anything about it. It seems like it would take lots of plays to get to that point, but that's when the "real" game would begin.

I'm not a lifestyle gamer. That's not to say that I don't enjoy exploring game spaces over repeated plays, but I don't want to dedicate lots of time to any single game. This is one reason Terra Mystica isn't for me - it's the kind of game that really rewards study.

At least, I think so. I also have some concerns about whether it will even hold up to the "lifestyle" play type it seems to demand. I have balance concerns, I have semi-solvability concerns - it seems very possible that this will be one of those games in which "serious" players only play these 5 races, and start in these positions, and essentially the game is decided by the random bits. Among all the glowing reviews, I'm already seeing little signs of this - people commenting that the games are feeling the same, that the most important decision is which race to play, and so on.

I suppose the most damning thing I can say about it is that I just didn't have very much fun. I've certainly played worse, but while I left the game thinking about what I could've done differently - usually something I consider a positive sign for a game - I simultaneously felt no desire to ever actually try again. I commented to my wife afterwards that I think I finally understand how she feels about most of the games I play - there was too much going on and keeping track of it all just felt like work.

My 6 rating might be too high, but I suppose I would give this another chance with fewer people to see if my first impressions are wrong. If you like playing a small number of games many times more than "dabbling", and don't mind having a ton of stuff to keep track of all at once, this is probably a great game for you (but perhaps not over time). For me, this competes with Container for the title of best game I don't particularly like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Denise
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For me TM is a brilliant game.

It is a perfect mixture of known and new game elements.
 
New, or at least not known to me:
The balance between advantages and disadvantages of  neighbourhood.
The bowls of power.  Mechanism works imho like an accumulator. You can collect the ability to boost one of your turns here until you can use it with best results.
Terraforming with variable costs depending on source and target terrain type.

Already known from a lot of games I like too:
Complex resource management.
"Too many" options who can select from for your single move.
Different races or fractions with some individual attributes.

Can't wait for the next session.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
iOS version: 

Great strategy game. I like the asymmetry of the different factions and how your decisions can directly give bonuses to your opponents. I haven't played the physical board game but I can see that being better than the iOS version because it's hard to remember all of the things at the same time (cost for something, current cult track, what's available, etc) as you have to switch screens a lot to see everything vs just seeing it on the board. Plus I hear the components are nice and solid. 

Only downside is the playtime. It's a lot of constantly counting and looking forward for what you need to do (which I love) but I can see this being a 2-3 hour game every time and if it's not played regularly a constant rules correction on how things work regarding conversions, power, priests, etc. So since I love to play different games a lot and can only play a couple long games per month, I'll probably never buy the full game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A heavy hitter gamer's game from the Essen 12 crop. Lots of wood in the box along with tough decisions.

RATING: 8
I played [url=https://terra.snellman.net/]30 or so online games against AI players[/url]. The game is a fun optimization puzzle. The most important currency is power points, which you can use to buy special abilities or any other type of currency (priest, worker, money, shovel, cult). You spend resources to shape land and build structures. I like how each race is unique, but I wish the overall game felt more thematic and cohesive. The building tree is really cool. RATING: 5
Terra Mystica is certainly an incredibly deep and strategic game...unfortunately it is also a very intricate, ponderous and mentally taxing one. There is so much to keep track of and so many moving parts that I found the big picture tends to get lost amidst the nuances.

While I would never call it a "bad" game (it clearly boasts expertly-crafted design), I didn't find the experience terribly fun. It was more of an exercise in mental gymnastics than an conduit for good times.

In short, I was hoping for more mysticism and less mathematics from a game called "Terra Mystica".

RATING: 7.2
[EDIT] after my second play, basically the problems of the game are still there. it is not slow, but it is long and complicated. on the other hand, it works well and it is kinda rewarding. i really have mixed feelings about this. raised the rating by 0.2
------------
TM is a well structured game that gave me bad gaming experience. Fundamentally, it is over complicated, terribly slow and not very original.
Components are good and you have a tons of them. Rules are never ending and there are too many details to remember. There is too much micromanagement to take care of but, most of all, downtimes are too boring. Somehow it is strange there can be these long time of waiting (talking about a 4 players game) since each turn you got to do something several times:nonetheless, it happens: you just have to wait.
Interaction is not very pronounced but to me this is not a bad thing per se.
The game is well balanced, there are multiple ways to reach victory, you have to take into account a lot of things and all this saves TM from a really bad game, but i don't feel the need to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Terraforming a hexed landscape in a battle for area control using randomly shaped wooden blocks* is Terra Mystica.

Its manufactured theme is a faux fantasy skin and some sloppily executed iconography lends greater confusion to an already convoluted system. Players suffer experiencing an abundance of face-up bonuses & powers which are a challenge to interpret, memorise and manipulate.

*These 'blobs' were compared by one of my friends to building blocks of duplo dropped on a non-descript kingdom.

A game state of this type will appeal greatly to any solution-driven player in your group, for moves can be planned ahead (or be blocked by opponents). If this game was simplified, given cleaner signage and textured with themes that fit the grain then it could become more enjoyable to play and teach.

One of the highlights for me was planning tactics interchangeably before each new round to gain bonuses. Unlike in Puerto Rico the player replaces his/her card counter when selecting a new tactic.

Aside from the average size board, player boards, card counters, wood blocks & meeples (no cards, no dice) I see no additional content to justify the hefty £60-65 asking price set to buy Terra Mystica. It might promise indefinite replayability yet for the same money I could recommend investing in a pairing of better designed releases that offer the same longevity and production quality with a sense of clarity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
This game is sick. It's a struggle to learn, but once you understand the rules, it's on. A highly strategic game with no unfair randomness (what little randomness there is affects all players equally, no frustrating lack of hits or resources due to unlucky dice rolls). The mild randomness is in the setup making the winning strategy different every game. Combine with relatively short game times gives this game huge replay value. The $80 price tag is steep, but was worth it in my opinion. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only logged one play so initial impressions only but I like this game a lot.  I love that there are no free rides in this game.  Every action you take you are deciding NOT to do something else.  Do I make a play for expansion, building upgrades, spend my power, or pass to get that bonus token I really want next round so I can upgrade my water travel or excavation...  This game is very complex but a lot of fun.  

There is a bit of deadtime between turns which you can use to plan your strategy and adjust as the other players moves change your strategy but if you pass too soon, you could be in for a 15 - 20 minute wait.  

Also, some of the races feel unballanced.  Some only have a bonus that applies in the very first round (IE, getting to start with three dwellings) and others give you points for every action (like a victory point for every excavation).  Not sure yet if it's my skill level with the game or not.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With the number of factions and the number of times we're likely to play this, I think it will be a game of who can figure out most quickly how to play the faction they're given (or that they draft).  There's a puzzle aspect to it that I found fun in the first play, and I like the spatial element on the board.  The building conversions are an interesting set of choices both because of the constraints on the number of buildings and the fact that up-grading one building removes another; so you're trading benefits, not just moving up.  Excellent design in terms of how the game presents the information on the game state.  There are a lot of knobs to turn, which seems overwhelming as the first play starts, but midway through the first game everything starts to make sense mechanically and the flow of resources and ways to get victory points gets clearer.  And, in our game at least, the factions seemed surprisingly thematic for this kind of Euro.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

(4): Complex

RATING: 9
My second favourite game of Essen 2012. It's a meaty and intricate territory building game with many paths to choose from and decisions to make, backed up by a varied selection of starting factions and special powers which should give it high replayability. At first, the choices are almost overwhelming, so it's good that there's a bonus to aim for each round which helps you decide what to build or upgrade.

The concern for some people might be that there's not enough interactivity between players. You're racing to terraform the best spaces and competing on the temple tracks and for certain bonus tiles but you can't directly attack others' positions. It's very Euro, but that's good for me: I like Euros.

Sold out at Essen so I ordered a copy when I returned home.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Well crafted game, extremely fun to play in a group of 4-5.

RATING: N/A
Brand new, sealed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Theme/Art:
The theme is great and immersive with the landscape shifting, every factions looks and plays unique. However, I'm not a big fan of the art style, but that may just be my taste.

Production quality/Design: 
No miniatures, but none needed since it's a eurogame. High quality wooden meeples and token, as well as a big board and cardboard pieces. Everything feels and plays high quality. No cards.
The design is amazing, ones you know how to play you can see what everything does with only one look due to very simple symbols.

Replayability:
The base game comes with 14 different races, each with its own abilities, so there is a ton of replayability. Also every game is different, because the bonuses for each of the 6 rounds are different everytime.

Depth/Difficulty:
It takes quite a while to explain to a new player (~1 hour) and you have to think of a ton of things during the game and plan ahead. I wouldn't say that the game is difficult, the mechanics are very easy to understand and also make sense, but there are many many mechanics and many options each turn.
I weight it 4/5.


Strategy:
Strategy is everything here. There is no combat, so you can plan ahead comfortably (as long as other players don't build in your way). Also every race has to be played with different strategies.

Luck:
There is next to no luck in this game. The only random factor are the round bonus tiles, which are determined at the start of the game, so you can plan ahead.
And you have to hope others don't destroy your plans by building on a tile you wanted.

If the players know the game it takes about 30 minutes per player, but it can easily take longer. Terra Mystica takes about 30 minutes to teach to new players.

Amazing game with insane replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Note: I have only played the app.

Terra Mystica comes highly recommended by many people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is an amazing game that I'd never turn down a chance to play... which is surprising because I'm horrible at it. I've never played a game that has seamlessly combined so many different mechanics. Each round is a struggle to figure out what will work best for you and determine what your opponents are trying to accomplish and (hopefully) slow them down. Mix in that everyone is using a different race and you all have different abilities and that's when your mind explodes.

There is quite a bit going on in the game and,because of the variability from game to game, you really need to know the race that you're playing and the ones that you're playing against in order to compete. Because each race plays so differently you have to understand how best to play them as you're guaranteed to fail if you don't play to their strengths. You also need to know what the other people can/want to do in order to hinder them. The game also has the strange dichotomy in that you're competing against each other yet you want to be close to them to gain benefits from the, but at the same time, you don't want to be to dependent on them to the point where you box yourself in.

All in all though, there's no way that I can give this game the justice it deserves here without creating a massive wall of text. There is so much depth and strategy in this game and so much variability. I've played it a number of times now and I don't even think that I've begun to scratch the surface. Add to that the Fire & Ice expansion that makes a few improvements to the game (variable player order) and I think the game is deserving of its BGG rating. Amazing brain-burner of a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tentative 8 on this.  Still learning how to play it...quite the brain burner.  I know I like it, but I'm working out whether I love it or not.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
太過複雜：不同種族有不同能力、機制繁雜有太多小細節、回合動作種類繁多等。

不同的種族能力有可能造成遊戲不平衡，地圖的設計對不同的種族間是否公平也有很大的存疑。沒什麼互動感和策略，每場遊戲，每個種族就照固定步驟進行就好，無聊。

玩起來就像是其他外國玩家的評論：像一張試算表(spreadsheet)。
就是一個多元一次方程式的線性規劃問題，用電腦跑就好，有點枯燥。

看起來很複雜，其實沒什麼變化性，每場遊戲都照重複步驟進行即可得到不錯的分數！無腦的遊戲，不知道排名為何衝這麼高？頗瞎。

主題也無法融入遊戲中，完全感受不出魔法迷幻氛圍，比較像"房屋連連看"的遊戲。和魔幻有關的只是種族的人物和法力，但是這兩項也可輕易的抽換成一般的人和能力屬性，看不出獨特性和專一性。

米寶和美術設計也不吸引我，不喜歡這款遊戲。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
2-5 players. Still my favorite game. I love the playing material and the income mechanism. The interaction with others through trade houses and power points is elegant. I don't get to play as often as I'd like though because it can happen that somebody who messes up in a turn and has few actions he can do has to sit and wait for 20-30 minutes while the others finish that round. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
I have increased my rating of this game due to the added features of the expansion.  The new board is more balanced and the passing board, new end game goal tiles, and especially the bidding of races for victory points makes the game far more variable and balanced.  Excellent game!
Original thoughts: This is an incredibly engaging, deep, and impressive game.  The game isn't as hard to understand as a lot of people make it out to be.  The steps and actions are fairly intuitive so I feel like the game isn't as heavy as people make it out to be.  I absolutely love this game because every race plays differently and the strategic decision making is intense and satisfying. I like how you get a bonus every round and choosing when to pass is incredibly important depending on what bonus you want or need for the next round.  The risk/reward aspect is nicely implemented.  You can build next to your opponents to get nice rewards but they may claim the valuable land that you need in later turns, and sometimes completely block you out of an area.  However, developing your civilizations away from your opponents is incredibly costly.  The last interesting aspect of the game that I would note is the manipulation of the power bowls.  This is one of my favorite parts of the game.  Not being able to move power to the third bowl until the first is empty forces players to be wise with their decision making process of when to spend their power to obtain a one time bonus.  These bonuses are first come, first served and only reset in the following round, so it is a race to spend off your power before your opponent gets the power bonus you need.  I would rank the game even higher if the races were better balanced.  This is one of the best that I have ever played. 

Note: Meeple Realty Insert

RATING: 7
Terra Mystica is a deep, and heavy eurogame, and the gameplay is good. Sadly I think it's one of those games that you must play a lot to actually make sing. It is hard to pull it off the shelf once a year, and try to relearn, and remember how to play each Faction. It's still a well designed game, and something I would enjoy exploring in depth, but probably won't.

Uwe knows how to write rules, they are fantastically laid out, and in perfect order for both learning, teaching, and referencing - just great! The intricate gameplay comes through from just reading the rules, but is better still in play.

My tastes in euros is changing though, and for now this will drop to a 7.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game feels like Eclipse to me without the dice rolling.  Complaints that some factions are superior to others probably have some merit, but I believe many of these to be inflated as match-ups among factions can be critical in some games because of the terraforming dial.

Fun to play.  Engaging.  A definite winner.

After dozens of online plays and 13 live plays, I can say that the "good v. bad" faction issues have merit.  Four of the factions are basically irrelevant unless you assign random factions as no one would ever choose to play Giants, Cultists, Auren, or Fakirs given the alternative of playing the opposite color side.  Blue and Black have fairly well balanced options and while it appears to me that dwarves are mildly superior to engineers in gray, I could see playing engineers in some instances.

This is not to say that the game is made any less by these issues.  It's still a wonderful strategy game, but a second edition with some tweaked faction powers for the underpowered options would be very welcome.

Possess the new town tiles now.  They add a dimension to the game and offer improvements to a few of the harder to play factions.  Definitely worth the five bucks out of the geek store.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I started off really liking this game. There is a good challange in finding the right way to victory with all the different races. The material and the board is very appealing. And far from last - there is very little that people actually dislike from the start (for exaple I would never get my wife to play a SciFi themed game, no matter how good it might be).
However, I hardly play the game any more - and don´t know anybody who does. And by now, I think it is for the lack of emotion. I don´t really feel enthusiastic when I decide for a move - or even win/loose the game. It is more or less a feeling like: "oh, well, good job, it did pay off, I guess". O.K., I might have optimized my potential, BUT there is neither the biting competition, nor the great satisfaction of having created something special, nor the feeling of having prevailed against all odds, nor much interaction with the other players...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Extremely awesome game. This is fast becoming my new favorite game of all time. The gameplay is deep enough to really make you think but streamlined enough to where you don't feel lost in the mechanics. I absolutely love the asymmetry of this game as it allows for balancing between experienced players and new players as well as providing 14 different factions each with a unique strategy. That's 14 different strategies to learn even without taking into account the other changes in setup each game.

This game has everything I love about games: tons of replayability, lots and lots of strategy, just the right amount of interaction and an overall extremely fun game every time it hits the table (not to mention an appropriate level of brain burning too).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm not a huge fan of this game. Maybe because I really suck at it. I do not want to make a blanket statement about variable powers in a game, but I think it does this game a disservice. I feel like the variable abilities are not well balanced as could be between all the factions. Also, I find myself losing track of scoring and resource gaining because it changes from round to round and it is different for each player. That said, I still want to play this game some more, because it feels like I'm just missing some defining strategy when I play it. In other words, I don't want to play it because I enjoy it, I want to play it because I hate not understanding a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I heard great things about this game so decided to pick it up.  The rules weren't too bad to learn and the multiple different races to play, combined with the randomness of scoring tiles, makes for a huge amount of variety.

However, the first time we played, the game went quickly and we were left wondering what was so great about it.  The second time we played there was a bit of an "aha!" moment when we noticed we should be streamlining our play to better maximize points and we got a better grip on power use.  The third game took a long time as we agonized over every turn to try to figure out the best way to play.

I am usually big on theme (ie. do I feel like I am playing a game or building a halfing empire) and the theme is fine for this game.  However, I find myself lost in maximizing the game mechanics to the point that I don't really notice the theme.  Normally, that would be a strike against the game, but in this game it is wilful ignorance on my part due to the depth and I don't mind forgetting the theme while playing.

This game comes with quality components and, despite my above comments, a great theme.

This is a deep and heavy game that I highly recommend for experienced gamers.  As per the above, due to the depth of this game, you need to play it a few times to really appreciate just how good it is.

RATING: 8.2
I don't know when or how it happened, but the more I play board games the more I like Euros. Something about their consistency really rubs me the right way. Terra Mystica, with its variable starting points and widely diverse factions, manages to fuse the randomness I crave with the strategic stability I'm starting to really appreciate - especially in competitive games.

Edit: 12/24/14
Wow. Played this about four more times now and it has only increased in enjoyability. Very pleased.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
一场没有硝烟的战争，一个被河流分割看似不大的岛屿上，十四个种族的原住民们为着有限的建筑用地巧取强夺，没有往日的兵戎相见，只有盖房速度和盖房质量将证明谁才是这个岛屿上的主人。大地秘境中有着不少经典游戏的影子，可以概括为取其精华，浓缩精华，精炼成型，完美出炉。虽然大地秘境的特点被众多特点所稀释，但依然凭借其极高的耐玩度在很多玩家心目中占据一席之地。
【关键词】七类地形，铲子，航行，十四个特色种族，魔力提炼，城市化，宗教排位，每轮特殊奖励，每轮行动牌选择，住宅/交易所/祭坛/神殿/要塞

【推荐度】高 【占地发展建设，中重度德式爱好者

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Superb Euro game. Next to zero randomness, but numerous races and other things to keep it fresh. Some excellent mechanics keep the game interesting, and despite it initially seeming complex, it's actually deceptively  simple. I've even introduced non-gamers to it - and they loved it too!
